text: Israel’s oil production is essentially negligible in global energy markets. The attack against Israel and the outbreak of war in Gaza immediately drove up the price of oil. Conflict in oil-rich regions feeds the view for many investors and policymakers that the world must accelerate oil and gas investments. Building out renewable energy—as well as energy storage and low-carbon fuel technology—will inevitably leave the world less vulnerable to energy crises, says Andrew Keen.. The spike in prices that has resulted from the Israel-Gaza conflict won’t necessarily be sustained for years or even months, says Keen. But it’S important not to lose sight of the long-term trend: we may need oil now, but as the International Energy Agency (IEA) forecast for the first time last month, fossil fuel demand will peak before 2030. It will not change the direction of the transition, but it will make it less likely that it will happen in the near future, Keen says. The price signal is often the single greatest determinant ofprofitability.
label: SENSITIVE

text: “Complicit” is surging in lookups on Merriam-Webster.com. It sits atop the current trending list, above “neophyte,’ “incredulous,” “refute,�” and “recuse.” The word is an adjective meaning “helping to commit a crime or do wrong in some way.’’ A “SNL’ spoof ad, starring host Scarlett Johansson as Ivanka Trump, promotes a fictional perfume, Complicit. It dubs it “the fragrance for the woman who could stop all this, but won’t.   “A feminist, an advocate, a champion for women ― but, like, how?” the voiceover purrs at one point. It’s an image, the spot suggests, that juxtaposes poorly with the visible and reportedly influential role she plays in her father's campaign and administration. It specifically calls out her failure to distance herself from her father’S campaign after the infamous Access Hollywood tape leaked. The tape featured an audio recording of Trump apparently confessing to grabbing women by their genitals without prior consent. “Just so we all know. Complicit’ is a word associated with President Donald Trump, as well as his campaign, administration, and business dealings. It means “helping to commit an act of crime or doing wrong insome way”

text: COP28 is the annual gathering of nearly 200 countries to discuss ways to prevent further manmade climate change. On the agenda: the phase-down — or even phase-out — of fossil fuels, a global goal to help the world adapt to extreme weather events, standards for trading carbon emissions and a new fund to pay for the damage wreaked by global warming. This year’s summit is expected to be the biggest yet, with more than 70,000 people expected. The rotating presidency is held by the United Arab Emirates, and COP28 will be held at the Expo City in Dubai. The talks are scheduled to last a fortnight, but they often spill over by an extra day or two as delegates argue over the final language of a communique that wraps up the meetings. The COP process made a breakthrough deal in Paris in 2015, when all countries agreed for the first time to ensure that temperature increases stay well below 2 degrees Celsius compared with pre-industrial levels. Achieving that means emissions need to fall to “net zero” by the middle of the century.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Tua Tagovailoa hit DeVonta Smith with a 41-yard touchdown pass in overtime. Alabama forced overtime with a 7-yard pass to Calvin Ridley with 3:49 remaining. It was the sixth national championship for Saban, tying him with Bear Bryant for the most in the bowl era. The Bulldogs made it a 13-0 game at halftime when wide receiver Mecole Hardman took a direct snap and scored on a 1-yard run with seven seconds remaining.. “I just thought we needed to throw the ball in the game, and I thought he could do it better,” Saban said of the true freshman out of Hawaii. ‘We’d seen on tape that there was no question that they were going to make a switch,’ Georgia coach Kirby Smart said of Alabama quarterback Jalen Hurts. ’Tua, you’re going to start the second half and we’'re going to rotate the quarterbacks ... see how things go, and we went from there’ The Bulldogs got the ball first in overtime and took a three-point lead on a 51-year field goal by Rodrigo Blankenship. text: Nick Goepper won silver in the men's ski slopestyle at the Pyeongchang Olympics. The U.S. skier struggled to cope with the media attention after Sochi four years ago. The 19-year-old went into rehab and has not had a drink in two-and-a-half years. "I just want to stay humble, stay focussed. I just love skiing and I love competing and I want to get back to it as soon as I can,” he said after his second Olympic win in Pyeonchang, his first since his bronze medal in Sochi in 2010, in the ski sloopestyle final in the 2010 Vancouver Games, in 2010. "It is important to have a plan. Failure to plan is planning to fail,’ said the American after taking second place in Sunday’s ski sloopestyle final at the Games in PYEongchangs. The American says he had considered committing suicide in the build-up to the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi as his drinking got out of hand after the Games. "Alcohol was a symptom of this problem, for sure. That symptom got pretty bad at one point but I was able to go to a treatment center for a couple of months and figure myself out, getting the important help that I needed," he said in a statement after his win in Sunday's final, which was his second medal at the Winter Games in four years. He says he has not been drinking in two and a half years.

text: Scientists from Boston University and the University of Utah demonstrated how bloodstains can yield even more valuable details than what is typically gathered by detectives. By examining the protrusions that deviate from the boundaries of otherwise elliptical bloodstain, the researchers studied how these "tails" are formed. The tail length can reflect information about the size, impact speed, and impact angle of the blood drop that formed the stain. When measured for several blood stains in a stain pattern, the trajectories of the drops can be backtracked to their presumed origin.Knowing the origin of thebloodstains at a crime scene can help detectives determine whether a victim was standing or sitting, or help corroborate or question a witness's testimony. They believe that incorporating tail length into standard blood stain analyses will produce more robust evidentiary information. The study involved a series of high-speed experiments with human blood droplets with diameters of less than a millimeter impacting horizontal surfaces at various angles. They hope it triggers more studies that focus on the length of the tail.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Lobbyists and big oil companies will be part of national delegations when negotiations start on Thursday. The lack of clear rules at the talks about conflict of interest has long been criticised. The last COP in Egypt set a new record for lobbyists, with 636 official delegates working for fossil fuel companies. In Dubai, the lobbies could again have a strong influence on the language of the agreements "and what it means", says Faye Holder, at think tank InfluenceMap. Some NGOs, however, have appealed for a boycott of the talks, while others want to counter lobbyists by turning up themselves in large numbers, says Kick Big Polluters Out. The umbrella group claims that at least 7,200 lobbyists working for Fossil fuel interests have been accredited to COP summits over the last two decades. The COP28 will have a record 70,000 delegates, with oil and gas majors officially invited along with other polluting industries, according to the UN's COP28 president Sultan Al Jaber.

text: Edward Osborne Wilson, the "father of biodiversity," is a visiting professor at Duke. He teaches a course on "Biodiversity and the Meaning of Human Existence" The course is being videotaped and will appear shortly on iTunesU. Wilson is on a crusade to stem the tide of extinctions that threaten to leave us with an impoverished cache of genetic information and, he fears, one unable to support human life.. The conservationist school sees humanity and its needs as paramount. The imperative of environmental stewardship from the conservationists' view is simply good economics. It is the current emphasis on using ecosystem services as a rationale for maintaining habitat that resonates with those arguments of Teddy Roosevelt and Gifford Pinchot, whose philosophy is embodied in John Muir's "The Use of Forests" The conservationists see the public domain as a public domain, which locks up its lands and stops settlement and settlement. What it really does really does is to take the public Domain and make sure that the best use is made of every bit of it, says Aldir Muir. The public domain does not act like a wall built around the wall of the National Forest. It's a place where people can gather, play and enjoy the natural world. It also is a place for people to gather together and share ideas and learn from each other, says Muir, who has been a conservationist for more than 50 years. The U.S. Forest Service is the nation's first chief forester, appointed by Teddy Roosevelt.
label: SENSITIVE

text: OpenAI is hiring a new team to study and protect against potential AI threats. The team will focus on chemical, biological, nuclear, and cybersecurity threats. Aleksander Madry, who is currently on leave from MIT, will be leading the team. Elon Musk, who helped cofound OpenAI, said in February that AI is "one of the biggest risks to the future of civilization" But others, like Meta's Yann LeCun, said claims around superintelligent AI wiping out humanity are "preposterous" and based more on science fiction than reality."We believe that frontier AI models, which will exceed the capabilities currently present in the most advanced existing models, have the potential to benefit all of humanity," OpenAI wrote in its announcement. It will also develop a "Risk-Informed Development Policy" that will include protective actions and a governance structure to hold AI systems accountable, the company said in a blog post this week. It is hiring for anational security threat researcherand aresearch engineer.

text: Karnataka ’s draft of the revised biotech policy, aiming to quadruple the state’s bioeconomy, was released at the Bangalore Tech Summit today. “This policy revision reflects our commitment to staying ahead of the curve and fostering growth in this critical sector,” said CM Siddaramaiah. The draft proposes several initiatives, like creating 5-to 10-acre biotech clusters for startups, SMEs with plug and play facilities, as well as for the established industries seeking to set up manufacturing units. It also proposes setting up a green-field bio foundry in Public-Private-Partnership mode, to address the growing demands of the growth-stage companies and to meet their requirements of GMP Pilot Plant & Scale-up facility. The policy aims to provide Biomanufacturing Unit Investment Subsidy of maximum Rs 10 crore, reimbursement of up to 50% expenses incurred for procuring high-end equipment for undertaking cutting edge R&D (up to Rs 10 lakh)

text: The CLUSSTER project aims to strengthen the French and European cloud industry by creating a cloud dedicated to artificial intelligence, high-performance computing and quantum computing. The project is being led by a consortium of French academic and industrial researchers in numerical calculation and AI: GENCI, CEA, CNRS and Inria, as well as industrialists Eviden (Atos Group), OVHcloud, CS Group, ActiveEon and Qarnot. This as-a-service model will provide access to one of the largest portfolios of computing services and supercomputers, encouraging and enabling the democratization of advanced computing by simplifying the use of public and private data centres. For the first time, this project will help to ensure a continuum between open research, confidential research and industrial activities. The first partners to make their computing resources available are France’s public organizations, GENCi and CNRS-IDRIS, and the private sector, such as OvHcloud.
label: SAFE

text: The World Wildlife Fund is partnering with "The Amazing Spider-Man 2" to promote Earth Hour. The film was able to achieve carbon-neutral status by donating to an Earth Hour Blue project that provides efficient cookstoves to prevent deforestation in the habitat of the Giant Panda. "Earth Hour gives you the power to inspire anyone, even if you're just one person, and Earth Hour is much more than an hour," said actress Emma Stone. Earth Hour takes place this year on March 29th from 8:30pm-9: 30pm. The campaign saw the participation of hundreds of millions across more than 7000 cities and towns and 154 countries and territories in 2013. the film was the most environmentally-friendly big budget feature in the studio's history, according to Sony Pictures Chairman Jeff Blake. "Spider-Man’s always been a very relatable Super Hero. Peter Parker is a hero to all people, and an inspiration, so it seems very fitting that he should join forces with Earth Hour to empower every single individual to help save the planet,” Blake added. The cast of the film has not yet commented on the partnership, but it is expected to arrive in cinemas in the U.S. in the fall of 2014 and will be released in Europe and Australia in the spring. The movie is being produced by Columbia Pictures and distributed by Sony Pictures Distribution, which also produces "The Hobbit" and "The Lord of the Rings" The film is scheduled to be released on September 26, 2014.

text: All-ladies Mötley Crüe tribute band, Girls Girls Girls, broke up in 2014. Rachel Rampleman documents the group's performances and eccentric activities, like working the tailgate parties of the original band. She also documents the nuances of the individual women in the band, who have cover lives like superheroes ranging from guitar legend to broker to hair stylist. The band's bizarre-o world parallels a peculiar moment now inert in music history -- when men got dressed up like sexy ladies with big hair and tight pants and sang some of the most misogynistic songs ever written. As an outsider, it's a little bewildering to witness that love of the hair-metal movement, smelling oddly like Stockholm syndrome, but it is powerful beyond the underlying message of the lyrics of the songs. They endure and subject themselves to the same conversations over and over, just like the same songs over andover. What does it mean to love something that excludes you? Not unlike other marginalized populations who take on a powerful stance repossessing language, girls Girls Girls take on the hair metal movement's brags of all the women they went through like sweaty t-shirts tossed after a show by diving deeper into a deeper love of freedom, limitlessness and forever-youngness that came with machismo. These women are armed with an endless ability to deliver an endless number of drinks at every show. They deliver an ability to beat the original rock stars at their beat, every beat, and every time.
label: UNSAFE

text: Fish farming and shellfish production usually spew far less greenhouse gas emissions than production of beef and other animal protein. Many are like problems that face massive chicken, pig and cattle operations. The farms and the waste from them can degrade and pollute nearby ecosystems. Faced with stinging criticism and tighter regulations, fish farmers are trying new ways to boost production and minimize harm. In a warehouse near Miami, large indoor tanks are designed to mimic the natural environment of salmon by establishing the right temperature, the right salinity and the right lighting. The idea: Grow the salmon indoors to reduce exposure to parasites, warming waters and algae blooms that threaten the fish grown in farms in open waters near shore — and in turn reduce the fish’s impact on the shoreline. The Protein Problem is an AP series that examines the question: Can we feed this growing world without starving the planet? To see the full project, visit https://projects.apnews.com/features/2023/the-protein-problem/index.html.

text: The 300-acre landslide in Oso, Washington, which killed at least 30 people, reveals a consequence of a relatively unregulated and unseen industry. Logging was not the sole cause of the disaster, but logging apparently played a major role. The media often do not investigate the reasons behind an event such as the landslide, attributing to "Mother Nature" or "Acts of God" disasters that were actually manmade. A system of belief that defies science and justifies irresponsible logging has become entrenched in our government agencies and universities, says John Rizzuto, author of the book "Logging: The Truth About The Environmental Cost of Our Forests" He says logging plans are not widely publicized, and most people remain unaware of the devastation wrought by typical modern logging practices, which rely on large machines and few workers to clear-cut the land. author: Logging proponents trivialize the damage from logging, arguing that although the land initially looks ravaged, the trees will grow back. The fact that we all use toilet paper is supposed to provide a carte blanche for loggers to do whatever they want to the forest, he says. Rizzutto: Loggers escape the burden of proving green-light claims without adequate environmental analysis or protection of vital resources, such as water, land and wildlife. In Massachusetts, a group of citizens applied modern science -- bringing in experts as needed -- to refute one logging company's claim after one logger shot down 22 reasons to log.
label: SENSITIVE

text: NASA is pulling back from its Mars Sample Return program in order to develop a revised way of bringing the Martian rocks back to Earth. The space agency is pausing work on MSR in response to a recent report that called out the mission’s mounting costs and delays. The Sample Return mission involves a group of robots, landers, and orbiters working on and off Mars. Despite its complex nature, NASA will likely not give up on its Martian sample retrieval mission as it makes up a great portion of the space agency's plans to send its astronauts to the Red Planet in the 2030s. It also holds significant value in terms of providing important information regarding whether Mars could have hosted some form of life during its ancient past. It just might take us a little while longer to have those answers as the mission seemingly still has a long way to go before it can drop off the other worldly samples on our planet. The full lifecycle cost will likely range between $8 billion and $11 billion, far more than original estimates.
label: SAFE

text: Leos Janáček's Jenůfa premiered in Brno in 1904 and returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday for the first time in ten years. The bleak opera is a fascinating and elegantly-proportioned psychological study that elevates the thorough development of themes of jealousy, shame, and love into an airtight and believable case study. Karita Mattila made a tremendous and extraordinarily-paced house-role debut as the crumbling sexton's widow. Unfortunately, though, Mattila was matched nowhere else in the cast, least of all by the JenŮfa of Ukranian Oksana Dyka. David Robertson lead with great attention to the orchestral writing and orchestrations of the village scenes have a lot of moving parts and scaled down for the intimate Act II. The Metropolitan Opera adroitly responded accordingly and the Chorus sounded in top shape. Other standouts of the cast included Hanna Schwarz, Buryja Garvin, Bradley Garvin and Ying Fang, whose pearly pearly soprano was indispensable and balanced his generous phrasing in his role as the Grandmother. The Met's production was directed by Olivier Tambosi, whose lackluster-but-inoffensive production had her spend most of the evening posing near the stage-dominating rock. It was a welcome and overdue return for the undiminished Finnish sopran. This JenŅfa wasn't so much a layered, tormented young woman as much as a baleful, shrieking village girl with a penchant for literacy.
label: UNSAFE

text: Astronauts will venture outside the International Space Station on Tuesday for an emergency spacewalk. The primary device failed on Saturday, leaving the $100 billion orbiting laboratory to depend on a backup system. The station’s current five-member crew from the United States, Russia and France were never in any danger, NASA said. The ISS serves as a research laboratory for biology, life science, materials science and physics experiments, as well as astronomical observations and Earth remote sensing. It is owned and operated by 15 nations, flies about 250 miles (400 km) above Earth and orbits the planet about every 90 minutes. It has been continuously staffed since 2000 and is manned by rotating crews of astronauts and cosmonauts from the U.S., Russia, France and other nations.. Earlier on Sunday, Whitson assembled and tested a spare electronics box to replace the failed device, which had been installed during a spacewalks on March 30, said NASA spokesman Dan Huot. Station managers are go for Tuesday Spacewalk with @AstroPeggy & @Aro2fish to change out failed data relay box. http://t.co/TCV2rcvf3C pic.twitter.com/OCep5L0ux7 NASA”s last emergency spacEWalk took place in December 2015 when two U.s. astronauts left the station to release the brakes on a robot arm’’ mobile transporter. text: Joosje Duk's short film “Night” has screened at festivals in New York, Chicago, Connecticut, Florida, Boston, Nashville and the Netherlands. Duk is loosely based on a transaction Duk observed while waiting outside a nightclub in France. She is, in other words, a fabulist with a progressive perspective on cinema’s ability to deliver messages and unearth truths about the world. The ironic shift that occurs more than halfway through the short evokes a mastery commonly associated with more experienced filmmakers, Duk says. The short was the recipient of our annual Impact Award, given to a submission with social or political resonance. It was screened about three dozen shorts playing at Brooklyn”s Nitehawk Shorts Festival; we chose ‘Night’ as the recipient for our annual impact award.“Look here, here, look here,’” Duk said. “It was just the two black girls being rejected in an all-white world. When we were rehearsing it and rereading it and sharing it with people, it felt a little too preachy, and a little much like ‘Look, here’S what I’m doing.’ “ Duk also loved “Requiem for a Dream,” “Big Fish” and the Japanese drama “Late Spring Spring!” She also loved a Darren Aronofsky film, “Mothers of the Dream.”

text: The James Webb Space Telescope is sending back stunning images of the universe. The European Space Agency has teamed up with watchmaker Swatch to create a watch face using one of these images. The offer launched on Wednesday and will run through December 17. In a related effort, the United States Postal Service last year launched a specially designed stampto celebrate the James Webb Telescope. The image on the stamp shows an artist’s digitally created depiction of the telescope, set against a striking starscape. It is hoped that the images could help unlock some of the mysteries of the Hubble telescope's predecessor, the Herschel Space Telescope, which went into operation in 1995. The Herschel telescope is the most powerful space telescope ever built, using its near-infrared camera (NIRCam) to peer deeper into space than ever.

text: Cold weather will continue into April but will not be as cold as earlier this winter. After mid-March, there could be as many as four milder days above normal. The brown marmorated stink bug, however, is well-adapted to colder climates. The mosquitoes responsible for the spread of West Nile Virus are hardier and are expected to continue as a major presence during 2014 in Pennsylvania, officials say.. The average mean temperature in a good part of Pennsylvania late next week could be before the 23 F mean, AccuWeather.com Long-Range Expert Jack Boston said. The cold spell that we're coming out of is likely going to be the coldest one, but that doesn't mean we won't have another cold spell," Boston said, adding that the cold spell is likely to last through the end of the month and into early next year. The weather will be more unsettled next week in the East, maybe a snowstorm in the interior of the region, Boston said; after that storm, there will be another blast of cold air, but not as bad as earlier in the winter, he said. this winter has put a dent in the invasive insect population, but it won't be a total wipeout, experts say. The bugs have been detected in 40 states, causing severe agricultural problems in Pennsylvania,. Delaware, Maryland, New Jersey, Virginia and West Virginia. They will huddle together and seek shelter in buildings, cracks of giant rock outcroppings or inside dead standing trees.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Yahoo Sports viewed hundreds of pages of documents from the years-long probe. The documents show an underground recruiting operation that could create NCAA rules issues. Documents tie some of the biggest names and programs in the sport to activity that appears to violate amateurism rules. There’s potential impermissible benefits and preferential treatment for players and families of players at Duke, North Carolina, Texas, Kentucky, Michigan State, USC, Alabama and a host of other schools. The breadth of names, schools and current players could offer a vexing test for both university compliance offices and the NCAA's enforcement division.. The NCAA has been in constant contact with the feds but so far has had minimal direct involvement with the case, as they’ve been careful to respect the boundaries of the criminal investigation. No one is certain how the NCAA enforcement office would potentially handle the cases. “There's potential for chaos, as it depends on the number of cases and the amount of information released,” said Atlanta-based lawyer Stu Brown, a veteran of representing schools and coaches in NCAA compliance cases. The amount of detail for activities that have come under federal scrutiny is uncommon, but the records show an uncommon amount of activity for Brian Bowen, Brian Bowen's dad. For example, the expense reports have hundreds of lines for “Flight for Brian” Bowen, the dad of Brian Bowen; Bowen did not appear in the documents, but did not have to pay for the flight, according to the records.

text: A Canadian company is poised to launch the nation's first tar sands mining operation at PR Springs. Supporters say it will be a boon for Utah's local economy and the country's energy security. Opponents fear real impacts on local wildlife and tourism, as well as downstream effects on already polluted air. "We don't need to do this," says Celeste Bradford, 10, standing at the U.S. Oil Sands site. "Now is the time to get everyone to look at Canada," says Raphael Cordray, who leads Utah Tar Sands Resistance. "If they failed to get a hold of investors and make this process economically viable, it's because they failed," says Tim Wagner, a Utah organizer with the Sierra Club. "There's no question that this is bad for air, for water, for animals," says Cordray,. "We could catch up with China. That's not even a joke," says Urry, editor-in-chief of EnviroNews USA, who documented numerous animals that succumbed to the gooey sludge leftover from the mine. The molasses-like substance, also known as oil sands, is a mix of bitumen oil, sand, clay and water, and contains 90 percent less sulfur than Albertan tar sands and overall smaller greenhouse gas footprint than those found in Albertan oil. "They've done a lot of clearing, and are widening the road down here," says Katy Todd, the company's chief executive officer, of PR Springs' land.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Ballet companies face the same patronage predicament as opera companies. Misty Copeland's advocacy has spotlighted for the broad public what was once a concern debated in relatively small circles: why aren't there more black ballet dancers? "Ballet is an international language - you can take ballet class anywhere and we are already united in our language," says Kristine Elliott Elliott, a former American Ballet Theatre soloist. The Gugulethu Project sends talented South African students to study in the U.S. and brings American choreographers, teachers, and dancers to teach in South Africa. The principles inherent in the study of ballet, including self-discipline, perseverance, respect for the self and the integrity of the body, are all transferable into the daily lives of the students who are fortunate enough to be involved in such training. "I learn a great deal from this project," says Elliott, who understands how arts education has been integral to the healing of South Africa's post-apartheid post-trauma communities. "In addition to giving people a way of working through trauma, working in the arts has given impoverished children a way to imagine a better future," says Ndaba Ndabeni, founder of London-based N'da Dance Company. "It has equipped them with life skills, helped direct them away from destructive behavior," she says. "Seeing them succeed and return, in many cases, to their communities, has been an inspirational learning process for the next generation of youngsters"
label: SENSITIVE

"I get to see more of the scenery, talk to more people than I would otherwise," van KuIJck said. text: The fish, found in Thailand, is called Cryptotora thamicola. The way it can walk and climb is unlike any other known fish. It moves almost like a salamander, researchers say. They believe this fish may be a link to a key moment in evolution, when finned creatures of the sea became the limbed creatures on the land. "From an evolutionary perspective, this is a huge finding," an author says. "This is one of the first fish that we have that is a living species that acts in a way that we think they must have acted when they evolved from a fluid environment to a terrestrial environment," says another author of the paper."What these fish do in complete darkness is they stick to the rock and they climb waterfalls completely underwater," an expert says. 'It's like a little blind cavefish squirming its way up a rock," she adds. "It's very, very unique," another researcher says of the cavefish's ability to support its own bodyweight against gravity using its pelvis and vertebral column. 'This is a big finding,' another author says, adding that it could offer a glimpse at the moment when life transitioned from the sea to the land some 420 million years ago. The fish is able to walk on its hind legs and support its bodyweight on its back, according to the researchers' research. The study was published in the journal Nature Scientific Reports. the fish, which can appear to walk, uses its fins and generally relies on the flow of water around it to keep upright, can support itself by itself. A 2009 video shows the fish in action.
label: SAFE

text: The U.S. Department of Agriculture's "plant hardiness zone map" was updated Wednesday for the first time in a decade. The map will give new guidance to growers about which flowers, vegetables and shrubs are most likely to thrive in a particular region. The lowest likely winter temperature overall is 2.5 degrees (1.4 degrees Celsius) warmer than when the last map was published in 2012. Southern staples like magnolia trees and camellias may now be able to grow without frost damage in once-frigid Boston.Winter temperatures and nighttime temperatures are rising faster than daytime andsummer temperatures, which is why the lowest winter temperature is changing faster than the U.s. temperature overall. "You wouldn't want to plant plants that aren't adapted right now for where you're living," said Theresa Crimmins, who studies climate change and growing seasons at the University of Arizona and was not involved in creating the map. "There are a lot of downsides to the warmer winter temperatures, too," said Crimmins.
label: SAFE

text: Sally Kohn: Worst effects of global warming are going to fall on the shoulders of our kids. Kohn asks President Obama to do everything within his power to prevent the carbon pollution. She says power plants are the single-largest contributor of carbon emissions in the U.S., but there's no limit to the amount of the global warming pollution they can spew.Kohn: 80 percent of Americans now deem global warming a "serious problem" and 70 percent believe it needs to become a priority on the political agenda, she says. She asks Obama to implement the carbon standards for new and existing power plants and reject projects like the Keystone tar sands pipeline that will increase global warming emissions."As dads, we want to protect our kids from everything. President Obama has the chance to help protect all of our children right now," Kohn says. "He can take this crucial step and forever be remembered as the dad, and the president, who put us on the track to stopping global warming. I hope he delivers. I'm right there with him. I've been doing this work for decades, so I've long worried about the consequences for my kids of pumping unlimited amounts of heat-trapping gasses into our atmosphere," says Kohn, a father of two teens who suffer from asthma, which is made worse by smog pollution. "On these "bad air" days, there's a greater chance Rory or Michaela will suffer an asthma attack -- especially if they're pushing themselves extra hard during a make-it-or-break-it soccer match," she adds.

text: "GQ" named Colin Kaepernick the magazine’s Citizen Of The Year. Colin Kaepernick took a stance when no athlete with his profile did in 2016. He knelt to protest the unjust killing of Black Americans by the police. When you risk it all for the people, that's patriotic. "I was struck by how humble this man is, how one man can remain so focused and so present up," he said. "How many of these ‘patriots’ would describe him as a thug? How far down the list would the list of police brutality fall? Pretty far? Think about it for a minute" He added: "He has never let any of the noise distract him from what he set out to do. Not once did he blink and say, ‘I’m not going to give up on this.’ That is pretty damn patriotic. Again, that ispretty damn patriotic" "He is not just throwing around dollars and hoping it inspires some sort of change. He is trying to change the world, and he is succeeding," he added. "That is the true American patriot. That is what I am proud of. That's what I stand for." "I am proud to be an American. I stand by what I believe in," Kaepernick said in a statement. "This is my country, and I will continue to stand for it. I will never back down from a fight for justice, equality and equality for all," he continued.

text: The comet, known as 12P/Pons-Brooks, is exploding relatively often and, confoundingly, far away from the sun. The comet is expected to reach peak brightness in mid-April 2024 as it continues on its 71.2-year journey around the Sun. At its closest, the comet will still be about one-and-half astronomical units away, or put another away: even further from Earth than the sun, a researcher says. "It might be bright enough that you can see with your naked eye or with binoculars, but that's not because it's going to be super close," Teddy Kareta tells Insider. "I think a lot of people are really excited about it," Kareta says of the comet's likely appearance in Earth's skies next spring. "Devil Comet" is a reference to the appearance of horns on the comet, which are actually tails of gas and dust formed by an odd series of explosive outbursts that scientists still do not understand.
label: SAFE

text: Euclid's instruments are sensitive enough to pick up the smallest galaxies. One picture shows 1,000 galaxies in a cluster 240 million light-years away. text: Ancient Egyptians used honey as a religious offering to their gods. In a more macabre line of uses, it was an important part of the embalming process. In the Middle East, cadavers steeped in honey were allegedly an incredibly valuable medical concoction, known as mellified man. Honey happens to have some antibacterial qualities, especially if it's dark, which is why it's been used in wound care for centuries. It might sound a little weird to smear honey on a wound or wrap an injury in honey-soaked bandages, but that's exactly what people did historically. The flavor and color of honey can vary radically, from light golden blonde to rich, dark manuka honey -- a prized New Zealand export. text: The season officially begins at 4:44 p.m. EDT during the autumnal equinox. The sun crosses directly over the Earth's equator and both day and night are about equal. Fall will last a solid three months until the beginning of Winter on December 21, according to the U.S. Naval Observatory. It's basically the time for trees to reevaluate their priorities and start anew. And it really is the perfect time for a hot cup of tea. And campfires. Really, it's just a time for nature to be beautiful. There are fall breezes. And some stellar food. Because there's nothing better than a warm cookie on a cold night. So, fall, we welcome you with open arms. Bring on the pie. A previous version of this entry misstated the official start time of fall on September 22. It was actually September 22, when the sun crossed over the equator for the first time in more than 100 years. It is also the first day of fall in the United States. It will last until the end of the month on November 21. The official start of fall will be on November 22, which is the last day of the summer season. The first snow is expected to fall on November 23. It could be as early as November 26. It may also be as late as November 27, depending on the weather. It can be as cold as November 28. It might be as warm as November 29, if the weather cooperates.

text: Study: Sea levels could rise by 2.3 metres for each degree Celsius that global temperatures increase. Sea levels rose by 17 cm last century and the rate has accelerated to more than 3 mm a year. U.N. panel of scientists says heat-trapping gases from burning fossil fuels are nudging up temperatures. A small number of scientists dismiss human-influenced global warming, arguing natural climate fluctuations are responsible for sea-level rise.. Some scientific studies have projected sea level rise of up to 2 metres by 2100, a figure that would swamp large. tracts of land from Bangladesh to Florida. The IPCC has said temperatures are likely to be 0.4 to 1.0 degrees Celsius warmer from 2016-35 than in the two decades to 2005. The Ice2sea project has said sea levels would rise by between 16.5 and 69 cm under a scenario of moderate global warming this century. The biggest impact rising seas will have is that storms will be more destructive in the near future, says David Vaughan, head of the Ice2Sea project. The project is trying to narrow down uncertainties about how melting ice will swell the oceans. It is based on a study by the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research, a leading climate research institute in Germany. The study is the first to examine evidence from climate history and combine it with computer simulations of contributing factors to long-term sea- level increases. "Our results indicate that major adaptation at our coastlines will be necessary," says Anders Levermann.

text: Australian company Star Scientific has announced it will start building a factory in Albuquerque, New Mexico in 2024. The investment is about $100 million, and the plant will eventually employ 200 employees to work at a 50-acre site that will contain up to 10 buildings. The process is called HERO which stands for Hydrogen Energy Release Optimiser. Any desired temperature up to 700C degrees can be used to heat homes and offices. But it can also heat water into steam to drive turbines that produce electricity. It is similar to what happens in a coal-fired power plant, except there the coal is combusted and releases heavy carbon emissions. If the inflow is green hydrogen, there will be no carbon emissions in the entire process. But lots of energy will have been used to electrolyze water into hydrogen and oxygen, which is an inefficient process. The full-life advantage of HERO is not clear, because blue hydrogen is produced along with a biproduct, CO2, that will have to be removed from the system.
label: SAFE

text: The James Webb Space Telescope will be launched in 2018. It will bring the deepest and farthest reaches of the physical universe much closer to observers on Earth than anything previously could. Webb will study every phase in the history of our universe, ranging from the first luminous glows after the Big Bang to the formation of solar systems capable of supporting life on planets like Earth. The spectacular images expected back from Webb will be like nothing else scientists have ever seen before ― big or small. It's easy to appreciate Webb’s size in this image showing team members standing in front of a full-scale Webb model at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland. The $9 billion telescope is made possible by a global effort including NASA, the European Space Agency and the Canadian Space Agency. The Hubble Telescope will continue photographing incredible outer space imagery, but it will not be close to Earth, where it has required humans to make “on-site” repairs to keep it functioning. It’ll be on its own, in an orbit around the sun, and will take pictures of the universe from as far away as 20 billion miles in the sky. The telescope will take astronomers all the way back in time to the beginning of thePhysical universe. It is named after former NASA administrator James Webb, who died in 2011. He will be remembered for his contributions to space exploration, including the creation of the Hubble Telescope and the development of the X-ray and X-Men.
label: SAFE

text: On May 13, 2010, John Seed's first blog appeared on The Huffington Post. Blogging has been a life-transforming experience and a door-opener, he says. "Every word matters. You never know who is reading your blog," he writes. "I have never had so many friends. Oh, and a few frenemies too... Something I need to do again: The "Paintings and Palettes" and "Studio Visit" blogs were a lot of work, but aA list of interviews can be found at http://www.johnseed.com/p/interviews. Some Acknowledgements: I owe a great deal of thanks to Arianna Huffington, Kimberly Brooks, Kathleen Massara and Katherine Brooks (my editors) The energy that I used to put into making things seems to all go into writing these days. A list of favorite stories: If I have a favorite moment, it is the one I'm writing about at any given moment. I'm often asked if I have favorite stories to tell, and if I do, it's the one that I've been writing about for the past five years. I write about representational painting because there is simply so much good work out there that hasn't gotten the attention that it deserves. I am writing as a writer, not as an artist: Yes, I am a writing artist at this moment in my life, and I'm very proud of it. I have learned a lot from blogging.
label: SAFE

text: The Drive-Thru is a natural subject for me as I like to paint places that people don't go to be there. The titles of these, and of most of my paintings, are the street addresses of the places the paintings depict. The mix of the allure of cheap comfort food, tempered by all the things I know are wrong about it keep me interested in this kind of subject. If I felt entirely critical about it, or entirely enticed by it -- it wouldn't stay interesting to me long enough to do something like make a painting of it. The figures get sliced by objects sometimes and are never facing the viewer. If the figure was facing you, then the painting would be a foil for the character of that figure rather than having the viewer be the most important figure in the painting. To me it makes the painting a more plausible space for the viewer to enter when you see the painting on a wall. I like doing this because it allows me to tell you something specific and true without coloring it emotionally. Sort of the opposite of soundtrack music where for the most part the job is to falsify emotion. This one was a visual treat for me, I was drawn in by the long horizontal format, all of the brushed steel and stacks of cups. It also looks like they want you to try the cookies since they have stickers of them on the window. It's a Burger King window. 6502 Laurel Canyon Boulevard 8 x 20 inches, oil on panel A KFC drive-thru window.
label: SAFE

text: The HCOB Global Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) for Italian manufacturing fell to 44.9 from 46.8 in September. The reading was below the median forecast of 46.2 in a Reuters survey of 15 analysts. "The recession in the manufacturing sector steepens ... manufacturing is set to decline 0.5% in the fourth quarter of 2023," said H COB economist Norman Liebke. The Italian economy stagnated in the third quarter, national statistics bureau ISTAT reported on Tuesday, after contracting by 0.4% in April-June period. The manufacturing output sub-index fell to 46.4 from a previous 47.4, while new orders declined to 40.3 from 43.2 -- both firmly in the sub-50 territory indicating contraction. "Italian manufacturers are stuck in a rut with weak demand. Uncertainty surrounding the economic climate is clearly weighing on order book volumes, which shrank for the seventh month running,"Liebke said.

A crash is a crash. I’d just like to know about the elbow, really" The tour, which began on Saturday and finishes on July 23, is made up of 21 stages over about 2,200 miles. The cyclist with the lowest overall time wins a yellow jersey and is awarded the green sprinter's jersey for five years in a row, and was vying to tie the record by claiming a sixth this year in Vittel, Germany. The rule says that any rider making a willful obstruction “against one of the 1st 10 riders placed” faces elimination, according to the International Cycling Union. In 2010, Australian Mark Renshaw got the boot for trying to headbutt fellow rider Julian Dean in a sprint finish in the race’s fourth stage, officials said. The 32-year-old, who was taken to a hospital for evaluation, said he suffered a gashed finger, which he guessed would need stitches, as well as an injured arm that was later seen placed in a sling. text: Astronomers have discovered a vast galaxy made up almost entirely of dark matter. Dubbed Dragonfly 44, the collection of stars lies about 330 million light-years from Earth. It contains only about 1 billion stars, which is roughly 1 percent the number of stars in our galaxy. 99.99 percent of the mass in what some are calling “the Milky Way’s dark twin” is in the form of dark Matter, an invisible substance that is believed to make up 85 percent of everything in the universe. The greater a galaxy's overall mass, the faster its stars move relative to each other, astronomers say.. Theory holds that dark matter particles annihilate each other and emit gamma radiation whenever they collide, Pieter van Dokkum, lead author of a paper about the discovery, told The Huffington Post. “It is an exciting discovery,” said Jeremiah Ostriker, an astrophysicist at Columbia University. ‘It gives us a chance to study [dark matter] in detail ― close-up.’ “The race is on to find massive dark galaxies are even closer to us, so we can look for feeble signals that may reveal a dark matter particle,’ he said in a news release. The discovery could bring us one step closer to understanding what the mysterious stuff is all about, he added. The team of astronomers who discovered the dark galaxy were completely surprised to find the dark matter galaxy, but those are tiny dwarf galaxies that are about a million times less massive than Dragon fly 44.
label: SAFE

text: As much as 98 per cent of China's development funding for Pakistan came in form of "less-than-generous loans" Only two per cent came in the form of grants between 2000 and 2021 in Pakistan. China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), a global infrastructure and investment initiative by Beijing, was launched in 2013. It is thought to be the largest partnership of Beijing's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) It increased to over $62 billion over time, and at least $25 billion was invested in cash-strapped Pakistan, a report said.. Pakistan and China have a long history of economic collaboration, and this year marks ten years of such ties. Last month, Chinese President Xi Jinping proposed to step up bilateral cooperation with Pakistan during his meeting with visiting caretaker Prime Minister Anwar-ul-Haq Kakar in Beijing to celebrate the 10 years of the CPEC. text: Researchers from the Institute of Atmospheric Physics of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and the Pacific Northwest National Lab in the U.S. have revealed that "hot model" climate projections have been overestimating the warming in China. They introduce a novel method to correct this issue, potentially reshaping climate change adaptation and mitigation strategies. The study is likely to have broad relevance and plays a pivotal role in reshaping how the global community responds to the CMIP6 mismatch with current consensus expectations, the researchers said in a statement. They developed an efficient emergent constraint method in two steps. First, they corrected future warming projections using present-day global mean surface air temperature warming. Then, they adjusted the projection results using local residual warming to account for local feedback.Results showed that the future warming of mean andextreme temperatures, constrained by this method, is 1.29°C and 1.20°C lower than the raw projections for the end of the 21st century under the high-emission scenario.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Researchers at the University of California, Irvine, invented a nanowire-based battery. Gold nanowires were coated with a manganese dioxide shell and encased in an electrolyte made of a Plexiglas-like gel. The researchers tested the power of the electrode up to 200,000 times over three months. They were shocked to find that, despite all of the tests, there was no loss of capacity or power and the Nanowires didn't fracture. The new battery technology could edge us closer to possibly developing longer lasting commercial batteries for computers, smartphones, cars and spacecraft in the future, the researchers say."The coated electrode holds its shape much better, making it a more reliable option," said research lead author Mya Le Thai, a UCI doctoral candidate, in a statement. "This research proves that ... we can make these kinds of batteries a reality," Le Thai said in the statement. batteries so far have been engineered to withstand only a certain number of cycles, such batteries could only achieve 7,000 cycles, according to Discovery News. The gel may plasticize the metal oxide in the battery and give it added flexibility, while also preventing any cracking -- allowing it to last longer than expected, the scientists say. "We were not attempting to extend the cycle life of these electrodes," said Dr. Reginald Penner, a chemistry professor at the university. The research was intended to prepare a solid state version of ​them by substituting a gel electrolyte for the liquid electrolyte.
label: SAFE

text: Seventy-one years ago, in June 1944, Edgar Krasa, then a young prisoner at the Theresienstadt concentration camp, was among some 60 Jewish men and women prisoners who lifted their collective voices in a choral performance of Verdi's Requiem. The concert was ordered as part of an elaborate, sinister hoax staged by the Nazis as a "model ghetto" to mislead the world into believing that it was not mistreating -- and murdering -- Jews and other prisoners. Seven decades after that concert, the now 94-year old KrasA, who endured deportation to Auschwitz and a death march, sat in Boston's magnificent Symphony Hall, as Murry Sidlin led a production of Defiant Requiem, a multi-media concert-drama Sidlin created to keep the memory of this remarkable story alive. The Boston performance featured the Orchestra of Terezin Remembrance, led by Sidlin and the world acclaimed Tanglewood Festival Chorus, whose powerful voices were a perfect, heart-stopping pairing with the emotional weight of the program. Award winning Boston-based actors Will LeBow and Jeremiah Kissel joined Sidlin in the program readings. In a conversation after the concert, soloist Nathan Stark said performing with DefiantRequiem was an emotional and eye-opening learning experience. "Here were these people going into the depth of hell, but as they went, they made it as beautiful as they could and using art to do it," he said.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Mr. T, real name Laurence Tureaud, began tweeting about the Winter Olympics over the weekend. The actor on the 1980s TV series “The A-Team” is getting “pumped” for Pyeongchang 2018. I like a good Underdog story where an athlete or a team makes it to the top, inspite of it all. That’s what the Olympics is all about. Each country sends their best to do their best! And each Olympian feels it’S their duty to try! Let me tell you something, you may notWinning, but You never Lose if You try!”. He added: � “I like tough competition, but I also like to see good sportsmanship. Just do your best, give it all you got, and then shake hands when it's over.’“I feel so bad when an athlete slips and falls after all those years of training. But, they don't stay down.. they get back up and try to finish their routine.”

text: Seed plants are the most advanced plant group in the world, accounting for two-thirds of all plant species and shaping the predominant flora of our world. The Earth was very different more than 300 million years ago during the Carboniferous period, when ferns were the dominant flora. The researchers found that the Casparian strip and suberin lamellae did not originate simultaneously. The former emerged from the common ancestor of all vascular plants, while the latter evolved in the common ancestors of seed plants. This finding challenges the longstanding assumption regarding suberInLemllae and offers new perspectives for studying the evolution of these structures. They also found that a significant expansion of homologous genes occurred in theCommon ancestor of gymnosperms and angiosperms. The findings suggest that the emergence of suber inLemlllae might have contributed to the drought adaptability of seed. plants, thus promoting their rise after the onset of arid conditions in the late carboniferous.
label: SAFE

text: When a person has no control over a situation, the feeling of helplessness that he or she will develop may be debilitating. The theory of learned helplessness posits that helplessness is itself a source of feelings of passivity, anxiety, and depression. Leaders should encourage their team to slow down and take a break from the “train” of fast-paced life. To be human is to be a paradox. We must both accept and oppose suffering. This can be especially helpful for leaders, who may feel obligated to reconcile team members' conflicts. There are situations where this just isn’t logistically possible, or the attempt to get involved will do more harm than good. By accepting Scott Samuelson’s conclusion, time and relationships can be saved. The Gay Science (The Joyful Wisdom) by Fredrich Nietzsche is life affirming philosophy, beneficial to anyone feeling helpless. This book is a collection of short phrases and poems, making it one of Nietzsche's most digestible works.
label: SENSITIVE

text: NASA's New Horizons spacecraft flew past Pluto in July 2015. The spacecraft’s high-resolution photos revealed its surprisingly complex geology. New Horizons has continued phoning home data from the flyby, which ends this month. It will then continue its journey in the Kuiper Belt to reach another object some 1 billion miles beyond Pluto by 2019. It all started with a postal stamp in 1991, which read “Pluto Not Yet Explored.’ “Now we’re back at the drawing board, trying to figure out how small planets work,” Alan Stern, principal investigator of the New Horizons mission, said. “Hopefully, this will inspire people to do even bigger things, because there are so many big challenges to get rid of poverty and pollution, and to do big things in space,’” he said. The VR experience is an appendix to an 11-episode series called “Destination: Pluto,�” said Jorge Franzini, a producer of the series. It was created by CuriosityStream, a young company that provides subscription-based streaming of documentary film. It is available on the CuriosityStream app and on the company's website, CuriosityStream.com. The series is the first in a series of 11 about the Pluto mission, which is expected to run through the end of the year. The second series will be about the mission to Mars in the 2030s, and then the Mars Curiosity rover in the 2050s.
label: SAFE

text: OnePlus 11 has three cameras on the back: a 50MP main camera, a 48MP wide-angle camera, and a 32MP Portrait Telephoto camera. The Google Pixel 8 only has two cameras: a 12MP camera and a 10.5MP selfie camera. Both phones use a spectral sensor to improve color accuracy. The Pixel 8’s realism and balance shine through in each photo. However, while I like the atmospheric shots the OnePlus 11 can take, the Pixel 8 wins out on the natural tone. Neither phone manages to extract a lot of detail through its natural-looking photos. It’re not hard to love the Pixel 11’S colorful and wide-angled photos, though they remain an eye-catcher, while thePixel 8 has more detail in the photo, especially when you crop it down. The results may surprise you in one key category: the results may not be possible to spot when you have the two side-side or front cameras down.

text: Major fossil fuel countries' plans to expand oil, gas and coal production would push the world far beyond the Paris deal's 1.5C global warming limit. Future of fossil fuels will be a key flashpoint when world leaders meet at the COP28 climate conference later this month. Most of the world's leading producers of fossil fuel have pledged to achieve "net-zero" emissions by midcentury. But the production plans of the top 20 producing countries are heading in the opposite direction, a UN report says. The report covers 20 countries that account for 82 percent of production and 73 percent of consumption of world's fossil fuel supply, including the United States, China, Russia, Australia and COP28 host United Arab Emirates. It found that planned increases in production in these countries would produce 460 percent more coal, 82 percent more gas, and 29 percent more oil than would be in line with the 1. 5C limit. a "large discrepancy" between governments' production plans and the need to rapidly move away from fossil fuels, says lead author on the report.
label: SENSITIVE

text: An upcoming magazine called “Disabled People Destroy Science Fiction’ hopes to “put disabled voices at the center of the narrative,” editor Elsa Sjunneson-Henry said. “I want to make it so that able-bodied readers can’t look away from, or explain away ableism,’ she said. For the past three years, the so-called “Destroy” series has worked to diversify the sci-fi landscape by publishing anthologies highlighting voices traditionally marginalized in the genre. The first three editions of “ destroy” are “Women Destroy Science fiction,  “Queers Destroy Sciencefiction” and “People of Colo(u)r Destroy Science Science Fiction.” Each disrupts a specific vision of the future that’s decidedly outdated, the magazines hoped to inflect readers’ understandings of the present through vivid visions of thefuture. The magazine is still looking for submissions in all writing categories, but is already on board, with writers including Rachel Swirsky, Alice Wong, Khairani Barokka and Khairi Bogi Takács on the board, as well as the editor-in-chief of Lightspeed Magazine, Dominik Parisien. It is currently fundraising on Kickstarter for the fourth edition of ‘destroy’ The first edition of 'destroy' was published by Lightspeed magazine in 2012, and the second edition was published in 2013.
label: SENSITIVE

text: NASA shared a photo of a memorial to the victims of the 9/11 attacks. The memorial is located on the abrasion tool on the Mars Exploration Rover Mission. The photo was originally taken and shared with the world on Sept. 11, 2011, during the 10-year anniversary of the attacks. Back in 2001, workers at Honeybee Robotics, which was located less than a mile from the World Trade Center, built the rover’s rock ab rasion tool. The American flag is displayed on a cable guard made of aluminum recovered from Ground Zero. The U.S. commemorated the 15-yeariversary of the September 11th terrorist attacks on Sunday, September 11, 2013, with a series of events in Washington, D.C. and across the country. The events were led by President Barack Obama, who was in the White House for the event, along with Vice President Joe Biden and other dignitaries from around the world. The event was held at the National Mall in New York City, where a memorial was held in honor of those killed in the attacks on the Pentagon, the South Lawn of the Whitehouse, and the East Side of the Lincoln Tunnel. It was also held in New Jersey, where the Pentagon is located, and in Pennsylvania, which is home to the World War II Memorial, which also was damaged in the terrorist attacks in World War I. The ceremony was attended by President George W. Bush, former President Bill Clinton, and members of Congress.

text: Semen Elistratov is the first athlete from Russia to win a medal at the Winter Olympics. He dedicated his accomplishment to compatriots he said had been banned from the Games. The International Olympic Committee is reportedly investigating his comments because of their apparently political nature. Elistatrov was suspended from skating in 2016 after the banned heart drug meldonium was found in his system. He was later granted amnesty by the World Anti-Doping Agency, which determined that low concentrations of the drug found in samples before March 1, 2016, were acceptable. He is one of the athletes competing at Pyeongchang under the banner of the Olympic Athletes from Russia team, which must follow strict IOC guidelines, including not wearing his country’s colors and refraining from “any public form of publicity, activity and communication associated with the national flag, anthem, emblem and symbol.” The IOC will report back at the end of the Games to the executive board to see if not just the letter but the spirit of the law has been breached, a spokesman told the BBC. The IOC banned Russia from competing in the Winter Games over its state-backed doping program over the past few years, but has since allowed some athletes to take part in the Games under the OAR banner in Pyeonchang. It is not clear if the IOC will ban ElistRatov from competing at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, where he won a gold medal in the men's short track speed skating event.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Hamas agrees to release 13 Israeli hostages in exchange of Palestinian prisoners. Later on Friday, 13 hostages held in Gaza will be freed, followed by an undefined number of prisoners from Israeli jails. Over the four days, at least 50 hostages are expected to be released, leaving an estimated 190 in the hands of Palestinian militant groups. For Gaza's two million-plus residents, the deal spells a respite from weeks of sustained Israeli bombardment. "The living here are the ones who are dead," a Gazan whose son Udai was killed in a recent air strike tells AFP. to begin at 7:00 am (0500 GMT) The armed wing of Hamas confirmed cessation of hostilities under the deal that is also intended to provide aid to Gazans struggling with shortages of food, water and fuel. It said Palestinian prisoners would be released for each one of hostages released from three Israeli jails in each of the occupied West Bank, then taken to the military camp on buses, an Israeli official said.

text: Orhan Pamuk opened the third Eventi Letterari Monte Verità with a reading from his book The Museum of Innocence. This year's festival deals with the theme of "Utopia and Memory," and in a relaxed talk with artistic director Joachim Sartorius, Pamuk allowed the audience an insight into his thinking and his way of working. The festival continues through the weekend and will feature readings by bestselling Italian author Paolo Giordano, award winning German writer Terézia Mora, legendary Swiss writer Thomas Hürlimann and Belgian writer, director, photographer and artist Jean-Philippe Toussaint. It comes to an end on Sunday with a concert by Swiss experimental musician Nik Bärtsch and his band Ronin, who will also speak about the complex interactions of rememberance and music as heterotopia, a paradoxical essence that holds coherent structure and unleashes moments in itself. But ultimately, the most important effect of EventiLetterari, the wondrous concept this meet-up of extraordinary minds will have created, is a new foundation on which to build more beautiful, artistic memories, with a world of chaos and tragedy surrounding us, that's a fresh breath of great breath of optimistic news for this optimistic writer presently outnumbered by pessimists. The event is open to the public and runs until Sunday at the Bauhaus Teatro San Materno in Ascona, Switzerland. For more information, visit eventiletterari.com.

Mark Ruffalo invariably tugs at our hearts; however I found him far too ordinary and verbally bumble-some to believe he grew up with mammon of once impressive proportions and he actively fenced for sport. I will never forget DeVito’s performance and everyone who sees this play undoubtedly will feel the same way. I never once noticed that the play was two and a half hours long with a 15 min intermission. I was completely absorbed in the drama. I have always thought I would have loved to be in the theater when Lee J. Cobb played Willy Loman in Death of a Salesman, but I wasn’t alive then, thank- goodness I am for Danny DeVino. I caught a glimpse of greatness. The Price is a fantastic play with an outstanding cast, go see The Price at the American Airlines Theatre. You will experience an impeccable night of poignantly told storytelling that takes place in the family attic of a once great Brownstone home which is about to be demolished. text: The Sierra Club filed a Freedom of Information Act request for environmental data held by the Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Energy. Researchers fear that the incoming administration could wipe out important information on a broad range of environmental factors. Fears about data purges were sparked when Trump’s transition team reached out to the U.S. Energy Department in December demanding the names of employees and contract experts working on environmental and climate change issues. Under President George W. Bush, the EPA moved to shut down some of its research libraries, reducing access to important information. The administration was also accused by the Union of Concerned Scientists of suppressing or distorting research by government scientists or contractors at the Fish and Wildlife Service. Trump has called climate change a “hoax” by the Chinese to “make U.s. manufacturing non-competitive.” Incoming chief of staff Reince Priebus more recently said his boss believes it”s a ‘bunch of bunk.’ While the Sierra Club presses its request for data, other organized efforts are continuing to save what can be preserved from government databases and post the information on independent websites. Other efforts include Guerrilla Archiving and Climate Mirror to save environmental information, and the End of Term Web Archive, which attempts to save as many records as possible from outgoing presidential administrations. text: astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson tweeted the advice on Earth Day. Climate scientist Gavin Schmidt suggested a better slogan: "Save our Earth" "Preserve the Relatively Stable Biosphere in Which Human Civilization Developed" doesn't quite have the same ring to it, but that’s a start, he said. "Save the Planet" has a better ring than the reality, according to science communications guru Aaron Huertas, who suggested the slogan on Twitter. "Planet Earth survives massive asteroid strikes -- it'll survive anything we throw at it. But Life on Earth will not," Tyson said in a tweet. " save our Earth," he added, "with the current coastlines, biosphere, atmospheric composition and inhabitants. @aaronhuertas @carolynporco @AdamFrank4 https://t.co/PyHhMU3HXt" 'Save the planet' is a good slogan, Schmidt said on Twitter, but 'save our Earth' would be a better one. 'Save our planet,' he said, 'is what we need to do to preserve our civilization. But that's a start.' "Save Earth" is a bad slogan, but a good one, Schmidt added. ' save our planet, not our civilization,' he added. "save our planet," he tweeted, "is the best way to save our civilization." 'Save Earth' is the best slogan, Gavin Schmidt said, and it's better than 'save the biosphere'

"Every time I’ve tried to predict what’s on the Show, I”ve always been wrong,” Grob Douglas said of the show’S unexpected plot twists, including the three-year jump from season one to season two of the current season of “Jane.’’ The actress also stars as Petra”s twin sister, Anezka, in the second season of the series. She said she based her character off her cat. "She really started the show at her most desperate point, as they seem as they may seem," Grob Glas said. "Anezko is the most crazy, crazy character, but she's also the most relatable, and I love that about her," the actress said of her co-star. “I think the most important thing is that she really really really wants to be a good person, and that she can be,’ she said. ‘I think that about everything. I never thought about it, but as an actor I depend so much on my costars, and when you’re doing scenes with nobody to play off, you have to come so well-prepared and prepared.”

text: The National Weather Service will no longer use all caps. The change will go into effect on May 11. The agency began using all caps in 1849, when teleprinters were still able to only use upper case characters. The NWS will still release some all caps messages during "extremely dangerous situations" and during forecasts with "international implications," the agency said in a statement. But light rain on Thursday will cease to be apocalyptically emphasized "LIGHT RAIN ON THURSDAY" and will be replaced with "LOW RAIN" and "DOUBLE DIPLOMATIC DOUBLE" instead of "LOUD RAIN," the NWS said in the statement. It's not clear if the change will be adopted by the public, which has been vocal about its use of all caps since the 1990s, or if the agency will be able to use mixed-case characters in the future. The weather service is based in Washington, D.C., but has offices in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. It is the nation's oldest weather forecasting agency, going back to 1849. It has been in existence since the U.S. Bureau of Meteorology was formed in 1847. It was the first weather agency to use the term "watches" in the 1800s, when weather reports were sent by "the wire" over teleprinter. It began using the name "National Weather Service" in 1848.
label: SAFE

text: The 2013 Atlantic hurricane season, which forecasters had predicted would be more active than normal, has turned out to be something of a dud so far. As the season heads into the historic peak for activity, it may even enter the record books as marking the quietest start to any Atlantic season in decades. "It certainly looks like pretty much of a forecast bust," said Jeff Masters, a hurricane expert. The jury is still out on what exactly has put such a damper this year over the Atlantic basin and the Caribbean, where tens of millions of people live in hurricane danger zones. Tuesday marks the statistical "peak day" of the season, and researchers say significant amounts of dry air and wind shear have helped keep a lid on hurricane formation. The El Nino weather phenomenon, which is part of the mix of unstable ingredients that can affect hurricane formation, is also not a factor this year, making the lack of storm activity harder to explain. But whatever happens in the coming days, Dennis Feltgen cautioned it was still too early to write off 2013 as a when tropical weather was unpredictable. "We are at the mid-point of the six-month hurricane season," he said, "and it is a mistake to believe that the second half would resemble the first half" The first hurricane in 2001, only formed on Sept. 9, and that season ended with 15 named storms, including four of which became major hurricanes, he said. An average season has six hurricanes, but this year has seven.

text: Researchers at Oxford University have used modern scientific technology to test a religious relic believed to belong to St. Nicholas. They used radiocarbon dating to investigate a pelvic bone fragment. The tests showed that the bone fragment dates to the fourth century, the period when some historians believe the saint died. Christian religious relics are physical objects that have an association with a saint or with Jesus Christ. In the Catholic tradition, relics are believed to be vehicles through which God brings healing and works miracles. The bone that the Oxford researchers analyzed came from Lyon in France, and is now owned by the Rev. Dennis O’Neill, a Catholic priest in the Chicago area who collects Christian relics. The researchers are now seeking to study the relics held in Bari, Italy, to see if the bone can be linked to that skeletal material and DNA. They’re hoping to use palaeogenomics and stable isotope analysis to figure out the deceased’s gender, age at time of death, and the geographic area in which the person lived. The bones are still buried in a crypt at the Basilica San Nicola in Bar i. Other parts are at the Chiesa di San Nicolo al Lido in Venice, Italy and at a church in the city of Bari called the San Nicola dei San Nicola. The relics are often kept in churches and “venerated” by the faithful, who come to touch, kiss, or pray next to these sacred objects. This suggested both fragments could potentially belong to the same person.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Four skeletons and gold artifacts were recently discovered inside the site of a former shop located near Pompeii's Herculaneum gate. Inside the store, archaeologists found a gold pendant necklace, three gold coins and an oven used to make bronze objects. In another area, they uncovered a limestone tomb, dating to the fourth century B.C., which contains a body of a man. Looters previously tunneled into the store and in their search of treasure pushed the victims’ bodies against a wall. When Mount Vesuvius erupted in 79 A.D., those who were not able to escape were buried in tons of ash. In many cases, this casing preserved them until their discovery hundreds of years later. A third of the ancient city remains buried beneath volcanic debris. The bones’ disarrayed state is far different from the usual Pompeii excavations. It is believed that the victims, including an adolescent girl, are believed to have sought refuge inside the store before they were overtaken by the volcano. The excavation was carried out in collaboration with the Ecole Francaise in Rome the Centre Jean Berard and the Archaeological Superintendency of Pompeii. The site is located about 18 miles south of Naples and is on the outskirts of the historic city. The excavations at the shop, as well as a second in the area, started in May and are expected to be completed by the end of the year, according to the archaeological superintendency’s website.

text: Kevin Spacey has been announced as the host of the 71st Annual Tony Awards. The TV, film, and theater actor is a veteran of award shows. In 1991, he won a Tony for his performance in Neil Simon’s “Lost in Yonkers.” Spacey currently stars in the hit Netflix series “House of Cards’ as Frank Underwood, a scheming Southern Democrat with an unquenchable thirst for power. The Tony Awards can be viewed as a relatively niche award show, honoring performances and productions many outside of the New York metropolitan area haven’t had the opportunity to witness. Its viewership is typically smaller: In February, the unexpectedly eventful Oscars broadcast garnered 32.9 million viewers, while the 2016 Tony Awards tallied 8.7 million viewers. Even that modest award-show viewership may prove to be an outlier for the Broadway awards, which have garnered around 7 million viewers in previous years. The 2016 awards, hosted by late-night host James Corden, saw a 35 percent increase in viewership that many attributed to the national obsession with Lin-Manuel Miranda's “Hamilton” Now that the year of ‘Hamilton’ has passed, producers fear that the audiences will leave, according to ABC. Can CBS hope to retain those gains in audience by leading with A-list host Kevin Spacey? That remains to be seen, and we’re willing to wait for it. (Sorry, "Hamilton" fans.)
label: UNSAFE

text: Last month smashed through the previous October temperature record, from 2019. Globally, the average surface air temperature in October was 1.7 degrees Celsius warmer than the same month in 1850-1900. The heat is a result of continued greenhouse gas emissions from human activity, combined with the emergence this year of the El Nino weather pattern. "We must not let the devastating floods, wildfires, storms, and heatwaves seen this year become the new normal," said Piers Forster, climate scientist at University of Leeds, in a letter to the EU's Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) The previous record was 2016 - anotherEl Nino year - according to C3S' dataset, which goes back to 1940. The only other time before October a month breached the temperature record by such a large margin was in September 2023, the EU said in a statement. "September really, really surprised us. So after last month, it's hard to determine whether we're in a new climate state," Burgess said.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Royal Mail has been fined £5.6m for failing to meet delivery targets. Ofcom said the postal service had breached its obligations by missing targets. Royal Mail said it was "very disappointed" with its performance last year. It was hit last year by a long-running row over pay and conditions. The dispute was only settled in July this year, after 18 days of strike action. The fine included a 30% reduction after Royal Mail admitted liability and agreed to settle the case. The money will be paid to the Treasury within two months. Do you run a business or have you personally been affected by Royal Mail delivery delays? Share your experiences by emailing haveyoursay@bbc.co.uk.
