text: Nine major Asian economies must increase the share of electricity they get from renewable energy from the current 6% to at least 50% by 2030. Nearly a third of that renewable energy should come from wind and solar power. A fifth would be hydropower and other clean sources and the remainder, fossil fuels. A global temperature increase of 1.5C (2.7F) since pre-industrial times is considered a critical climate threshold beyond which risks of catastrophes rise. The need for urgent action was echoed by U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, who called for a “climate ambition supernova” in a speech on Tuesday. Asian nations are united in their heavy reliance on fossil fuels and national plans are not aligned with ambitious climate pledges announced by their governments, a report says. The study reviewed energy plans of Japan, South Korea, Vietnam, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Taiwan. It did not include China, the world's biggest emitter of carbon, or India, another major contributor.

text: The FCC has fined Dish Network $150,000 for not properly deorbiting its satellite. The company admitted it was liable for not shifting its EchoStar-7 to a safer spot. Dish had told the FCC it had a plan for dealing with the direct broadcast satellite way back in 2012. The issue of how to deal with all the trash in space is an ongoing and complex one. But this is the first time the FCC has fine a company for this kind of action. The FCC has strong enforcement authority and capability to enforce its vitally important space debris rules, said FCC enforcement bureau chief Loyaan A. Egal in a press release. "This is a breakthrough settlement, making very clear the FCC have strong enforcement power," Egal said in a statement. It's unclear if Dish will comply with the fine, but the company has said it will implement a compliance plan in the coming months. The fine is the FCC's first for space junk, but it's a step in the right direction.
label: SAFE

text: "Repro Rights Zine" aims to provide information and empowerment in this alarming time. The first edition of the zine, published shortly before Trump’s inauguration, is available for free download. The zine-masters enlisted artists Petra Collins, Meriem Bennani, Lola Ogbara, Ser Serpas, Alia Penner, Aidan Koch and Raina Hamner to create limited edition posters to stick inside the zines. These special artist editions sell for $20 each, with all proceeds going to the Center for Reproductive Rights. We reached out to contributing artist Ogb Lara to learn more about the project and the artists who contributed to the second edition, which is now available on the Repro Rights zine website. For more information, visit Repro rights zine.org. The second edition is available now on the website and can be downloaded for free for a limited time at www.reprorightszine.com. The third edition will be released in the coming weeks and will be available for download on the site and on Facebook and Twitter. The fourth edition is expected to be released next month and will include information on how to get an IUD, reproductive rights for trans and gender-nonconforming individuals, who to call to help protect the Affordable Care Act, and where to find the specifics of reproductive rights state-by-state. It will also feature a selection of quality feminist art from the artists involved in the project, as well as a photo essay.

text: Sean O'Casey's The Shadow of a Gunman is set during the War of Independence in 1920 Dublin. Kevin Rodden stars as Seumas a man of "contradiction" that offers an appealing psychology to the actor. The show will run from April 9-25 at The Skybox at The Adrienne, 20th & Sansom Streets in Philadelphia. Performances are Wednesdays through Saturdays at 7pm and Sundays at 2 p.m.. Tickets are $25, general admission; $20 for seniors; and $15 for students."I'm not interested in answers for a character, but rather in questions. What does this person want and how does he go about getting it? Is that productive? What are my points of intersection?" said Peggy Mecham co-director of the play. "I think this is an opportunity to see a play that's near its 100th anniversary that not only reflects its time but also explores human nature with wonderfully diverse characters," said Mecham. "In 90 minutes, few plays can pack such a punch, and I'm really proud of our production's ability to balance all these moving parts without holding the audiences hand," said Roddan. The Irish Heritage Theater is Philadelphia's only professional company dedicated to preserving and acquainting new audiences with poetry and power of classic Irish theater. The company has produced Brian Friel's Philadelphia, Here I Come and A Night with Lady G, among other works by Irish playwrights.
label: SAFE

text: Stamps feature lyrics from Christmas carols including Silent Night and Away in a Manger. They are also the first Christmas stamps to feature King Charles's silhouette. The tradition of Christmas-themed stamps goes back to December 1966. They've been made with an art technique called woodblock printing. It involves using carved wooden blocks to print ink or paint onto paper. They also feature a barcode that you can use on an app to view a special Christmas message from Shaun the Sheep. The stamps show lots of different scenes from the Christian story about the birth of Jesus. This includes pictures of Mary, an angel singing, and baby Jesus in a stable. Each stamp has its own line from a famous Christmas carol. The UK's Postmaster General created an art competition for kids to enter, with the hope of having their art featured on a stamp. They used to be in charge of the Royal Mail and telegraphs. They were machines that people used to use to send messages over long distances using electric signals.
label: SAFE

text: Denmark is supporting the Ukrainians with a EURO 40.2 million reconstruction package. The package will provide 20 mobile heating boilers for the city of Mykolaiv. The effort is part of the second reconstruction package from Denmark to Ukraine since the launch of the Ukraine Fund in the spring of 2023. "I am pleased that Denmark can help make a difference for a people fighting a tough battle for their freedom," says Minister for Development Cooperation and Global Climate Policy, Dan JĂ¸rgensen. In addition to support for heating in Ukraine, the EURO40.2million will go to: The Ukraine Fund, a fund that will provide financial assistance to Ukrainian citizens affected by the conflict. The fund will also provide support for the reconstruction efforts in the country, including with a continued focus on Mykololaiv Region and City. In the coming months, energy supply will be among the most important areas of action. The consequences of the war are grave for many Ukrainians.

text: Eva Schlegel is best known for her photographic portraits that focus in front or behind her subjects, but never on the subjects themselves. Her work is being shown in an exhibition at Park Hyatt Vienna. In 2011, she was the Commissioner for the Austrian Pavilion at the 54th Venice Biennale. She has been the subject of numerous solo exhibitions, including a March 2015 show at Galerie Krinzinger in Vienna, as well as a 2014 show at Gallery Wendi Norris in San Francisco. In "o.T . 031″ (2013) and "o .T . 018″ (2001), viewers are given a glimpse at one of Schlegal's best-known series. Each depicting a figure in front of a window, holding back a curtain, the color lambdaprints are characteristically blurry. The effect of looking at the compositions feels as though one has looked directly at the light from the windows, and then closed their eyes, leaving the imprint of the forms depicted on their eyelids. Much like the photographs of human forms, text is transformed into something recognizable but unreadable -- tricking the brain, at first, to try to interpret them as personal before discovering that they merely representations of form. Another show by the artist entitled "Characters and Figures" is also on view at Galeries KrinZinger through April 4, 2015. The exhibition is a glimpse of the artist's oeuvre for those who might not know her work.
label: SAFE

It aims to achieve $ 5 million in ARR by November 2025, chief financial officer Brajesh Bhanj Deo said in a statement. text: The global aviation sector is responsible for a whopping six-percent of all industrial climate emissions. If the aviation sector were a country, they would be the seventh largest climate polluter in the world. The issue is so tricky that the UN agency ICAO has yet to develop an agreeable solution. Some airlines, namely major US carriers like United Airlines, have been throwing big lobbying dollars around that have effectively delayed any major action so far. It is a complicated piece of international policy that will likely start to gain attention as other sectors begin to deal with, and take responsibility for, their contributions to global climate change. The International Civil Aviation Organization is expected to make a recommendation on how to regulate emissions from the aviationsector at a major summit in Montreal, Canada in late September. Rumor is that I CAO will likely punt off a decision once again, to be made at some much later date. The U.S. coal industry is facing imminent regulation of their carbon emissions, like the Keystone XL pipeline and Canada's tar sands, but this sleeper issue of global airplane emissions continues to fly low. It's time to get serious about climate change, says John Defterios, the director of the Center for International Policy Studies at the University of California, Los Angeles. The time to act is now, says Defterio, and it's time for the U.N. to do more than just talk about the issue of climate change; it is time to do something about it, he says.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Huffington Post asked 10 science-fiction, speculative fiction, urban fantasy and dystopian authors to answer a single question: What will the next 10 years bring? Will drones become omnipresent? Will the already dissipating line between our gadgets and ourselves fade further? Or, will things remain, more or less, the same? Read what Edan Lepucki, Jo Walton and others had to say: David Walton author of Superposition: "The earliest adopter of new technology might just be your grandmother" Elizabeth Bear author of Karen Memory: "I think one of the biggest trends of the next decade -- and beyond -- is also one of our greatest hopes for a post-scarcity economy" Robert Charles Wilson, author of The Affinities: "Change is inevitable. It devours everything familiar and builds a strange new structures. It’s the heart of the genre. It's the same river, we don’t even have to step on it twice anymore. We can start asking what might be new and different in the next ten years?" The Huffington Post asks the authors what they think the future will hold for writers and other creative types, and gets a wide range of answers. For more, go to CNN.com/soulmatestories and follow us on Twitter @CNNOpinion and @CoryDoctorow on Facebook. The latest episode of "iReport" airs tonight at 10 p.m. ET on HLN and Sunday at 9 p.M. ET.

text: Study: Restoring global forests could sequester 22 times as much carbon as the world emits in a year. Reaching the world's full potential for restoration would draw out an estimated 226 gigatonnes of excess carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. This is roughly one-third the amount added to the atmosphere since the industrial revolution. Of the total carbon sequestration potential, only 39% would come from reforesting denuded areas, the study says. Most would come simply from protecting forests that are still standing and allowing degraded woodlands to recover, according to the study. The paper offers a major update to a 2019 paper that sparked fierce debate in the scientific community, it says. the idea of earning an offset through simply planting trees "is now categorically against what the science says," Thomas Crowther of Switzerland's Federal Institute of Technology Zurich says. The study's authors specify that restoration must be done a certain way to be effective. They argue that forests must be diverse, rather than mass plantings of a single species.
label: SAFE

text: California-based semiconductor company Advanced Micro Devices ( AMD ) India and the Indian Institute of Science (IISc ), Bengaluru, have set up a joint initiative to advance High Performance Computing (HPC) and AI research in the country. The research intellectual property (IP) will be jointly owned by the parties. AMD has also set up an India Development Centre (IDC) under the leadership of senior fellow Prakash Raghavendra to drive research projects in India. “HPC & AI are fundamentally redefining the world of technology and AMD is at the centre with our portfolio of computing products,” Jaya Jagadish, country head and senior vice president, AMD India said.

text: AG Drive Soundtrack is a compilation of energy-driven, electronic dance music (EDM) songs that lean toward the genre's trance, psytrance and dupstep sounds. Of the album's 14 songs, Pulkkinen's "Drive" mix serves as the soundtrack's lead single and offers a pulsating rhythm with powerful beats that drive the heart of the game and could easily motivate the listener to dance. The Domestic Machine Movement's "Delta Course" track offers an old-school video game sound with robotic vocals. Tommy Baynen's active trance track "Rock That" is about as radio-play-worthy as any EDM track can get. The latter is one that would no doubt work party-goers up during the summer. Overall, the album is infused with the right combination of ingredients to entice both video game fanatics and electronic music fans, whether they're one-in-the-same or not. Be advised, after listening to this album, a fan of one, may easily become a follower of the other — the end result of a trance-like pull one can only assume Pulkkinsen may have intended. To learn more about the album and other AriTunes Records' music, visit: www.aritunesrecords.com/AG-Drive-Soundtrack-Album-2-1-2. label: SAFE

text: The March for Science has been critiqued as too elitist, too white, and unwilling to own up to the ways science has been misused as a tool of white supremacy throughout history. Some groups, including many of the large science associations involved in the march, have spoken of the effort as non-political. Scientists get involved to help set the record straight, offer their expertise, and fight for the truth, when necessary. It’s not scientists who make science political, it's politicians. The fossil fuel industry continues to spend millions every year on climate denial front groups, and millions more lobbying against renewable energy, environmental protections, or science based policy of any sort. All that spending has bought Big Oil plenty of friends on Capitol Hill. One of their favorite puppets has been Representative Lamar Smith of Texas, a climate denier who chairs none other than the House Committee for Science, Space and Technology. The Scopes Monkey Trial-like case has helped convince more scientists to speak out, especially about the lies they see being spread by the fossilfuel industry and their allies in Washington. More scientists are taking to the streets to push back on their attacks on their field and to become influential voices pushing back on attacks on science. The march is scheduled to take place in Washington, D.C. and at over 500 satellite marches all around the world on March 8 and 9, with the goal of raising awareness about climate change and the role of science in the 21st century.

It’s also us," Kohn writes. "We cannot let any injustice, no matter how small, slide within racist and misogynistic systems" "It is important to stand with him. Period. A black man beingblackballed for taking a political stance to save lives is 100 percent unacceptable," she says. "The NFL has LONG been a system on the ‘caveman’ side of the evolutionary scale, showing consistently it does not value NFL players’ lives or health," she adds. "Don’t get me wrong — NFL owners have done an injustice, unfortunately, that is completely consistent with history in regards to many black players who take brave social stances" "We have witnessed the NFL consistently allowing things over and over to get worse than this," she concludes. "It's time to draw the line and stand up for Kaepernick and his right to take the field again and take the heat for what he's been through and continue to go through" "I’m a Seahawks fan. text: IPCC provides a basis for science-based political decisions on climate change. But it does not make any direct recommendations for measures by states. The Paris Agreement has given nation states more leeway and left them more or less free to decide for themselves by how much they want to cut their emissions. If we want to avert the biggest dangers of climate change, we need to act very fast, says Bernd Siebenhüner, author of a new book on the IPCC and climate change in the 21st century. The IPCC report contains measures for climate protection, but only points out options. It does not give a breakdown of what would have to be done in Germany, for example, in order to meet the climate targets. Nor does the IPCC allocate an emissions budget to each individual country. It is therefore not allowed to give a detailed analysis of the measures that need to be taken by each of the actors in the key category of actors, which after all lead the global climate negotiations. This restricts its impact on national policy.
label: SENSITIVE

We don’t have to sit idly by while grid operators and utilities install grid-scale renewables and storage and work through transmission system upgrades. text: Bill Nye isn't sold on SpaceX CEO Elon Musk's plan to colonize Mars. "I’m open-minded but skeptical that anyone actually wants to live out his or her life on Mars,” he said. The mission would be part of a larger plan to establish a colony on the red planet, which could take years to reach and colonize, he said in a speech Tuesday. The plan was unveiled at a major astronautics conference in Guadalajara, Mexico, where Nye was on hand to see the plan in action. It's not clear whether NASA will send a manned mission to the red Planet in the 2030s, but the space agency has its own plan to send astronauts there sometime in 2030s. The company's plan is to build a fleet of vast spaceships and use them to ferry wave upon wave of humans to the Red Planet, Musk told the conference. text: Dani Dayan is chairman of Jerusalem's Yad Vashem memorial centre. He says the attack was fundamentally different from Nazi Germany's mass murder of six million Jews. The memorial centre has cancelled educational seminars and turned some spaces into classrooms for 400 students evacuated from southern Israel, says Dayan. "We removed the photos from the walls so as not to add trauma to trauma," he says.

text: More than 150 startups are chasing an ambitious goal: meat that doesn’t require raising and killing animals that is affordable and tastes and feels like the meat we eat now. text: Käthe Kollwitz knew profound personal suffering after her younger son Peter died in battle in Flanders in 1914. She recognized that she was expressing something greater than her own feelings and that her art could only function if it served an entire society. In the context of America’s recent Presidential election, it seems critical for artists to ask themselves about the role of empathy in their own work. Whether their work is political, personal or somewhere in-between, the element of empathy can allow an artist to “give voice to the sufferings of others,” as Käthe Kolwitz did so nobly in her works. The invention of empathy corresponds to many of the climactic shifts in the art, philosophy and psychology of fin-de-siècle Europe, and it changed the way artists thought about their work. The development of empathy as a social expectation and custom parallels the development of Expressionism: of inwardness as a gateway to emotional connection. That inwardness—so essential in the modern conception of a self-aware individual—is the hinge that connects to social awareness and the empathetic understanding of others. Empathy is, without doubt, a political force that plays a considerable role in attitudes towards social issues. In a recent article for Psychology Today, attorney and social advocate David Noise argues that empathy and “cousin” compassion are crucial elements in politics and policy, arguing that they “lead to an intelligent assessment of what is happening internally and around the world”
label: SENSITIVE

Festival-goers will pay a £75 as a deposit and the balance is due by the first week of April. The price of a ticket for 2024 is £355 (plus a £5 booking fee), up from £335 for 2023's event. In November, festival ticket and coach packages sold out in 25 minutes on 16 November.
label: SAFE

text: The Marcus National Blood Services Center in Ramla, near Tel Aviv, had been scheduled to open within days. The $135-million, 6-story, state-of-the-art facility is protected from rockets, missiles, chemical attacks and earthquakes. The former blood bank, which was built in the 1980s, was not able to handle the country's needs in times of war. In early October, the center received 5,000 units of blood in one day — five times more than usual, said its staff. and has processed more blood than has ever been held in Israel’s reserves, it said. and as Israeli troops advance deeper into the Gaza Strip, it is preparing for a potential surge of casualties that might need transfusions. The ideal blood donors are those with Type O, which can be given safely to anyone and can help people more quickly, experts say. and can give blood to the military to treat wounded soldiers on the battlefield, they say. "During war, blood is part of the resuscitation process and the idea is to have a stock," one doctor says.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Carla Cubit has organized exhibitions and performances around social justice themes for years. Her latest show, "Black Lives Matter Art Show," will take place Tuesday, Jan. 31, at The Living Gallery in Brooklyn. The show will feature a talk from Monica Octavia of the Museum of Impact, billed as the world's first social justice museum. Cubit will also open the stage to other poets and performers interested in participating in the evening’s events. The event is free for all attendees, but the artist will be selling handmade jewelry with messages like “Black lives matter” and “Not My President” for $1 each. Posters from the Stop Mass Incarceration Network will also be available at no cost. For many, the time to support local organizations advocating for racial justice and artistic expression is now. As Cubit put it, the show offers a chance for viewers “to see things other than pretty flowers and trees in the contemporary art world. Something that makes a statement.’“The political climate has changed but I’m still interested in the samesocial justice themes,” Cubit told The Huffington Post. “Open the discussion, get people aware of what's going on in the world around them. Wake people up to injustice,’ Cubit said of her goal for the show: “Get people to wake up.” The pop-up exhibition is free to attend and will be open to the public.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Spotify introduced a new hub for artist merchandise on Monday that recommends goods like T-shirts, vinyl records, and this brass Lana Del Rey lighter for moody girls. It is the latest effort from Spotify to integrate merch purchasing into the app, which has been a priority for artists who distribute on the streaming service. Spotify does not take a cut from sales, but the merch push does serve a business purpose. As of Monday morning, I am only able to access the hub through the link on the press release, as it does not show up on my app search page. The easiest way right now is to go to the merch tab on an artist’s individual page. A representative from Spotify said they were looking into the issue and would be happy to clarify. The company launched a partnership with Shopify in 2021 and has been making small updates ever since to facilitate shopping. Still, the purchasing does not happen directly in the app; users can browse goods but are then directed to artists’ individual merch stores.
label: SAFE

text: The Uttarakhand Uniform Civil Code report seems to be in perpetual 'soon to be launched' mode. text: Rupi Kaur, 22, is an Indian-Canadian student at the University of Waterloo. She posted a photo of a young woman on her period to Instagram. The post attracted three million views in less than a day. Instagram has since clarified its guidelines so photos like Kaur's presumably won't go missing. The incident dovetailed with the celeb-backed backlash against the site's censoring of breastfeeding photographs, making Kaur an accidental icon of a feminist movement. The Huffington Post chatted with the 22-year-old about overnight fame and what she really meant to say. She's gotten death threats, alongside interview requests from the world's biggest media organizations. She hopes to create a conversation without words and with imagery that would battle societal norms. She also hopes to show how context influences art consumption, like a Susan Sontag essay on the Mona Lisa and stamping on a stamp is a different thing than looking at it in person, she said. The first reaction was so splendid and then about twelve hours later, people from her hometown ganged up and started bashing it. The women were like, "I get it, but I hate my period," Kaur said. "In a few years we won't even need women anymore because we'll just breed babies in our labs." "You like this feminist moment? You're ugly and you're ugly," one woman said, "You're a feminist and you can't be ugly" Kaur: "I've been mulling over in my mind for the past year. My periods personally are so crazy and painful [They] eliminate my entire existence for a week"
label: SENSITIVE

text: Christopher Davis will miss the remainder of the season with an ankle sprain. The injury happened during practice when Christopher Davis landed awkwardly after attempting a tackle. Trainers and medical staff are developing a comprehensive rehabilitation plan. Christopher Davis released a statement thanking fans for their support and expressing determination to return stronger. Sports medicine experts say the the remainderof the season timeline is reasonable for this type of injury. The Panthers are currently 5-3 and have a bye week in the NFC Championship Game on Sunday. The game will be held at Lambeau Field in Tampa, Florida at 4:30 p.m. and 6:00 p.M. on Sunday, September 17. The Carolina Panthers are the No. 3 seed in the AFC. The Tampa Bay Buccaneers are the fourth seed. The New Orleans Saints are the seventh seed. The Saints are also the fourth-place team in their division. The Falcons are the sixth-place side in their NFC South, with a record of 6-4-1. The Redskins are the third-place squad in their AFC South, having won three games in a row and two of their last three games. The Seahawks are the fifth-placed team, having lost just one game in their last six games. They have won three of the last five games in the playoffs.

text: Astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson warns that science is eroding in the U.S. He says science deniers are creating a "recipe for the complete dismantling of our informed democracy" Tyson has been campaigning to “Make America Smart Again” since President Donald Trump won the election last year. Last month, he warned that the country would need more than an intelligence boost if Trump’s proposed budget cuts to key areas including science passed. He promises that his new video contains “what may be the most important words I have ever spoken,” which he posted to Facebook Wednesday. He praises science as an “exercise in finding what is true” that is based on peer-reviewed experimentation backed by other experiments and counter-experiments that gives birth to an ‘emergent truth’ “Recognize what science is, and allow it to be what it can and should be: In the service of civilization,’ he says. “It's in our hands.” Watch the powerful video in full above. The Earth Day March for Science will take place on Saturday in Washington, D.C., and other cities across the country, including New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and San Francisco, to protest against anti-science moves by the Trump administration and the Republican-led Congress. For more information on the Earth Day march, go to www.earthday.org/scientists- march-for-science.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The orangutans are located in the Camp Leakey research facility in Central Borneo. Through observation they have learned to help humans with chores like doing the laundry. Borean Orangutan are classified as endangered by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature. Habitat loss due to forest destruction is the primary cause of a significant population decline in recent decades. The DNA structure of orangUTans and humans differ by a remarkably small amount, so their willingness to learn and be challenged is not so surprising. The apes might just get in a boat and start rowing. Yes, they row boats. Although it might be imitation, it is still an incredible demonstration of teamwork. It is also a great example of how humans can help the orangutan in a variety of ways, from feeding to caring for their young to helping them with chores. It's a win-win situation for all of us, and it's a great lesson in how to live in the wild with the animals that we love and care for. The oranguans are untrained, but they are watching us and learning, just as much as we are watching them and learning. They are "simply free to do what the apes do," says one researcher, "and that is to row boats." It's also a lesson in teamwork, as the apes are able to learn from each other and help each other out in their daily lives. It also is a great demonstration of how we can work together to achieve our goals.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A diver who spotted something metallic not far from Sardinia's coast has led to the discovery of tens of thousands of ancient bronze coins. The coins dating from the first half of the fourth century were found in sea grass. Exactly how many coins have been retrieved hasn't been determined yet, as they are being sorted. Given the location and shape of the seabed, there could be remains of ship wreckage nearby, the ministry says. The find is “further evidence of the richness and importance of the archaeological heritage,” a Sardinian archaeology department official said in a statement. the coins were in an excellent and rare state of preservation,’ the ministry said. The few coins that were damaged still had legible inscriptions, it said, adding that the find is one of the most important coin discoveries in recent years. The ministry didn't say exactly when the first diver caught a glimpse of something metallic just off shore Sardinia, not near the town of Arzachena.
label: SAFE

text: Abraham Poincheval will live in a 12,000-kilogram limestone boulder for a week. The French artist will sit in a hole carved in the middle of the rock, his arms outstretched. It's all part of a performance piece titled “Pierre,” which translates to “stone” in English. He will chronicle the emotional and logistical details of his rocky experience in a journal, explaining in very literal terms what it feels like to be the heart of a stone ― and basically entombed alive. He's also spent eight days buried under a rock, a week on top of a 65-foot pole, and 20 days underground as a human mole in the past, all of which have been documented on YouTube. The artist is moving on to an even stranger artistic pursuit, titled ‘Egg,’ for which he will sit on a dozen eggs for between three and four weeks, with the hopes that they’ll hatch. It will begin March 29 and will continue for a period of 21-26 days at the Palais de Tokyo, Paris. and run from from Feb. 22 to March 1, 2015, according to the artist's website. It is unclear how the artist will react to the extreme conditions of his performance, though his prior performances suggest he'll be just fine. The museum has an emergency phone line in case of emergencies, though the artist’s previous work suggests he’d be fine.
label: SENSITIVE

text: ESG standards (Environment, Social and Governance) are metrics designed to guide responsible investing. The "S" in ESG has evolved into the financial innovation of social impact investing (SII) SII promoters cast themselves assaviors with the moral vision to solve worldwide suffering. But this does not always translate into promised results in the postcolonial Global South, writes Andrew Boulden. SII is worthUS$1 trillion with 92 percent of the investors based in the Global North and 59 percent of investments made in the global South. The SII process usually follows the neoliberal, accounting-based conventions of Global North capital markets, he writes. BouldEN: SII investors should reflect on and declare their invisible power and neoliberal privilege to create a space where issues of equality and power-sharing can be discussed with beneficiaries. It is possible to contribute to the "Witnessed Revolution" imagined over a decade ago by proposals during COP26, writes Bouldens. We have not many other options and time is of the essence, he says.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Gloria, by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins, opened June 15, 2015 and continues through July 18 at the Vineyard Theatre. The Vineyard's production of this exceptional play is itself exceptional. The whole thing works out magnificently, in my view. But you really must see for yourself. The cast of six are superb, each and every one. The staging by Evan Cabnet (of A Kid Like Jake and The Dream of the Burning Boy) is impeccable. There is also a keenly helpful set from Takeshi Kata, along with intelligent sound design from Matt Tierney (of Machinal) But the play's the thing, especially in this case. The author has come up with a provocative theme, filled it with dazzling language, and managed to build it into something likely to resonate in your mind long after you climb the stairs of the vineyard. The play is directed by Michael Crane and stars Catherine Combs, Jennifer Kim, Ryan Spahn, Michael Crane, Jeanine Serralles, Kyle Beltran, and Jennifer Kim. The show is directed and written by Brendan Jacobs- Jenkins, who also wrote An Octoroon, which opened in April 2014 at the Soho Rep and moved to Theater for a New Audience in Brooklyn. The production is being staged by Evan cabnet, who is also the director of A Kid like Jake and the Dream of The Burning Boy. Theatre for a new Audience is a nonprofit organization based in New York City.
label: UNSAFE

text: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has given the nod to a USD 170 million loan aimed at modernizing water supply services in Kochi. The move is expected to play a pivotal role in elevating urban living standards, ensuring clean water access, and bolstering climate resilience. ADB's intervention comes against the backdrop of Kerala experiencing severe dry spells and droughts, notably in 2016, which severely impacted water availability. The project aims to mitigate these challenges and enhance access to quality water, a vital element of inclusive development, according to ADB. The ambitious project involves the rehabilitation and upgrade of five existing water treatment plants with a cumulative production capacity of 325 million litres per day (MLD) A new plant with a capacity of 190 MLD will be constructed. Around 700 kilometres of pipes will be replaced, accompanied by the introduction of a real-time monitoring system. Approximately 146,000 water meters will be upgraded to high-quality and reliable meters. In a bid to promote female employment in the construction, operation and maintenance of water supply systems, the project places a special focus on training initiatives.
label: SAFE

text: Weinstein Books has been shut down by Hachette Book Group, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The Weinstein Books staff will be absorbed into Hacchette Books. The imprint published a range of fiction and nonfiction, often by media figures and celebrities. MSNBC host Mika Brzezinski signed a three-book contract with Weinstein Books earlier this year, but said she could not move forward with the books until Harvey Weinstein was no longer associated with the company. The comedian Iliza Shlesinger defended her decision to publish with the imprint, saying she couldn’t “ vilify a company of women who have been supportive of me.’’ The Weinstein Company fired Harvey Weinstein on Oct. 8 after numerous allegations of sexual harassment and assault against the former film producer. He has denied all of the allegations against him, saying he has a “very good” relationship with his accusers and that he’s “looking forward” to working with them again. The company has not commented on the decision to shut down the Weinstein Books imprint, which was a joint venture between the Weinstein Company and the Hacchete imprint Perseus Books. It is unclear what will happen to the books published by the Weinstein imprint under the new Hacachete imprint. The new books will also be published under the Perseus imprint, as well as by the other Hacatchete imprints, the Hollywood Reporter reports. The publisher has yet to comment.

text: The Chinese and Pakistani navies are holding week-long drills in the Arabian Sea during which the two all-weather allies will also conduct joint maritime patrols for the first time. With the theme of "joint response to maritime security threats", the exercise will include formation movement, VBSS (visit, board, search and seizure) and anti-submarine operations. "This is the third time for China and Pakistan to hold such an exercise, aiming to consolidate the all- weather strategic partnership and traditional friendship between the two countries," a Chinese military spokesperson said. The Indian units of Apple, Google and Amazon are being investigated by the U.S. tax authorities over possible non-payment of tax. Razorpay plans to move its parent firm to India through a cross-country merger that may entail a tax payment of $250-300 million in the US, where it is currently domiciled, according to multiple people aware of discussions. India has become the largest real estate investors in the Dubai property market, playing a pivotal role in shaping the city's real estate market.

text: Nicolás Almagro was forced to quit the French Open due to a knee injury. His opponent, Juan Martín del Potro, helped him off the court and comforted him. Del Potro was due to face Britain's Andy Murray in the third round on Saturday. The injury occurred during the second set of their match on Thursday. Earlier this month, the Spanish player had to stop playing against compatriot Rafael Nadal due to the same knee injury, causing him to forfeit the Italian Open. He almost skipped the tournament due to back and shoulder issues, according to the Telegraph. The pair were due to play each other in the quarterfinals on Saturday, before the injury occurred. The match ended in a tiebreak, with del Poto winning the match 6-4, 6-2. The two players will now face each other on Saturday in the fourth round. The winner of the match will face Andy Murray or Novak Djokovic in the next round, which will be played on Sunday. The French Open will be held at the Roland Garros stadium in Paris for the first time since 2005. The tournament runs through Sunday. It is the first grand slam of the year. The final grand slam to be held in France. The event is expected to draw more than 100,000 spectators. It will also be the first major tennis tournament to be played in Paris since 2002, when it was held in Paris. The last time it was played there was the US Open in 2002.
label: SAFE

text: "Portals" are real art projects that connect strangers around the world. The first portal connected citizens of New York City with strangers in Tehran. Now the Portals team is hoping to recreate the boundary-breaking experience in Washington D.C. and Havana, Cuba. The project, which is currently gaining a following on Kickstarter, hopes to raise $60,000 by March 24 to make the dream real. The rewards for donating range from Portal postcards to the opportunity to reserve dance classes, karaoke sessions or the activity of your choice in a future Portal."People aren't talking to each other. Hatred based on religious intolerance, xenophobia, sexuality-based bigotry and so much more rage on," Shared_Studio says on their Kickstarter page. If we do not meaningfully engage with people from different walks of life, our capacity for empathy weakens and divisions of class, race, and identity deepen, they say. "Portals," as they're called, are not figments of your imagination, but rather very real art Projects, realized by Amar C. Bakshi and a team of interdisciplinary artists called Shared_Studios. They're already over half way to their goal of $100,000, which would make the project a reality by the end of the month. They hope to raise the rest of the money through donations, which can be made on their website or via the Kickstarter page, as well as through book sales, concerts, and other activities.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Cohen Media Grouphas acquired worldwide rights toMerchant Ivory. The film directed byStephen Soucymakes it world premiere on Saturday at DOC NYC. It features interviews with major stars of Merchant Ivory productions, including Emma Thompson, Vanessa Redgrave, Helena Bonham Carter, and Hugh Grant. Ivory, who turned 95 in June, and Charles S. Cohen, CMG Chairman and CEO, serve as executive producers. Many of Ivory’s films with Merchant have been restored and rereleased by Cohen Media Group. The company plans a 2024 North American theatrical release for the film. It is the first comprehensive feature documentary to lend new and compelling perspectives on the partnership, both professional and personal, of director James Ivory, producer Ismail Merchant and their primary associates. With six Oscar winners among the notable artists participating, these close and often long-term collaborators intimately detail the transformational cinematic creativity and personal and professional drama of the wandering company that left an indelible impact on film culture.”
label: SAFE

text: The NCAA Division 1 Infractions Appeals Committee announced its final decision on Tuesday after an unsuccessful appeal by the school. The punishment follows a 2015 investigation that found a basketball team staffer paid prostitutes to have sex with the school’s athletes and recruits and also had striptease dancers perform for them. The NCAA said that the basketball team's former staff member knew that his actions violated NCAA bylaws. The athletes knew their behavior violated the rules, or should have known, making them ineligible for the competition, the NCAA said. The school must also repay revenue earned from appearances in the 2012, 2013, 2014 and 2015 basketball tournaments, amounting to about $600,000. Louisville is one of the schools the FBI is investigating for “pay for play” deals with basketball recruits. The university's interim president Greg Postel, said at an afternoon press conference that he agrees the conduct that led to the penalties was wrong but that he disagrees with the committee's ruling. “The pain this infraction has created for our fans and for our players who were not involved in the events in question is perhaps the most regretful result of this determination,” Postel said at a press conference on Tuesday. The ruling orders the school to vacate all of its wins during the academic years between 2011 and 2015, which included two Final Four appearances. Individual records of student-athletes will also be vacated. It's the first time in the NCAA's modern history that a Division I men's basketball national championship has been stripped from a school.
label: UNSAFE

text: Tammy Faye, the Olivier-nominatedElton John–Jake Shears–James Grahammusical about ’80s-era televangelist Tammy Faye Bakker, will premiere on Broadwayduring the 2024-25 Season. The musical will be staged at an as-yet-unannounced Nederlander Theatre. Venue, production dates and casting will be announced at a later date. Tammy Fayefeatures music by John, lyrics by Scissor Sisters’ Shears and book byInkplaywright Graham. Rupert Goold, who directed Graham’sInk, will direct Tammy FayE, and Lynne Page will choreograph. The official synopsis: “From a studio in South Carolina, Tammy Fayer and Jim Bakker revolutionized religion. Preaching to millions 24 hours a day, Tammy just wants to put the fun back into faith.” Tammy Fayehad its world premiere at London’S Almeida Theatre in Fall 2022.
label: SAFE

text: Dutch voters cast their ballots on Wednesday in a nail-biting election. At least three parties including the far right could hope for the top spot. No one party is on track to take more than 20% of the vote. Immigration was the issue that triggered the collapse of Mark Rutte's last cabinet in July. The party that wins the most seats traditionally takes the lead in negotiations and provides the prime minister but even that is not guaranteed under the Dutch system. The Netherlands is a founding member of the EU, and Rutte is a key operator in EU summits, as parties on the right have suggested seeking exemptions from the bloc's rules on agriculture and immigration. The election is expected to last until 9 p.m. (2000 GMT), when national broadcaster NOS publishes its first exit poll. It will be the country's first new prime minister in over a decade after Rutte resigned in July as his fourth coalition governmentcollapsed, ending a 13-year tenure in the post.
label: SENSITIVE

text: SpaceX has launched its first-ever recycled cargo ship to the International Space Station. A Falcon 9 rocket launched the recycled Dragon capsule at 5:07 p.m. local time Saturday from the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Florida. Shortly after the first-stage booster launched the Dragon into orbit, it fell away from the capsule, flipped around, fired its engines and landed safely at the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. The Dragon made its first trip to space in 2014, delivering food and supplies to the ISS, and was refurbished after landing in the Pacific Ocean intact. Saturday’s refurbished capsule will deliver 6,000 pounds of supplies, including mice and flies to be used for research, a roll-up solar panel, food and a neutron star detector, according to NBC News. The reused Dragon is expected to reach the orbiting lab on Monday. It will be the first returning craft since NASA's now-retired shuttles. The booster launched Saturday likely will be used again, as SpaceX hopes to lower the cost of flights to space with reused rockets and capsules. It was the first recycled orbital rocket, a Falcon 9, to be launched two months ago and successfully landed it on an ocean platform named Of Course I Still Love You. The launch had been delayed twice due to thunderstorms, with the second delay caused by the launch being delayed by more than an hour because of the weather. It is the first time a recycled rocket has been used for space travel.
label: SAFE

text: Sergei Shchukin was a successful late 19th-century Russian businessman in the textile industry. Starting in 1897 during a visit to Paris, he began collecting paintings from the masters of Impressionism. Monet's Le Déjeuner sur l'Herbe, Picasso's La Buveuse d'Absinthe, Matisse's L'Atelier Rose, are just a few of the masterpieces that made it to the museum in Paris. Braque, Renoir, Degas, Van Gogh, Cézanne, Pissarro, are among the other 50 masters represented by the collection. The art was labeled "bourgeois and cosmopolitan" by purgist dictator Joseph Stalin, who was in office from April 1922 to October 1952 and considered the art collection to be too decadent to be shown to the public. "For me, it's a big event," LVMH Chairman Bernard Arnault said recently, "the collection is one of the most beautiful that has ever been put together. It is a complete vision of the beginning of contemporary art." (Note: in French, the collection is spelled Chtchoukine.) The exhibit is likely to attract visitors from all over the world. The Fondation Louis Vuitton art center in Paris is run as a nonprofit initiative, as part of LVMh's promotion of art and culture. The museum has only been open for two years and sits in the middle of the suburban woods at the door of Paris, encroached to the delightful Jardin d'Acclimatation.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A voluptuous new dance film airs Friday on PBS stations nationwide. American Masters - American Ballet Theatre: A History feels more like an eccentric personal meditation, than a historical trek through the company's 75 storied years. The film is punctuated by pearls of wisdom from dance historian Jennifer Homans, choreographer Alexei Ratmansky, critics Anna Kisselgoff and Clive Barnes, current artistic director Kevin McKenzie, and dance legends Alicia Alonso, Freddie Franklin, and Lupe Serrano. The slow-motion sequences captured in this film are breathtaking, revealing the "deep intimacy" that, in Homans' words, is the province of great ballet. "The story of ballet in the 20th century is really the story of the confrontation between Russia and America... of Lucia Chase struggling with the Russians to make an American company," Homans says. "How boring would it be if it stayed an Imperial art? It couldn't, in America!" Ballet to the People is not a fan of MTV-style quick-cuts and epic slow-mo in filming ballet, which often rob a work of context and meaning, reducing it to pretty acrobatics. We root for Daniil Simkin, as he battles his own invisible demons in Everything Doesn't Happen at Once. The succinct, year-by-year timeline you will find on ABT's 75th anniversary website is perforce dry, but a welcome and essential anchor for theCompany's rich, sweeping history.
label: SAFE

text: The show features paintings, sculptures, and mixed media pieces that reflect on personal experiences and societal patterns. Museum educators have developed age-appropriate guided tours to help visitors engage with the complex themes. The exhibition includes interactive elements where visitors can share their thoughts. Organizers hope the show sparks conversations about equality and justice. text: Antarctica and Greenland are melting well over three times faster than they were in the early 1990s. Melting sea ice means rising seas. Without changing course, we're heading towards a calamitous three-degree Celsius temperature rise by the end of the century. At COP28, which starts later this week, leaders must break this cycle. Leaders must act to limit global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius, protect people from climate chaos, and end the fossil fuel age. We need a clear and credible commitment to phase out fossil fuels. And we need climate justice - setting the world up for a huge increase in investment in adaptation and loss and damage to protect people. And I thank you. United Nations Secretary-General 27 November 2023 I have just returned from Antarctica - the sleeping giant. A giant being awoken by climate chaos. And this year, Antarctic sea ice hit an all-time low. That matters for us all. What happens in Antarctica doesn't stay in Antarctica. We live in an interconnected world.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Two militants have been killed after an infiltration attempt by them was foiled. The militants tried to sneak into the valley in North Kashmir’s Uri sector. The operation attempt against the infiltrating militants has been suspended due to inclement weather and will resume once it clears up, the Army said. The Army added the other members of the infiltrated group took the bodies of the slain militants as they withdrew to the enemy side of the LoC. “As per our own assessment, the recovery of two blood stained bags confirm that at least two terrorists were grievously injured, forcing them to shed their load and flee,” the Army added in a statement on Sunday evening. ‘The search operation is suspended and will resumes once the weather clears up. Operation under progress,’ the statement said in response to a request for information from the Indian media about the alleged infiltration attempt, said the Army. The search operation was conducted on 22 October and found two AK series rifles, six pistols, four Chinese grenades, blankets and two bloodstained bags containing Pakistani and Indian currency notes.
label: UNSAFE

text: Study tracked outdoor temperatures andworker productivity at a high-tech factory in China. Despite climate-controlled conditions inside the factory, productivity dropped by 0.83% for every 1°C increase in outdoor temperature. Researchers say their findings are a "cautionary tale" as governments and businesses adapt to risingglobal temperatures. The study also found that a wet-bulb temperature over 28°C was associated with 5.8% lower productivity compared to a typical day. The paper, published in the journalEnvironmental and Resource Economics, is titled "How much will climate change reduce productivity in the high-technology supply chain? Evidence from silicon wafer manufacturing" The study was led by the University of Exeter and involved 35,190 worker-shifts (635 separate workers, all male)."In our study, climate control on its own was not sufficient to insulate a firm from the effects of high outdoor temperatures," said Dr. Jingnan Chen from the Universityof Exeter. "Our findings provide further evidence of the likely economic impacts of climate change"
label: SENSITIVE

text: Malawi has no sewer network, so people make do, doing their business in basic pit latrines. Water For People set out to support small scale entrepreneurs to be in a position to solve this problem for customers in Blantyre. One of these was a man named Matthias John. Matthias' story points to the difficulty faced by sanitation entrepreneurs and why they are in need of ongoing and specialized support over time to succeed. The Sanitation business will never be easy, but with the right encouragement and assistance, a Matthias can emerge from a hill. Now you'll see that when you look from that hill, when you'll look from the same hill, you'll find Matthias, a man who has emerged from the hill, a business that has really moved his life," says Water For people's chief executive officer, Peter Moya-Ngwabuwe. The project will also be tested in Uganda and Malawi in the coming year in order to further support Matthias to grow his business in Malawi and to diversify his business into latrine construction and toilet upgrading services. It will also give out sanitation loans to try to solve some of the challenges that exist for sanitation businesses and households looking for financial products and services. The campaign will also help to raise awareness of the need for better and cleaner pit emptying devices. The mission is to end the cycle of poverty in Africa by helping people to build a better, cleaner and more efficient sanitation space in their homes and communities.

text: Kiefer won the 100-meter backstroke at the 1936 Berlin Olympics. Kiefer later was an instructor in the U.S. Navy and a business owner. He was inducted into the inaugural class of the International Swimming Hall of Fame in 1965. He also served on the President’s Council on Fitness, Sports and Nutrition under three U.s. presidents."He was a pioneer for our sport in the truest sense of the word," USA Swimming Interim Executive Director Mike Unger said in a statement. "He embodied swimming and lived it every day of his life," said USA Swimmer Interim Chief Executive Officer Mike Ungers. "I will miss him very much," said former Olympic gold medalist and current U.N. ambassador to the United Nations, Edith Piaf. 'He was the first man to break one minute in the100-yard backstroke as a high schooler in Illinois,' said Kiefers' son, Peter. "We will all remember him as a swimmer who lived his life to the full," said his son, Paul Kiefner. "His legacy will live on in the generations to come," said Peter Kiefler. "It's a sad day for swimming, but a great day for our country," said the late swimmer's son, Robert Kiefr. "The world has lost a great swimmer, and we will all miss him." "He will be remembered as a swimming legend," said U.K. Swimming Association President and Olympic champion, Bob McAlister.

text: David Jones wrote about the Great War, in which he fought, and his style was influenced by Welsh culture. Jones was both a poet and painter, Kenneth Clark described him in the mid-1930s as "the most gifted of all the young British painters" Jones' 1937 subtle, allusive, powerful book about the war that had ended almost two decades earlier. "They were modern artists in search of a public, uncertain reward, as they knew from the immediate risk and uncertain reward of their stories," he writes. The reputation of artists has always been fickle, but Jones' was not celebrated for Moby Dick until the 20th century until after his death, he says. In Parenthesis was one of the ways of living with PTSD, one of what we today term "post-traumatic stress disorder," he says, in a way that, his intricate, overlaid visual art, has become a gift to many others as well as many others. It was not until graduate school that a seminar on "war poets," to write about David Jones, was an opportunity, he writes, "to write about the stories of my predecessors, from their stories of Impressionist painters to Herman Melville to Hermann Hesse, that I began to think of Jones as a poet. I had never even heard of Jones until I had an opportunity to study him. He writes: "For me it was like falling down the rabbit hole in Alice's Adventures in Wonderland"

text: As the planet warms, we’re losing snow. This loss isn’t just a consequence of more greenhouse gases heating the atmosphere. When tiny bits of black carbon fall on snow, they darken it. The snowpack absorbs more of the sun’s energy, warms and melts faster. New modeling suggests that by burning less fossil fuels, the ailing snowpack will get a two-for-one benefit: lower temperatures on the snow's surface and in the surrounding air.. Globally, climate change means warmer air and less snowfall. Between 1955 and 2020, spring snowpackdeclined by 20 percentacross the American West. In the western US, up to 80 percent of water resources can come from snow melt, depending on how close you are to the mountains. “People don't necessarily know where their water comes from, because they're downstream of where the snow and ice accumulates and then melts,” says snow hydrologist S. McKenzie Skiles.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Farmers in the states surrounding India’s capital still burn off the stubble in their rice fields at this time of year. As a result, the modest financial benefits from using seeders have been whittled away to nothing. The real solution would be to shift rice-growing to wetter states in the east of the country. But that would involve taking on the vested interests of farmers by dismantling the current web of subsidies that supports northern farms. The main states involved are Haryana and Uttar Pradesh, and in Delhi and Punjab, a rising force of the opposition, AAP, a growing force in rural areas, and the BJP, the ruling party in India. text: New Broadway production of George Orwell’s dystopian novel, Nineteen Eighty-Four, delivers such a slap. The pain inflicted by this 1984 is far more grippingly sensory than it is gratuitously gory. When dramatizing the actual narrative of the novel, 1984 is most effective. The performances are terrific, but there is something in the shaping of this performance that invites the audience in while, ultimately, leaving no way out. It's creepy and, at times, rather frustrating. But it works. It is no fun and neither was Orwell, from what I have read. But 1984 did provide me with one tangential wisp of reassurance. Even as 1984 delivered its fearful wake-up slap, I found myself realizing not every real-life authoritarian demagogue is as smart, effective and effective as George Orwell. This was, for me, a tiny, wishful saving grace. The show is open to interpretation and designed to leave the audience reeling and wondering. “Orwellian,” in other words, in other than “orwellian” The show opened last week at the Hudson Theatre, adapted and directed as it was in its original London incarnation by West End wunderkinds Robert Icke and Duncan Macmillan. The production is scheduled to run through December 15. It’ll be available on Broadway through December 16. For more information, visit the Hudson Theater’S website. text: Julian Zelizer: President Obama's statement on Keystone sounded like a threshold issue. He says the President's criteria for Keystone focused solely on the climate problem. Zelizer says the Administration is "doing the math" on the carbon impacts of the pipeline. The U.S. should not be an accessory to the production and sale of carbon-intensive oil, he says. oil is not inevitable, Zelizer writes, but it's a step in the right direction for U. S. energy security. The Obama Administration's rejection of Keystone could encourage more opposition to taking tar sands oil to market. The moral dimension is that helping Canada reduce its carbon budget is not in our national interest, he writes, and it's not in the world's interest to lead on climate change either. The President will have to figure out what to do with the diminishing carbon budget to meet his all-of-the-above energy policy and the prospect of leading the world in oil production in the next few years. It's time to make a decision on the final part of our climate plan -- to make America the lead part of the international effort to combat climate change, Zelizers says, no matter how difficult it may be to do it in the short-term or the long-term. The president's staff reportedly feels that the statement was straightforward and that all the speculation is fascinating, he adds. It sounded as though climate change has become the dominant concern -- a pass/fail test -- in decisions that have carbon impacts.

text: In 1944, the American Museum of Natural History in New York performed an experiment called "Response of Captive Alligators to Auditory Stimulation" In 2007, the Tampa Bay Times decided to replicate the 1944 experiment at Gatorland, near Kissimmee, Fla. When they play a sustained B-flat through the wood of the boardwalk, the gators go wild as predicted. The roaring and bellowing of the male gators are mating calls, and in the spring months, they are especially loud. text: Sergio Garcia hit the ball into the water five straight times on the 15th hole at the Masters. He required 13 strokes for the par-5 hole, tying for the worst score ever on one hole. Garcia finished the day with an 81. The current leader heading into Friday’s competition, Jordan Spieth, has a 66. He carded a 3 on the same hole when he played it in 2017 during his march to the title, Sports Illustrated wrote. He said afterward: “I don’t know what to tell you,” he said afterward. “It”s the first time in my career where I make a 13 without missing a shot. Simple as that. It’S just unfortunate, but that's what it is. It's one of those things. It was real ... and really painful to watch.” The Masters starts on Thursday at Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia. The winner will be crowned at the end of the tournament in April. The defending champion is Spaniard Sergio García, who won the title in 2013 and 2014. The tournament runs through Sunday at the club in Augusta, Georgia. It is one of the most prestigious golf tournaments in the U.S., with a total prize fund of more than $1.5 billion. The Masters is the first major golf tournament of the year and takes place every year in April and May. The event is held at the Augusta National golf club in southern Georgia.
label: SAFE

text: Violence broke out at Storm Arena during the Warriors game. At least 9 people were treated for injuries, and 8 individuals were taken into custody. Stadium officials are reviewing security protocols. The confrontation began in the stands when fans from rival teams got into an argument that escalated into physical fighting. Security personnel intervened but struggled to control the crowd. The incident occurred during a game between the Warriors and the San Francisco 49ers. The game ended in a loss for the Warriors, and the 49ers won the game in the second round. The Warriors won the first game of their playoff series, beating the San Diego 49ers in the quarterfinals, 2-1. The second game of the playoff series was won by the San Jose 49ers, who defeated the Warriors in the final game, 3-1, in front of a sell-out crowd of more than 100,000 people at the SAP Center in San Francisco. It was the first time the Warriors had won back-to-back games in the playoffs since 2008. The team won the title in 2008 and 2009. The last time they won in the postseason was in 2007, when they beat the New York Knicks in the first round, 1-0. The win was the team's third in a row and the first in six games this season. The victory was followed by a loss in the next game, when the Warriors were beaten by the Philadelphia 76ers in a game that was decided on a technicality. The next day, the Warriors beat the Knicks again.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A special UN committee met for a fifth time in Abu Dhabi this week to finalise recommendations. The goal is to get the fund up and running by 2024. To get all countries on board, it was agreed the World Bank would serve as interim trustee and host of the fund for a four-year period. The US attempted to include a footnote clarifying that any contributions to the fund would be voluntary, but the committee chair did not allow it. The committee also recommended that developed countries be urged to continue to provide support to theFund. But it failed to resolve whether wealthy nations would be under strict financial obligation to do chip in. The U.S. State Department official said: "We regret that the text does not reflect consensus concerning the need for clarity on the voluntary nature of contributions" It is a sombre day for climate justice, as rich countries turn their backs on vulnerable communities," said Harjeet Singh, head of global political strategy at nonprofit Climate Action Network International, in a statement.
label: SENSITIVE

text: PETA reports that 2.5 percent of U.S. residents are vegans, while another 5 percent are vegetarians. Celebrities like Bill Clinton, Ellen DeGeneres and now Al Gore are all on board with veganism. Experts note it can be one of the healthiest ways to eat, as you’ll limit calories and harmful fats while still consuming vitamins and minerals. It’s also good for the environment; it uses fewer resources, and doesn’t support industrial livestock farms, which often face criticism for their treatment of animals and environmental waste. The Smiths' song "Meat is Murder" is named after a vegan, Betty White, who is an animal lover but not a vegan. This article has been updated to reflect that Betty White is not a veggie, and that the name of the song is in fact Meat is Murder, not Meat Is Murder. It has also been corrected to say that Bill Clinton is a vegan and not a vegetarian, as it was previously reported. The article also incorrectly stated that Al Gore is a veg, when in fact he is a vegetarian and a non-veg person who lives in New York City with his wife, Hillary Clinton, and his daughter, Chelsea Clinton, in Washington, D.C. It was also incorrectly reported that Ellen deGeneres is a Vegans, when she is actually a Vegetarian and a Non-Vegetarian, as she is also a Vegan and a vegetarian.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Fireweed is exploring for zinc and lead mineralization at the Gayna Project in the Northwest Territories, Canada. The geology appears similar to that of the high grade Kipushi zinc mine in the Democratic Republic of Congo1. Fireweed is testing the concept that Gayna may host similar vertically oriented, reef-margin zinc andlead mineralization, where zinc occurs within very dense rocks. In 2022 and 2023, Fireweed carried out ground-based surveys that took measurements of the Earth’s gravity field to identify any anomalies that may relate to dense rocks in the subsurface. There is a close spatial relationship between mineralization around the discovery “A” showing at Gayna and a gravity anomaly, which continues to support the exploration model. Preliminary, unconstrained inversions of the 2022 and2023 gravity data have delineated 12 targets with strike lengths of 250 to 1,100 m which are ready to be tested by 2,000 to 3,000 m of diamond drilling.
label: SAFE

text: Nicolas Cage is opening up about his cameo inThe Flash. Cage tested as the Man of Steel for what would’ve been a Tim Burton-directed feature that was ultimately scrapped. “I don’t think it was [created by] AI. I know Tim is upset about AI, as I am. AI is a nightmare to me. It’s inhumane,” he said of the film's use of artificial intelligence. The actor said he was on the set of the Andrés Muschietti-directed film that starred Ezra Miller giving props to the director. He said he had no dialogue so had to convey with his eyes the emotion in the scene. ‘I literally went to shoot a scene for maybe an hour in the suit, looking at the destruction of a universe and trying to convey the feelings of loss and sadness and terror in my eyes,’ he said. The film is due out in theaters on September 14. It will also be released in UK cinemas on September 15.

text: The United States and China announced an agreement to sharply increase clean energy. The deal comes at a pivotal moment for the world's two biggest polluters. In two weeks, representatives from nearly 200 countries will gather in Dubai for UN climate talks. The agreement is short on enforcement mechanisms, but it does push forward on several fronts, experts say. the US-China climate deal is a rare point of agreement between the U.S. and China, which is at odds over geopolitics and trade. The new climate deal represents a rarepoint of agreement. The countries agreed to “pursue efforts to triple renewable energy capacity globally by 2030,” with the intention “to accelerate the substitution for coal, oil and gas generation” Both countries anticipate that they will achieve “meaningful absolute power sector emission reduction” this decade. The United States is the biggest climate polluter in history, while China is the largest polluter, with 38% of the world’s greenhouse gases.

text: Study: Restoring global forests could sequester 22 times as much carbon as the world emits in a year. Reaching the world's full potential would draw out 226 gigatonnes of excess carbon dioxide. That's roughly one-third the amount added to the atmosphere since the industrial revolution. "There cannot be a choice between nature and decarbonising," study's author says. "This paper has to be the one to kill greenwashing," Thomas Crowther says of the study's message."This is like the absolute, absolute upper bound of what could possibly ever be fathomable," says lead author of previous study. "You're never going to get there. It's unwise and it's not feasible," he adds. "The take-home message is that the forest that we have protected should be protected - absolutely correct and foundational," says ecologist Nicola Stevens of Oxford University, who had co-authored the criticism of Crowther's earlier paper. "It's always going to have some flaws, but also improves with technology advances," she says.
label: SENSITIVE

text: College football's playoff selection committee announced the schools that will compete for this year’s national title. No. 1 seed Clemson faces off against No. 4 seed Alabama in the Sugar Bowl on Jan. 1. The two teams competed in last two national title games, with Alabama winning in January 2016 and Clemson prevailing this past January. Also on January 1, No. 2 seed Oklahoma plays No. 3 Georgia Bulldogs in the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, California. The winners of these two semi-final games will square off for the national title in Atlanta on January 8. Since 2014, when the new playoff system was introduced, Alabama is the only team to have been selected for the tournament every year.. Some analysts argued that Ohio State. and even the University of Southern California (ranked eighth) were better teams this year. “To put (Alabama) in over Ohio State and USC ... should require more,” wrote Dan Wolken of USA Today. The selection of Alabama (which didn’t play on Saturday) was made on the strength of the teams’ strength of schedules, Wolken said. The decision to select Alabama was made by the playoff committee on a vote of 12-to-1. The committee made the selection after all three teams posted wins in big games on Saturday. The winner will be crowned the college champion in 2000, while Georgia has not won a national title since 1980 (long before the current playoffSystem was devised) The winner of the national championship game will be announced on January 15.

text: Brown University voted not to divest from the 15 largest U.S. coal companies. The decision comes as the fossil fuel divestment campaign continues to pick up momentum. There are now active divestment campaigns underway at over 400 colleges, cities, and religious institutions across the US. The campaign is also spreading to Europe, where Bill McKibben and 350.org are kicking off the Fossil Free Europe tour in Berlin this evening. "The voting process at Brown echos the coal industry's stranglehold on our nation's governing bodies," said Ian Georgianna '15, a member of Brown Divest Coal. "What's the point of teaching about climate science or environmental racism if we won't act on that knowledge?" said Kari Malkki '16, a Divest coal member. "Until then, our 'Boldly Brown' motto sounds laughable," said another member of the campaign, Ian Georgina '15. "This could have been a moment for Brown to step up as a leader in the fight against climate change," said Ruby Goldberg '17, a Brown student. "I'm deeply disappointed in our administration," said one student, "The board acted explicitly in opposition to the voices of Brown's community, and of the endowment oversight committee," said a student, Kari Goldberg '16. "To me this vote shows that Brown doesn't take its commitments to social justice and combating climate change seriously," said student, IanGeorgina '16,. "We're going to keep pushing them to stand for what is right"

text: The Soyuz capsule made a parachute descent southeast of Zhezkazgan, disappearing into a layer of haze as it neared the ground. Station commander Jeff Williams, with the U.S. space agency, and flight engineers Alexey Ovchinin and Oleg Skripochka are back on Earth. A replacement crew is due to launch on Sept. 23 from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan. Williams, 58, returns to Earth with a career total of 534 days in orbit, more time than any other astronaut in U.s. history and 14th in the world. of the mission comes the same day a U.N. space probe was cleared for launch on Thursday to collect and return samples from an asteroid in hopes of learning more about the origins of life on Earth and perhaps elsewhere in the solar system. The mission comes to an end with a change-of-command ceremony on Monday, with Williams handing over command of the station to Anatoly Ivanishin, who remains aboard the station with NASA astronaut Kate Rubins and Japan’s Takuya Onishi. It was several minutes until NASA could confirm the landing at 7:13 a.m. local time on Wednesday (9:13 p.M. EDT on Tuesday/0113 GMT on Wednesday) The mission ends a 172-day mission aboard the International Space Station, which is a project of 15 nations. It is the second mission for Williams, who has spent more time in space than anyone else.
label: SAFE

text: Sweden’s Charlotte Kalla wins first gold of the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang. Kalla made her break at the start of the final lap, opening up a lead that saw her cross the finish line 7.8 seconds ahead of her Norwegian rival. Coach Johan Granath was left on tenterhooks to see if Kalla's timing would pay off. Norway's Marit Bjoergen won silver to become the first woman to win 11 medals at the Olympic Winter Games in Pheonix, South Korea. The first gold medal of the Games goes to Kalla. The second gold medal goes to Krista Parmakoski, who finished third in the women's skiathlon. The third gold medal went to Norway’Sophie Hildebrand, who took home the bronze in the giant slalom. The fourth and fifth gold medals went to the women”s freestyle skiathlon, which took place in the same venue as the men’t-for-profit event. The final medal was the silver medal for the women in the skiathlon at the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics, where Kalla was runner-up. The last gold medal was won by Norway s Marit Bjoer gen, who won silver in the 2014 Winter Olympics for the first time at the Winter Games. The other three medals were won by the women in the men's freestyle event, which was held at the Alpensia Ski Jumping Centre.
label: SAFE

text: Leaked images show a new version of Apple's HomePod smart speaker with a built-in display. The display appears distinctly different than the LED matrix used on the original HomePod. The larger size and widescreen orientation suggest it is likely a full touchscreen display. It's hard to say definitively without hands-on testing, but it seems doubtful a modest display will be a game-changer. The real test will be whether Apple delivers a significantly upgraded overall experience when it likely unveils the new model later this year. The company’s famous “it just works’ reputation doesn’t always apply to its smart home products currently, as shown by its buggy multi-room audio support and Siri reliability and speed. But, for now, leaked images provide the best sneak peek at what may be in store. For now, they are the only ones we have to go on the record about the rumored new HomePod speaker, which is expected to be unveiled in September.

text: When organizations take risks on behalf of their customers, it changes the calculus of ardent allegiance. text: Three UCLA basketball players detained in China on suspicion of shoplifting arrived back in the United States on Tuesday. President Donald Trump said he had sought the help of Chinese President Xi Jinping in the case. The players landed at Los Angeles International Airport on a flight from Shanghai on Tuesday evening, their heads down. The three declined to speak to throngs of reporters before boarding a bus. The UCLA team had been in China for a game against Georgia Tech in Shanghai on Saturday, which UCLA won 63-60. the teams had traveled to Hangzhou earlier in the week to visit the headquarters of the game’s sponsor, Chinese tech giant Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. The students, all freshmen, were taken in for questioning by police about alleged shoplifting from a Louis Vuitton store. They were released from police custody early on Wednesday and had been confined to a luxury hotel pending legal proceedings, the White House said on Wednesday.. Since the matter did not occur on the court, it would be up to UCLA whether the players will be punished, Pac-12 Commissioner Larry Scott said. "I'm just glad it's resolved and that they're on the way home safely,” he told Reuters by telephone. “I want to be clear that we take seriously any violations of the law,’ Scott said of the incident. ‘I’m just glad that they’re on theway home safely.’ “The relevant case involving three students has already been resolved according to law," Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang said.
