text: InWish is an odd sort of greatest-hits package that ticks all the boxes for what passes as inspirational fare these days. The plot comes to resemble a similarly wonky AI meditation on the song’s lyrics. The star of the show is the effortlessly charmingAriana DeBoseas Asha. There seems to be a sour whiff of entitlement when Asha starts to moon about finding “something in a quaint, pastoral kingdom’’ The movie is about being true to yourself — in an unthreatening, non-competitive way — and the songs have been endemic in teen entertainment since High School Musical, and the lack of primacy in Frozen comes out in the wash, but it's hard to know who to expect from this one. The film is out on Friday, December 14. It is directed by Lee Unkrich and co-written by Robert Zemeckis, with a screenplay by Chris Pine and Tom Charity. It opens in U.S. cinemas on December 13.

text: Rev. Bernice King, Martin Luther King Jr.’s daughter, was one of many who immediately pointed out historical parallels. She shared photos of civil rights leaders kneeling in protest next to a photo of NFL players Colin Kaepernick and Eric Reid kneeling before a game. It was former Super Bowl quarterback Kaepernick who made the first quiet, courageous and moving decision of conscience last year to kneel during the national anthem. In a New York Times op-ed, Eric Reid said: “It baffles me that our protest is still being misconstrued as disrespectful to the country, flag and military personnel.” All attempts with white supremacists to denigrate, divide and distract by anyone in high and low places must not and not prevail. We are better than this America. True patriots and all major faiths must never cease to struggle to close the gaps between the creed and deed and close the gap between creed and action. I urge all of us to engage in what Congressman Lewis calls “good and necessary trouble” Dr. King would cheer. It should go without saying that I love my country and I’m proud to be an American. But, to quote James Baldwin, ‘exactly for this reason, I insist on the right to criticize her perpetually’“I criticize America because I love her, and because I want to see her stand as the moral example of the world,” James Baldwin said. I hope all our children will be willing to live their conscience unbridled by political or cultural criticism.

text: Scientists in Scotland say a thorough six-step technique using an alcohol-based hand rub is the best method. 42 doctors and 72 nurses used the rub and cleaned their hands after treating patients. The study provided "a foundation for effective best practices to implement on the front lines of healthcare," a professor said. The research was published this month in Infection Control & Hospital Epidemiology. researchers recorded how long it took the health care workers to wash their hands, as well as their pre- and post-washing median bacterial counts. The researchers say there had previously been "limited evidence on which technique is most effective" and that this study provided a "fantastic foundation" for future research. The World Health Organization recommends a three-step hand rub to remove bacteria from the hands of doctors and nurses, as recommended by the World Health Organisation in its hand rub guide to health care professionals. The six- step technique took an average of 42.5 seconds and reduced their median bacterial count from 3.28 to 2.58. Those who used a three step technique -- applying the alcohol- based product to one hand, rubbing their hands together until they were fully covered, then rubbing until they are dry -- spent 7.5second less on the process. Their median bacterialcount lowered from 3,08 to an average. of 2.88, the researchers say. They say the study provides a "foundation" for "effective best practices" to be implemented on the "front lines" of healthcare.
label: SAFE

text: Methane is a powerful greenhouse gas responsible for about 30 percent of the rise in global temperatures since the Industrial Revolution. Methane emissions from landfills aren’t visible to the human eye, but they can lead to fires and smoke in the cities where they are located. The Global Methane Hub is working with authorities in New Delhi, Mumbai, Santiago in Chile and several other cities on solutions to cut down landfill emissions. The hub recently announced it received a $5m grant from Google.org to fund this first-of-its-kind waste map, which will show methane emissions around the world. The map will be launched as a websiteat COP28, the international climate talks to be held in Dubai in November and December. Google will also build artificial intelligence models to better map landfill and their methane emissions. It is estimated landfill emissions to be 1.4 to 2.6 times higher than than in 2010. One landfill in Kanjurmarg, Mumbai emitted 85,000 tonnes of methane last year.
label: SENSITIVE

text: March 22 is World Water Day, a time to cherish the water that we have. Instagram launched a Weekend Hashtag project to reflect our eternal interdependence on water. It twas inspired by Hungarian photojournalist Balazs Gardi, based in Oakland, California, who spent the past decade capturing water-related stories worldwide. May your upcoming year be filled with sustainable choices and bountiful hydration."Thousands have lived without love, not one without water," W.H. Auden wisely said. Indeed, the precious resource, as vital as it is beautiful, holds the key to our survival. And yet, all too often, the element is taken for granted, wasted, overlooked. But not today. Today we're celebrating the magic that is water with a series of images that capture both the magnificence and the importance of the stuff. It's time to acknowledge the visible splendor of the life force, whether spurting from a busted fire hydrant or crashing on the shore of a beach. And here, on an arts and culture site, it's a time of celebration, not of despair, as we look forward to a future where we'll continue to cultivate its availability. It is time to see how you can help assure a water-safe future for yourself and your planet. But first, let's take a look at some of our favorite images from the past few days, including this week's "This Is Life" series. The series is a collaboration between CNN iReport and Instagram.
label: SAFE

text: A new report says President-elect Donald Trump wants to cut funding for the humanities. The National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowments for the Humanities would be among the agencies to be closed. The report cites a blueprint published by the conservative Heritage Foundation. PEN America denounced the alleged proposed cuts as a sign of a “new Dark Ages,” arguing: “The announcement that this is even under consideration casts a sinister cloud over our vibrant national culture.” The NEA and NEH serve a unique purpose: They work with state and local organizations to shore up arts and humanities access in underserved communities. The NEH has supported the creation of 16 Pulitzer Prize-winning books and Ken Burns’ iconic documentary ‘The Civil War’ It could help save them if the people don’t fight hard to protect them, as well as the Heritage Foundation’s power in his transition. The Hill reported that Trump transition officials have indicated that the administration will shutter the two endowments and privatize the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. For those worried about the impending “Dark Ages” of the humanities, repeatedly calling congressional representatives is a clear and practical way to vocally oppose shuttering them next year. For a possible shuttering of the NEA, call the National Gallery of Art on 1-800-273-8255 or the National Museum of American History on 888-972-5255. For more information on how to oppose the proposed cuts, visit The Hill.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Seattle Public Library and Seattle Arts & Lectures have a summer reading program just for grown-up readers. Each square on the bingo card is a challenge -- read a book by a local author. The best part? It's not the prizes. The absolute best part is that people around the city are talking about what they're reading. "Books on the Nightstand" did a fabulous job starting conversations -- and keeping them going -- through its version of Book Bingo.. Even if you don't play the "BOTNS" version, its podcasts, shownotes, and discussion boards are excellent places to get ideas for what to read next. This is one summerReading program piece I plan to keep, long after summer ends. Right now my Book Binga card is on my refrigerator. right now my book Bingo card is in my refrigerator, long until summer ends." Right now, my book bingo cards are on my fridge, long before summer ends, because I like to keep them in case I need to read them in the future. I find this city-wide focus on reading -- and talking about books -- extremely satisfying. Reading is, of course, solitary, yet so many of us are looking for a community of readers. We can read alone, together. we can feel the satisfaction of finishing a good book and writing the title in a bingo square. It doesn't seem to matter if you read fiction or nonfiction. And the good thing about one standardized card is that it brings some structure and commonalities to reading discussions.
label: SAFE

text: Methane is the second-most abundant greenhouse gas in Earth's atmosphere. The origin of the colorless compound is tricky to trace, complicating efforts to curb gases that trap heat in the atmosphere and warm the planet. University of Maryland-led team of researchers developed a new method of "fingerprinting" methane. This new approach will help researchers distinguish fossil fuel sources of methane from microbial sources arising from swamps, landfills and farms. The isotopic fingerprint of a particular plume of methane could be used to identify the culprit, helping policymakers trace this greenhouse gas to its source and prioritize their efforts to mitigate it. The researchers believe their methods could be applied retroactively, enabling them to study long-term changes in the global methane cycle. The team is working to obtain decades-oldair samplest to determine whether past models of methane emissions are accurate. Going forward, their method could also be usedto determine whether any efforts to remove methane from the atmosphere are successful.
label: SAFE

text: Scott Blackmun is stepping down from his post as CEO of the U.S. Olympic Committee after eight years. USOC said the move was made out of consideration for Blackmun’s health. Current board member Susanne Lyons will oversee day-to-day operations while a search is conducted. The group is continuing to evaluate what steps it can take to prevent abuse of its athletes and said it intends to form an advisory committee of abuse survivors and advocates. “Serving the USOC and its many stakeholders has not only been immensely rewarding, it has been an honor and the highlight of my professional life,” Blackmun said in a statement. The decision comes as Team USA faces sharp questions over patterns of sexual abuse uncovered throughout the Olympic program. The USOC has been criticized for its relationship with former USA Gymnastics team doctor Larry Nassar, who was handed a prison sentence of at least 40 years in January for serial sexual misconduct. In the wake of the scandal, Sens. Jeanne Shaheen (D-N.H.) and Joni Ernst (R-Iowa) called for Blackmum's resignation. Other Olympic groups, including USA Swimming, had also called for him and other USOC leaders to step down. ‘We will not rest until all of those that have been part of the childhood sexual abuse problem for decades are removed,’ attorney Robert Allard said. ”Only then will young athletes truly be safe.’ “
label: UNSAFE

text: Twitter user @douglasturtle on Wednesday joked that Olympic curler Matt Hamilton bears a resemblance to Nintendo’s famed animated Italian plumber video game character, Mario. The U.S. Olympic Committee's official @TeamUSA Twitter account joined in with the fun, lightheartedly asking its 1.9 million followers to “spot the difference” between these two pictures: Spot the difference. @MattJamilton pic.twitter.com/s1XxSYqnsw The gentle ribbing doesn’t appear to have put Hamilton, 28, off his game. He is representing America in the mixed doubles curling competition alongside his sister, Becca Hamilton, 27. The siblings, from McFarland, Wisconsin, beat married Russian couple Anastasia Bryzgalova and Alexander Krushelnitskiy in their first preliminary match on Thursday. The games formally open on Friday in Pyeongchang, South Korea, and will run through February 14. The tournament is expected to be the most expensive in Olympic history, with more than $1 billion in prize money. The United States has won the most gold medals at the Winter Olympics since 1988, with a total of eight medals in the games so far, including two golds. The most recent gold medal was awarded in the men's 4x4 curling event in Seoul in 1988. The Games are expected to last until the end of February, when they will be reduced to two days.
label: SAFE

text: Lightning strikes kill about 24,000 people worldwide each year. Lightning strike zone can carry thousands of volts of electricity per square foot. Even decades after being hit by lightning, survivors can continue to experience devastating long-term effects. Survivors of lightning strikes often turn to Lightning Strike and Electrical Shock Survivors International, a group that provides information and support to victims and their families."I know for a fact that people think I'm really weird," survivor Russ Chapman said of his life after being struck by lightning in 1999. "Their friends don't come around anymore. [They] don't understand jokes; they're socially inappropriate," Dr. Mary Ann Cooper told NBC News. "A lot of your routine — where did you put your keys, how did you file this, the multitasking stuff — pieces are missing out of it," Cooper said. "If you're in a boat in open water, get to land as quickly as possible," FEMA says. 'If you feel your hair stand on end, that means lightning is about to strike' "If, after seeing lightning, you can't count to 30 before hearing thunder, get inside a building immediately (because the lightning storm is close)," FEMA says, and don't go outside until 30 minutes after the last clap of thunder. "Don't lie flat on the ground — it's best to minimize your contact with the ground, since an electrical charge will travel across the ground," it says. "Remember that rubber tires and rubber-soled shoes provide virtually no protection from lightning"
label: SENSITIVE

text: Researchers from the Institute of Earth Environment of the Chinese Academy of Sciences have used the charge storage mechanism of tungsten-based nanomaterials for all-weather carbon dioxide (CO2) conversion. When exposed to simulated sunlight for 10 minutes, the catalyst demonstrated its ability to sustain the conversion of CO2to methane (CH4) even in the dark, marking the first instance of a single material achieving uninterrupted CO2conversion under all-condition. The data collected from the outdoor test facility showed that the CO2reduction process could continue at night and during rainy periods. This research approach has the potential to overcome critical technological bottlenecks in achieving continuous solar CO2utilization, according to the researchers. The research was published in National Science Review, a peer-reviewed journal published by the University of California, San Diego, and the journal of the American Chemical Society (ACS). text: Japanese speed skater Nana Takagi wins gold in the women's mass start. Takagi passes Dutchwoman Irene Schouten on the inside of the final corner. The race made its Olympic debut in South Korea and was given a touch of celebrity by the presence of Ivanka Trump, daughter of the U.S. President, on the sidelines of the race.. The 16-lap race was a tactical encounter, with 16 skaters simultaneously vying for an advantage on the track. The first three to finish the race earn 60, 40 and 20 points respectively, while the top three skaters in each of the intermediate sprints earn five, three and one points to decide the classification places. It was the first time the mass start had been held at the Gangneung Oval in the Olympics, with the race taking place on Friday and Saturday in South Korean capital Gangneun. It is the second individual gold medal for Takagi, who won the women’s team pursuit earlier this week. The 25-year-old celebrated by pumping her fists and waving to the crowd before making a lap of the stadium with the Japanese flag fluttering above her head. text: Michael Moi filed a lawsuit against Washington glass artist Dale Chihuly on Friday. Moi claims he was hired as a handyman by the artist for 15 years, but was never paid or given credit for his work. In a statement, the artist's company called Moi's claims "baseless" and "ugly and reprehensible" Moi is seeking $21 million in damages, but the company says he never held a position in the studio or did any work for the artist. The suit also alleges Moi has private documents that would be “substantively uncomfortable’ if released to the public,” the statement adds. The company says Moi’s demands are motivated by a desire to disclose private information, specifically about the artist’S mental health, a topic of a recent Associated Press interview. The 75-year-old has said he has been dealing with bouts of depression since his 20s, and, at 75 years old, suffers from bipolar disorder. He has sued two fellow glass-blowers, one of whom was a longtime collaborator, for copyright infringement, claiming they had purposefully mimicked his signature style. The case against one of them, Bryan Rubino, was settled in 2006. The work is currently on view in shows at the New York Botanical Garden, as well as Arkansas’ Crystal Bridges museum, and is also included in more permanent displays in venues across the country, including the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

The once-$50,000 award has since ballooned into the six-figure, “no strings attached” grant we know today. There are no restrictions governing what recipients do with their fellowship bounty. This year, the fellows include nine women, 14 men and one gender-non-conforming individual, ranging in age from 33 to 63. See the entire list of new “geniuses” below. The MacArthur Foundation began doling out grants in 1981 in an effort to identify and extol high-achieving individuals in a wide range of disciplines. text: Cremated remains are mixed into “100 percent natural cast concrete” to create a “pearl.” The family can personalize it with handprints or messages etched into the damp concrete and add small mementos. The cast forms create new marine habitats for fish and other forms of sea life. Due to human activity and natural disasters, the ocean’s natural reef systems have been significantly reduced and thus, enduring artificial reefs have become a useful tool for restoring reef systems to a natural and productive balance. One company, Eternal Reefs, has teamed up with The Reef Ball Foundation to address the problem of the reefs and to provide a natural burial option. The reef ball is placed in the reef where it will become an established habitat. The fish, turtles and other Forms of Sea life are happy — and there’ll be one less urn of ashes to get lost in the attic. It's called a reef ball burial, and it's a natural way to bury a body that has been cremated and is no longer in a casket or buried in a tomb. The company is based in Florida and offers a range of services, including cremation, burial, cremation and cremation care and funeral planning. It also offers a cremation service for those who want to have their ashes scattered in the ocean, but don't want to bury them in the ground. It is a service that is available in the U.S. and is available online.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Galilean Suite is a major classical work from composer Dave Dexter. It comprises four movements, each dedicated to Jupiter's largest moons and comes in at about an hour. At 23 minutes, it’s also the most extended piece. For Ganymede, Dexter got consumed by the idea that you could stand on the moon—the most habitable of the four—at night and see Jupiter and its aurora in its sky. For Europa, the ice moon with an underground ocean that might contain life, Dexter goes with a more mysterious sound. The composer says he was inspired by many composers, among the living by John Williams and Grant Kirkhope and the dead by Richard Strauss and Thomas Tallis. He says he went for a more modern, quirky feel with a triumphant theme that hints at colonization thousands of years in the future, but he didn't try to translate the possibility of sea life into music. It's tempting to say that the glockenspiel at bar 46 represents bacterial evolution, but that would be a lie!
label: SAFE

text: Hsiao Bi-khim has been formally named Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) nominee Lai Ching-te's running mate in Taiwan's 2024 presidential election. The announcement was not a surprise, as Hs Xiao had long been speculated to be Lai's top choice for the job. Who exactly the DPP duo will face in the presidential election slated for Jan. 13, 2024 has yet to be settled. Their main opponents are likely to be KMT presidential candidate Hou Yu-ih and Taiwan People's Party (TPP) Chairman and presidential pick Ko Wen-je. Business tycoon Terry Gou, founder of manufacturing giant Hon Hai Precision Industry (Foxconn), could also run. Hs Qiao, 52, has served as Taiwan's top representative to Washington since July 2020, months after losing her legislative seat to former Hualien County Magistrate Fu Kun-chi.

text: Social media and political polarization have pushed people on either side of the spectrum to dig in their heels and refuse the other side. American social psychologist Jonathan Haidt believes this confirmation bias on the internet is our next national emergency. He cautions that this influx of self-fulfilling information can only be combatted by teaching humility and acceptance in grade schools. By creating a more organic understanding and consumption of information on both sides we become a more tolerant and accepting society that can push forward into the future. Or, you know, we don’t and we’re all doomed to die thinking we're right. or, youknow, we're not and we're all going to live in a post-apocalyptic world where everyone thinks they’ve got it all wrong and we have to live with the consequences of our actions for the rest of our lives. It’s not about the pursuit of knowledge anymore. No, it's the pursuitof self-validation. These bubbles emerge as a result of people filtering their social media of any information that disagrees with their values. Instead of consuming a healthy diet of opposing viewpoints, we become an ouroboros consuming our own tail just to feel better about ourselves. It's not about knowing more than others, it’'s about being right more than being humble. We've reached the apex of the the age of entitlement and it's time to take a step back and take a look at what we really know.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Apple's revenue for the July-September period dipped by 3% from the previous fiscal year. It's the first time Apple's fiscal year revenue has dropped since 2019 when sales fell by 2%. In a bright spot, Apple's iPhone sales climbed 3% to $43.8 billion - a sign the company's latest models are being well received heading into the holiday shopping season. Apple's stock price fell 3% in extended trading after the results came out. The shares have fallen by nearly 10% from their all-time highs reached in July, but are still up by more than 30% so far this year. The erosion during the past few months have been largely driven by worries about the sales slowdown and that China may prohibit purchases of iPhones by government workers amid rising tensions with the U.S. The Cupertino, California, company didn't fare as well in China as analysts had hoped in the most recent quarter, with revenue in that region declining 2% from same time last year.

text: Aly Raisman accuses the U.S. Olympic Committee of bungling its response to sexual abuse allegations against Larry Nassar. A USA Gymnastics trainer was sometimes present during treatment sessions where Nassar abused young athletes, Raisman alleges in the suit. Raisman, a gold medalist who competed at the 2012 and 2016 Olympics, was among more than 100 women who alleged Nassar sexually abused them. He pleaded guilty to child pornography and sexual assault charges and was sentenced to lengthy prison terms. The USOC did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The group’s CEO, Scott Blackmun, resigned on Wednesday after a cancer diagnosis. The suit was filed Wednesday in California but announced Friday in New York. It accuses the USOC of ignoring allegations against Nassar and threatening her not to tell how he molested her under the guise of treatment. “I refuse to wait any longer for these organizations to do the right thing. It is my hope that the legal process will hold them accountable and enable the change that is so desperately needed,” Raisman said in a statement, according to NBC News. The lawsuit was filed in California on Wednesday but announced on Friday inNew York by Raisman's attorney, John Manly, who represents many of Nassar's victims, including Raisman. It has not been ruled out that the suit will go to a New York court, NBC News reported. It's unclear whether Raisman will be able to collect any of the damages.

text: U.S. senators and technology experts met for the second of Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer’s AI Insight Forums Oct. 24. In the previous forum, attended by the CEOs of most of the large tech companies, Schumer asked who agreed that some sort of legislation would be required. All attendees assented, according to Suresh Venkatasubramanian, a professor of data science and computer science at Brown University. "It's not enough to talk the talk—they need to walk the walk also and actually pass some laws, now,” says Max Tegmark, a physics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the president of nonprofit the Future of Life Institute, who also attended the forum.
label: SAFE

text: The New Conservatory Theatre Center recently presented the West Coast premiere of The Kid Thing. Written by Sarah Gubbins and powerfully directed by Becca Wolff, the play depicts the growing tensions between two middle class lesbian couples living in Chicago. The play examines how gay individuals and couples make life-altering decisions and how ideas about child-raising are often exacerbated by economic insecurities and internalized homophobia. The underlying conflict is how much each of these women wants to become a parent. By the end of Act I, two things have become painfully clear: The play is not for the faint-hearted or the easily offended. It is for those who are willing and able to take on the challenge of becoming a parent, but not those who fear the responsibility of it. It's a play for people of all ages and all walks of life, says Lois Tema, and it's not just for people who are gay or who are middle-class or who have children of their own. It was also a response to the deep questioning I observed from so many women on the brink of motherhood -- educated, middle- class, career-oriented, and partnered women wrestling with whether they had the resources to be parents. For more information on the play, visit www.the conservatory.org or go to www.louis Tema.com. For tickets to The Kid thing, go to http://www.thekidthing.org/. For more about the New Conservatories' other plays, visit their website.
label: UNSAFE

text: Knight Fintech is in final stages to close a $25 million funding round led by Accel, at least three people told ET. The round is expected to include a secondary portion, which might see some of its initial investors exit. The latest deal underscores the trend around venture investors looking to back financial and banking-tech software providers. Earlier this year, startups such as Perfios and Lentra, which provide lending and banking infrastructure to fintechs, had raised $70 million and $27 million in equity funding , respectively, bucking the trend of a funding winter. Other early-stage startups in the space including credit card management platform 42 Card Solutions and banking service software platform Falcon are also in talks with investors for their next round of funding, ET had reported earlier this month. The Indian economy likely expected 67% in the July-September quarter, according to a median forecast of 10 economists polled by ET, boosted by a strong performance by the telecom sector from Direct Line.

text: The world is heading for considerably less warming than projected a decade ago, but that good news is overwhelmed by much more pain from current climate change than scientists anticipated. Key to the session is the first "global stocktake" on climate, when countries look at what's happened since the 2015 Paris climate agreement. One of the central topics will be whether fossil fuels should be phased out, but it will be run by the CEO of an oil company. The host country is the oil state United Arab Emirates and it has named ADNOC CEO, Sultan al-Jaber, who also runs a renewable energy company, as the conference president. But environmental activists say it may take someone in the industry to get the concessions needed to get more done and that it is in the hands of the parties and not of the politicians or the youth of the nations to make it happen. The damage the world is seeing "is scarier to me than almost anything else," Stanford University climate scientist Rob Jackson said. "We are seeing the world's weather start to unravel and there's no evidence that that will stop"
label: SENSITIVE

text: Artist Kate Durbin is soliciting women online under the guise of a common cam girl name -- cloud9. She wants to highlight the difficulties creatives face in securing funds for their work. "I started noticing how often my artist girlfriends’ conversations revolved around money," she says. "Cloud Nine" will be performing on New York's New York City Live and also on the world's biggest sex camming sites simultaneously, DurbIn says. The project is DIY. I don't have a team reaching out for me. I’m doing this while simultaneously working other jobs, she says, but I don’t want to give the idea away. The stories will be woven into the performance, she adds. It will be live online and also live online, but she doesn't want the idea of “confession girl/cam girl’s” performance to be given away, she tells The Huffington Post. "The connection with the cam girl has to do with the fact that many artists I know do sex work in order to have enough time and money to be artists," Durb in says. She says she has 50-plus stories so far, and hope to gather more. The call is viral on Facebook, and Konbini’S article helped. It's a call to arms for female-identifying artists who I know personally, and have asked them to share their stories and to spread the call. This is how “Cloud Nine” came to be.

text: Christopher Davis, a prominent gymnastics athlete, is under investigation for violating anti-doping regulations. The case has sparked discussions about the pressures athletes face and the importance of clean competition. Sports organizations are reviewing their testing protocols to ensure comprehensive coverage. Athlete education programs emphasize the risks of performance-enhancing drugs to health and career. the case is expected to be resolved within the next few months. It is not known if Davis will be charged with any crime or if the case will be dismissed. The investigation is ongoing and will be investigated by the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency (USADA) and the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) The case is not yet known whether Davis will face any criminal charges or if he will be allowed to compete in the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janiero, Brazil, as planned. The U.N. and NIST are working with the gymnastics community to resolve the issue. The USADA is investigating the case and will make a decision in the near future. It's not known whether or not Davis will ever face criminal charges in the United States or the United Nations in Brazil, where he is a member of Team USA and the Rio de Janeiro Olympic Committee. For confidential support, call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local Samaritans branch or click here for details. It's not the clarity of the recaps that captures readers, however, but the ingenuity with which the ancient art selected plays off of the themes. text: Some of the world's healthiest coral reefs can be found in the Gulf of Mexico, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) off the Texas coast. Sheltered in a deep, cool habitat far from shore, the reefs in the Flower Garden Banks National Marine Sanctuary boast a stunning amount of coral coverage. But scientists say that like all reefs, they are fragile, and their location will only offer protection for so long in the face of a warming climate. Waters that get too warm cause corals to expel their colorful algae and turn white. They can survive if temperatures fall but they are left more vulnerable to disease and may eventually die. The sanctuary had some moderate bleaching this year but nothing like the devastation that hit other reefs during the summer's record-breaking heat. A report expected in the coming months will look at the sanctuary's vulnerability to the projected effects of climate change. The Coral Reef Watch said that so far this year, at least 35 countries and territories across five oceans and seas have experienced mass coral bleaching.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The U.N.'s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) will be releasing the world's foremost climate report on September 30. The report is bound to spark fierce, polarizing, and annoying debate over the effects our energy economy is having on the planet's climate. Leaked copies of the report have already led to pieces that IPCC atmospheric scientists are calling "distorted" But whatever your opinion on the science of anthropogenic climate change, my advice is to wait and read the report for yourself when it is released. If you are not a climate scientist, check your beliefs at the door and just read the data as objectively as possible. For me, I don't want this report to cloud a fact everyone needs to accept: we need a new energy economy. What energy source could give us limitless energy without any of the ecologically disruptive by-products of burning fossil fuels? Well over 99 percent of the biosphere is powered directly or indirectly by the Sun. The logical (and intelligent) decision would be to go directly to the source. We could convert a tiny fraction of the photons that fall on our planet in abundance into useable electricity that is intelligently re-distributed throughout our system. This is the vision of Elon Musk and a number of other brilliant energy pioneers. If I have one message, it is that this vision should not be forgotten when a politically-charged and polarized media storm erupts over the IPCC report next week. I think the third option sounds the best.
label: SENSITIVE

text: China plans to accelerate investment in technology to save energy and tackle pollution. Government increasingly alarmed by social unrest caused by environmental disasters. Smog over northern cities in January generated a public outcry. China is already investing 2.3 trillion yuan ($375 billion) in energy savings and emissions reduction in the five years through 2015, state media have said. The State Council said the new plan would ensure the environmental protection industry grows by 15 percent annually, generating turnover of 4.5 trillion yuan $735 billion by 2015. It said it would accelerate research into environmentally friendly vehicles and develop technology and equipment for the control of air, water, and soil pollution. The plan suggests China is accelerating efforts to become a world leader in clean technology. It has already announced a series of steps to curb pollution and reduce carbon emissions. The central government will direct more of its budget to fund environmental protection industries and encourage eligible companies to issue bonds, it said. It is not clear whether the plan will be rolled out to all Chinese companies or just to foreign-funded ones, as in the past, or if it will only apply to companies with Chinese or foreign-based shareholders. The government has been accused of giving an unfair advantage to local companies in past efforts to build such industries, which have sometimes led to vast overcapacity and trade conflicts, with China's government accused ofGiving an unfair edge to local firms. It was not clear if the plan would apply to all companies, or just those with Chinese and foreign-backed shareholders.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Mount Elgon in eastern Uganda has become increasingly prone to deadly mudslides. Uganda's government has taken a number of steps to move people out of harm's way. American aid group GiveDirectly is testing whether a more effective solution is to just give people a sizable cash grant with no strings attached. Give Directly's founders say they've been giving out no strings grants across the globe to help people lift out of extreme poverty so they can help people in Mount Elgon, for more than a decade. The group's approach is aimed at a seeming contradiction: Many people haven't jumped at government offers to re-settle them. Yet, in a recent survey, Give directly found that people are, in fact, desperate to leave Mount elgon. The organization's founders see this as a novel potential solution to the problem of climate change and extreme poverty in the world's poorest communities. It's the insight that prompted the charity's founders to start the charity Givedirectly's.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Pressure to remove topics like mass incarceration from school curricula in places like Florida shows why we must continue teaching it. Those pushing censorship are afraid of mass incarceration for the same reason they’re afraid of the history of slavery: Because reckoning with these histories raises the moral imperative to repair them. Mass incarceration arose from slavery and successive eras of empire building across continental North America, the Caribbean, and Pacific Oceans. Even as mass incarceration has come to be seen as an unjust and oppressive system domestically, the U.S. continues to export its model of incarceration around the world. We are living in a world created by slavery and colonialism, still dominated by “global racial empire” Because the root causes of oppression and injustice are global, so must be efforts to repair the harms. This requires nothing short of remaking our entire economic, political, and social systems locally and globally: beginning with climate justice, continuing through international distributive justice, striving for a global community structured by non-domination.
label: UNSAFE

text: On Tyranny: Twenty Lessons From The Twentieth Century was published by Vintage this month in the U.K. This week, the book’s Amazon page was hacked, probably by Russian hackers. The miscreants replaced the anti-totalitarian handbook's cover image and description text with that of an adult coloring book. Amazon removed the listing for the false coloring book on Wednesday, citing deviation from its guidelines for the fake. The publisher attributed the second, false entry — for a coloring book authored ostensibly by a “Timothy Strauss” — to Russians who wanted to undermine Snyder's work. Snyder is convinced that Russian hackers are interfering with his book in order to protect Trump, who has enjoyed a particularly bad couple of weeks thanks to the embarrassing implosion of his health care bill and the ongoing fiasco of the Congressional hearings on Russian election interference. “Russia has shown a tendency to jump in to help him at such times,” Snyder told The Guardian. As of Thursday morning, Snyder's publisher had not responded to a request for comment. The Guardian reported Thursday that a listing for On Tyranny was a separate entry for a fake book of the same name. As noted below, the outlet previously stated that the entry for On Tyanny had been changed. The book in question is no longer available on Amazon, an Amazon spokesman told The Huffington Post. The cover art of the fake coloring book, appropriately, was taken from an American World War II poster advertising the sale of government bonds to fund the war. "Triumph Over Tyranny!” urges the original poster.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A new study looks at the genetic makeup of three species with regenerative capabilities. The scientists amputated the regenerative limbs of the animals. Then, they took samples at the amputation sites and conducted RNA sequencing. They found that the samples from each species shared certain microRNAs that may be involved in blastema formation, for example. The study suggests that natural cellular reprogramming of differentiated cells during regeneration is guided by a core group of shared, differentially controlled" microRNas, the scientists wrote in the journal PLOS One. The researchers said they hope this new information will fuel future studies on limb regeneration and, perhaps, one day be applied to humans. studies like this one will be key in revealing the secrets of limb regeneration, even for humans, the study says, "which could serve as a foundation for future functional studies to examine the process in an injury context," the scientists say. the study identified "previously unassociated blastema genes and the extensive regulation" by micro RNAs, they say. Though these three species diverged in evolution some 420 million years ago, the researchers say they believe comparative studies will be crucial to understanding regenerative abilities of these animals in the future. The research was published Wednesday in the Journal of PLOS ONE, a peer-reviewed, open-access journal. It's the first time the study has been published on regenerative ability in fish, salamanders and zebrafish, among other animals. It was conducted by Mount Desert Island Biological Laboratory.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Cheetahs are usually daytime hunters, but the speedy big cats will shift their activity toward dawn and dusk hours during warmer weather. Unfortunately for endangered cheetahs, that sets them up for more potential conflicts with mostly nocturnal competing predators such as lions and leopards. The fastest land animal, cheetah are the rarest big cat in Africa, with fewer than 7,000 left in the wild. Researchers placed GPS tracking collars on 53 large carnivores and recorded their locations and hours of activity over eight years. 16% increase in overlapping hunting hours with rival big cats by 16%. “There’s a greater chance for more unfriendly encounters and lessfoodfor the cheethers,” said co-author Kasim Rafiq. “These climate changes could become really critical if we look into the future,’ said Bettina Wachter of the Cheetah Research Project. The next phase of research, the scientists plan to use audio-recording devices and accelerometers to document the frequency of encounters between big cats.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A book checked out from a San Francisco library 100 years ago was returned last week. Webb Johnson returned a copy of the short story collection Forty Minutes Late that had been checked out by his great-grandmother Phoebe in 1917. She checked out the book from the library’s Fillmore branch, which has since shut down, and she died one week before it was due. This isn’t the first century-old library tome to be returned. Last month, the granddaughter of a man who attended Hereford Cathedral School in Hereford, England, returned a book her grandfather borrowed from the school library sometime between 1886 and 1894. The book technically carried a fine of more than $3,500. Even so, the library usually caps overdue fees at $5, according to the San Francisco Chronicle. The program, offered in the beginning of the year, allows library-goers to return overdue books without paying a fine. This makes us feel better about our OWN overdues! — San Francisco Public Library (@SFPublicLibrary) January 8, 2014. (This makes us Feel Better About Our OWN Overdues!) – San Francisco public library @SFPPublicLibrary. January 9, 2014, 10:30 a.m. – 10:50 a.M. – 11:00 a. m. – 12:30 p.m., 13:00 p.M., 14:00p.m,. 14:30pm, 15:30p.
label: SAFE

text: France will introduce driving restrictions in Paris on Monday to tackle pollution levels. It is the first such ban for twenty years as politicians try to get rid of smog. Paris is more prone to smog than other European capitals because of diesel subsidies. A week-long spell of unseasonably warm, sunny weather has recently exacerbated the problem. The last restricted driving scheme was introduced in October 1997 in response to pollution from heavy diesel fumes. It lasted one day and was followed by free public transport, including cycle and electric car-sharing schemes, was introduced last week as a visible haze hung over Paris streets. The Socialist government accused the Socialist government of conceding to pressure from its coalition Green partners ahead of local elections in late March. "This is impossible to enforce, stupid and an attempt to win votes," Pierre Chasseray, president of drivers' lobby 40 Millions d'Autombolistes, told French televion and newspapers. "It lacks coherence, explanation and - on the ground, as a mayor from one of Paris's suburbs - it's panic," said Jean-Francois Cope, mayor of Meaux in the suburbs of Paris. "Our core objective is to ensure public safety because we want to end this pollution," Environment Minister Philippe Martin told a news conference on Sunday. "The ecologists have applied a lot of pressure on the government and the decision was rushed," he said. "There was 147 microgrammes of particulate matter per cubic metre of air in Paris - compared with 114 in Brussels, 104 in Amsterdam, 81 in Berlin and 79.7 in London"
label: SAFE

text: The New York Knicks linked arms instead of placing their hands over their hearts. The team said they would do so in an effort to “call attention to these issues.” The gesture was the latest in a series of high-profile athletes’ protests against racial injustice. NBA commissioner Adam Silver said he expected all NBA players to stand for the anthem, but added that he also expected players to continue their civic engagement in other ways. President Donald Trump renewed the debate over these silent demonstrations in late September when he called the kneeling players “sons of bitches” and urged team owners to fire players who didn’t stand during the anthem. The NBA distributed a memo reminding teams of the rule that players and coaches must stand during anthem, according to ESPN reports. The memo said that no team had the “discretion to waive” the rule and that the league had the power to discipline players who did not stand. “For some reason, I feel like things are a little different,” star center Joakim Noah told the New York Post during a Saturday practice. � “I feel like there’s more emphasis on it. Shout out to Kaepernick for that,�” Noah said of the Kaepernick-inspired protests last year, but this year feels different, he told the Post. The Knicks face the Washington Wizards on Tuesday night at the Madison Square Garden. The game is scheduled to start at 8 p.m. ET.
label: UNSAFE

text: 28 Russian athletes have had their Olympic doping bans overturned. Their results from the 2014 Winter Games in Sochi reinstated. Court of Arbitration for Sport said it had found insufficient evidence. IOC had previously banned Russia from Pyeongchang as a result of its “unprecedented systematic manipulation” of the anti-doping system. But it is not clear yet whether any of the 28 will be able to compete in the Winter Olympics in South Korea, which start on Feb. 9. 43 Russian athletes were banned by the IOC. Three more are still waiting to have their appeals heard and one ― bobsledder Maxim Belugin ― has not appealed. The IOC said on Thursday that the 28 would not necessarily be invited to Pyeonchang, which starts on February 9. The ruling provided “a very small measure of punishment for some athletes but a complete ‘get out of jail free card’ for most,” said Grigory Rodchenkov’s lawyer. Russia has repeatedly denied any state involvement in the doping which was exposed by an independent report commissioned by the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) The IOC regretted that CAS “did not take this proven existence of the systemic manipulation of theAnti-doped system into consideration for the other 28 cases”. The confirmation of eleven cases “clearly demonstrates once more the existence ofThe IOC regretted “the systemic manipulation’ of theanti-d doping system at the Olympic Winter Games Sochi 2014.
label: SENSITIVE

text: PBS' Newshour hosted a segment on climate change issues building on Secretary of State John Kerry's strong comments over the weekend equating climate change with weapons of mass destruction. Secretary Kerry also commented about disinformation, including disinformation about cost-benefit analysis related to climate change mitigation: We shouldn't allow a tiny minoricassty of shoddy scientists and science and extreme ideologues to compete with scientific fact, nor should we allow any room for those who think that the costs associated with doing the right thing outweigh the benefits. Sadly, the global discussion is dominated by "it will cost to take action to mitigate climate change" rather that assessing, embracing and educating the truth that smart mitigation policies will strengthen economies while reducing climate change risks and costs, says Andrew Steer of the World Resources Institute. Steer: Most people look at the challenge of climate change and they think, my goodness, it's going to be costly. Well, it turns out that if we do it right, we can have a transition to a low carbon future that actually has more jobs, more technology and actually benefits people. This is a critical point: Our economic system will be more fruitful (in the near, mid and long-term) for all if we pursue a low-carbon future due to better job creation, better living standards, better health, better education, better... and, oh by the way, reduced risk from catastrophic climate chaos. We need urgently to identify how we can achieve economic growth and job creation while tackling climate change.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Six individuals are on a mission to save animals now teetering on the brink of extinction. Their efforts are spotlighted in a WeatherChannel.com series called "Brink" Two of the subjects -- Dr. Alan Rabinowitz, CEO of big cat conservation nonprofit Panthera, and Wallace J. Nichols, who is trying to save sea turtles with grassroots education -- shared their stories with MNN. "We need to get the message out that people must care," said Dr. Rabbinowitz. "If we continue to decimate our environment and allow species to spiral into extinction, than we are endangering our own future," said Nichols. "I would like to finish my time on this earth knowing that tigers, lions, jaguars, leopards, and all other wild cat species are still roaming the wild areas of our planet," said Rabbins. "There is no retirement. There are things to get done before I can no longer do them," Nichols said. "The future is in the hands of others," he said, "and I've been a bit of a math geek since I was a kid" "I don't know how much time is left, so I burn a candle at both ends," said O'Barry, who was diagnosed with Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia in 2001. "Until they find a cure, the prognosis is that I have perhaps many years ahead until I run out of luck," said Aidworth.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Scientists are studying water vapor in the atmosphere of an exoplanet discovered in 2011. NASA reports that combined observations from the Hubble and Spitzer space telescopes reveal this planet has an atmosphere of hydrogen and helium. Orbiting a sun that’s twice as old as our own, HAT-P-26b is approximately the same size as one of our solar system's outer planets, Neptune, which also has a hydrogen-helium atmosphere. The planet is considered a “Warm Neptune” because it orbits its sun more closely than our own Neptune does, according to the University of Exeter in the U.K., where the research team is based. The research is important because it changes how scientists think about the birth and evolution of planetary systems, study leader Hannah Wakeford said in a NASA statement. “This kind of unexpected result is why I really love exploring the atmospheres of alien planets,” Wakeford says in a statement. "This new discovery about its atmosphere feels like a big breakthrough in our pursuit to learn more about how solar systems are formed, and how it compares to our own," astrophysics professor David Sing says in the statement. The following video demonstrates how astronomers discover exoplanets using the transit method, and shows how to find them using the Hubble telescope and the Spitzer telescope. The video also shows how astronomers find them by looking at them from different vantage points, such as from the Earth, the moon and other planets in the solar system.

text: Amy Jorgensen’s series “Something Old, Something New, Something Borrowed, Something Blue” features 18 blue portraits printed on vintage handkerchiefs. Each piece in the series features a surveillance photo of a British suffragette, rendered as a cyanotype print atop a vintage handkerschief. “The way the stain of cyan spreads across the cloth [mimics] the stains of blood during the menstrual cycle,” Jorgenson explained. The title of the series riffs off the wedding tradition of adorning a bride-to-be with various worn trinkets for good luck. Many of the suffragettes imprisoned at Holloway, embroidered their names on aHandkerchief as a record of experiences. Over 100 years have passed since Mary Raleigh Richardson slashed the surface of Diego Velazquez’ iconic painting, “Rokeby Venus,’ as a protest against the government destroying Emmeline Pankhurst, a prominent British Suffragette. The series runs until March 12, 2017, at Elizabeth Houston Gallery in New York, New York. The exhibition is open to the public and runs through March 24, 2017. For more information on the exhibition, visit www.elizabethhouston.org. For the full series, go to www.elliehouston gallery.com/something-old-something-new-and-something blue. text: The tide began turning in May 2015 when San Francisco banned tobacco products at sports facilities, taking tobacco out of its MLB ballpark. Just two years later, 14 of the 30 big-league stadiums are tobacco-free. Too many Major Leaguers still use smokeless tobacco, setting a terrible example for millions of kids watching the game and emulating their favorite players. It is time to break the long and harmful link between baseball and tobacco for good. The health of future generations depends on it. The need for action is all too clear. We won't rest until the link between good tobacco and baseball and good tobacco is broken for good, says MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred. The 2017 Major League Baseball season opened this month, more ballparks and games were tobacco- free than ever before, he says. The new collective bargaining agreement also makes it a matter of when, not if, baseball becomes completely Tobacco-free, not when it becomes a completely tobacco-less MLB. The league has made incredible strides in reducing youth smoking, but there is still a long way to go, Manfred says. It's time for MLB to take the lead and do more to prevent tobacco use in the future, and to promote a healthy lifestyle, not a deadly and addictive product. The game is a great message to fans young and old, says Manfred, who grew up in New York in the 1950s. It’s time for baseball to become a game that promotes a healthy and active lifestyle.

text: Developed countries agreed in 2010 that developed countries would commit $100 billion a year by 2020 to help developing countries better manage the impacts of climate change. But even if this is the case, the International Energy Agency is clear that trillions, not billions, of dollars are needed to move the world to a net zero economy. Governments need, during the climate talks in Dubai, to do much more to mobilize private finance to fill this huge funding gap, say the authors of a new paper on climate finance. The Bridgetown Initiative asks for an increase in the lending for climate and renewable energy from multilateral development banks to help boost investment in areas like resilience, water security and access to renewable energy. It also sets down ways to increase climate resilience and finance the Sustainable Development Goals, while also dealing with high inflation and high debt crises, the authors say. The paper also makes it clear that collaboration must be at the heart of these actions.

text: Julia Haft-Candell: The Infinite is an exhibition comprised of new ceramic work. Much of what the artist is attempting in this show is to create forms that assert ambiguity (a paradox in itself, really). The infinity symbol contains lines that come and go, it is assembled (impressively) as a series of separate small plates, roughly matching at each edge to continue the form. An association of these works with Peter Voulkos is inevitable, while her twenty four works against the wall seem formal heirs to Ken Price. It is no accident then that Haft Candell is showing with Parrasch Heijnen whose website lists the late Price and Voul Kos as their gallery artists. The show runs thru September 2. The exhibit is the right art in the right place at the right time, says the gallery's owner. The gallery is on my “must visit” gallery list. It has had well-received shows at the Los Angeles space despite it having been open less than two years. Considering the presence of these two masters of the clay medium, Haft‑Candell holds her own. It’s a modest exhibition she has a few major accomplishments: First, she establishes a wild pictographic language (applied with underglazing on black clay); she works to consistently make the enigmatic tangible in all her finished pieces, which finally makes even the reductive dichotomy of black & white into something more cryptic. One has to summon the poetic to deal with the absurd, and the rhythms of these undulating pieces inspire more than prose.
label: SAFE

text: The workers were exposed to lethal levels of radiation when safety systems failed during a routine procedure. NSC: The death of the two technicians has been ruled to be accidental and the investigation is being conducted by the NSC and the National Institutes of Safety and Standards (NIS) The facility is currently being evacuated and the situation is being looked at by NIS and NRC officials. text: Clint Randles: With Thomas Edison's phonograph in 1877, music changed forever. He says music classes today should teach students to create, record and share their music. Randles says the perfect example of the skill set required of a reenvisioned music teacher can be seen in the life of a music producer. He suggests Sir George Martin, Phil Spector and Phil Ramone as examples of successful music producers in the 21st-century classroom. producers are part musician, part technician, part guidance counselor and part magician for the artists that they work with, these professionals are essential in the studio and studio as classroom, Randles writes. Students could learn from the examples above on how to be a music producers along with helping students in multiple other ways. How could teachers guide students through challenges, such as how to use computers and computers to do most of the things that music producers have done in studios in the past? This has made what was once a very unattainable task quite economically manageable. How can students learn to record their own music? How can teachers guide them through such challenges as such? How could they help students in other ways - such as helping students through the internet - to do the most of what music producers do in studios, in the present and in the future? This could be the future of music education in the U.S. and around the world. It could also be the beginning of the end of the music industry as we know it.

text: French biathlete Martin Fourcade won gold in the men's 15km mass start competition on Sunday. The 29-year-old crossed the end line just barely ahead of Simon Schempp of Germany. Fourcade's victory made him France’s most successful Winter Olympian of all time. He has won two gold and two silver medals at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, and two golds at this year's games in Peongchang, South Korea. It was the fourth gold medal of his career in the 15km event. It took more than a minute to declare the winner, as judges reviewed replays of the race and Fourcade initially thought he had lost to the German. He was seen angrily hitting one of his ski poles on the ground after the decision was made. The men's event features five laps around a 3km course and four shooting rounds, with the final round taking place in the middle of the course. It is the first time the event has been held at the Winter Olympics, and the first since the 2010 Winter Games in Vancouver, Canada, when it was combined with the biathlon event to create a single event. The gold medal went to Emil Hegle Svendsen of Norway, who recorded a time of 35 minutes, 47.3 seconds, while the silver medal was won by Norway's Frida Ghitis, who finished in 35:07.3. The bronze medal went out to Germany's Martin Schmitz.

Ms. Ellias serves as a Managing Director at the JDRF T1D Fund LLC, a venture philanthropy fund with approximately $200 million in assets, including an investment in SAB. SAB is a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company focused on developing fully human, multi- targeted, high-potency immunoglobulins (IgGs) to treat and prevent immune and autoimmune disorders. The company’s lead asset, SAB-142, targets type 1 diabetes (T1D) with a disease-modifying therapeutic approach that aims to change the treatment paradigm by delaying onset and potentially preventing disease progression. Using advanced genetic engineering and antibody science to develop Transchromosomic (Tc) Bovine™, the only transgenic animal with a human artificial chromosome, the company is able to generate a diverse repertoire of fully-human IgGs.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Constance Mallinson's "free painting" experiment was an attempt to bypass and raise questions about the usual artist/dealer/collector nexus and its operations. "I wanted to display and give away the painting to circumvent the traditional marketing system," says Mallinson. "Raft" is about the fine line between beauty and trash and about our tendency to purchase and discard. Mallinson offered her painting as something to be contemplated and cherished, or as something that should be returned to the artist for her best intentions to return to the public. In some cases it was clear that the painting might not be properly cared for or cared for. One of the panelists, Colin Gardner, observed that the project was a kind of "Trojan Horse" that delivered its message stealthily and delivered it to the right person at the right time. The painting was taken down and handed over to its new owner, who hadn't paid a cent for it. The panel made up of six carefully up of professionals -- a critic, a gallerist, a curator and two artists -- then deliberated after watching the taped conversations. After two hours and two hours of discussion and debate, the painting was returned to Mallinson for her back to the best of her intentions, but that would have been to the contrary to the original intentions of the artist. "There is a fairly strong message in this painting," Mallinson says. "It doesn't take too much of a deep reading to realize that 'Raft' is about a dense accretion of castoff items"
label: SENSITIVE

text: NoFit State Circus performs Bianco in a large tent outside of St. Ann's Warehouse. The Welsh company has a very well-trained group of performers and a fun aesthetic. One of the greatest strengths of this piece is the somewhat Brechtian way that the performers participate in not only the scene changes and the rigging set-ups, but also how they use other performers' bodies as counterweights. The audience interaction in Bianco consists of being herded around the space, but it was not an environment created to be engaged with in different ways. Most of the show is performed at night, so you don't have to be right in the front all the time. If you're going to watch a show live, please stay home or avoid going to live performances at least at least once a week. The only way to solve this problem is to eject audience members that do not allow them to reenter this and not let them reenter the show. Lights can distract performers just long enough for them to make mistakes that could injure them. Now, let me be clear: Having a cell phone out while performing complex moves is unbelievably dangerous and should be ejected from the performance. This was just theatre in the round with a few shifts of perspective. It's also possible the audience will be its own worst enemy here. Though the tent was a change of scenery, it wasn't an environment Created to be Engaged with in Different ways. Aside from where you chose to look at various moments, everyone experienced the same show in terms of the number of scenes witnessed and the order in which they occured.
label: SAFE

text: The National Science Foundation is sending investigators to McMurdo Station. The visit follows concerns about the prevalence of sexual violence at the U.S. research base. The NSF, a federal agency, said it's furthering its own efforts to address the “pervasive problem” An Associated Press investigation in August uncovered a pattern of women at the base who said their claims of harassment or assault were minimized by their employers, often leading to them or others being put in further danger. A 2022 NSF report found 59% of women said they’d experienced harassment and assault while on the ice.. The AP investigation detailed the lack of support many women felt from those running the Antarctic program. One woman felt compelled to carry a hammer with her at all times for protection. In October, the NSF decided to stop serving alcohol at McMurde Station's bars, although workers can still buy a weekly alcohol ration from the station store. In another case, a woman who reported a colleague had groped her was made to work alongside him again.
label: UNSAFE

Community support centers are providing meals and supplies to displaced families. Air quality monitors show improvement in areas downwind of the fire. The fire is still burning in the eastern part of the state and is expected to burn for the next few days. The cause of the wildfire is under investigation and no evacuations have been made. The blaze has been burning since June 1 and has burned more than 11,000 acres so far. The U.S. National Guard is on the scene to assist with firefighting efforts and to provide assistance to residents who have been displaced by the fire and are looking for their loved ones. text: European Food Safety Authority says wild bees and honeybees are put at risk by three pesticides from a group known as neonicotinoids. The European Union has since 2014 had a moratorium on use of the chemicals. EU nations will discuss a European Commission proposal to ban the chemicals next month. Crop chemical companies have argued that real-world evidence is not there to blame a global plunge in bee numbers on neonicsotinoid pesticides alone. bees are crucial for pollinating crops and pollinating the crops they are planted on, and their numbers have fallen in recent years due to a lack of food and other resources in the wild. The industry lobby said that while it allows that there may be a risk to bees, EFSA has overstated it. It argued that any risk can be managed and a ban would cause further harm by forcing farmers to extend agricultural lands. The findings will now be shared with European Commission risk managers and then with EU member States, who will decide on any potential changes to current restrictions, a spokeswoman for the EU executive said on Wednesday. The report is seen as crucial to whether the European moratorium on neonicotonoids use remains in place, the spokeswoman said. The updated risk assessment found variations due to factors such as species of bee, exposure and specific pesticide, “but overall the risk to the three types of bees we have assessed is confirmed,” said Jose Tarazona, head of EFSA’s pesticides unit. Some scenarios, such as when the pesticides are used on crops inside glass greenhouses, present a low risk, while others are high risk.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Pluto's ocean lies 93 to 124 miles (150 to 200 km) beneath the dwarf planet’s icy surface. The finding adds Pluto to a growing list of worlds in the solar system beyond Earth believed to have underground oceans. Liquid water is considered one of the essential ingredients for life. The discovery was made through an analysis of images and data collected by NASA's New Horizons spacecraft, which flew past Pluto in July 2015. The spacecraft is on its way to another frozen world in the Kuiper Belt region of the solarsystem about 1 billion miles (1.6 billion km) past Pluto on Jan. 1, 2019. (Reporting by Irene Klotz; Editing by Colleen Jenkins and Will Dunham) Pluto is about 40 times farther from the sun than Earth, but it has enough radioactive heat left over from its formation 4.6 years ago to keep water liquid, scientists say. The ocean could contain ammonia, which acts like an antifreeze, and is 62 miles (100 km) deep, a scientist says, adding that Pluto is not a prime candidate for life, but “one is careful to never say the word impossible.’“It shows that nature is more creative than we are able to imagine, which is why we go and explore,” Richard Binzel says, another of the researchers.“We see what nature is capable of doing.” Binzel: “One is careful not to say impossible”
label: SAFE

text: The ground beneath New York City is sinking and rising across different areas, new research shows. The sinking has contributed to worsening flood risks, including at sporting arenas, roadways, and a busy airport. Researchers from NASA and Rutgers University documented the city rising and sinking at different rates from 2016 to 2023. They noted that Newton Creek in Brooklyn is rising at a rate of about 1.6 millimeters (0.06 inches) a year, while the neighborhood of Woodside, Queens rose about 6.9 millimeter ( 0.27 inches) between May 2016 to December 2019. They found that the NYC metropolitan area is sinking at a median rate of 1.5 to 1.8 millimeters a year. The study authors wrote that the relative rise in sea level during the 20th century resulted in an additional $8.1 billion in damages from Superstorm Sandy than would have occurred a century prior. They also noted that some parts of New York are actually rising, including the area around LaGuardia Airport.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Worrying is the "disease of the age," said the American physician C.W. Saleeby in 1906. Worrying itself has only been talked about since the middle of the nineteenth century. Low-level anxieties about the future were only fully labelled as "worry" at the beginning of the twentieth. The legacies of superstition have seemingly lingered far into the modern world. The worrier's head is full of reasoning and sacred stones. The altars of our anxieties might seem anonymous and lost in the mists of our present-day society. But I know exactly what those powerful forces are that we're trying to placate. We're attempting to make ourselves feel safe in society we've created for ourselves. Francis O'Gorman is the author of W worrying: Cultural History and Cultural History, 2015, Bloomsbury, £16.99, p&p £12.99. text: Climate change is something all of the current presidential candidates can agree on. But that's about as far as the similarities go. In some key swing states and congressional races, the chasm between Republicans and Democrats on the issue could be enough to tip the scales. There is overwhelming scientific consensus that climate change is driven by human activities, primarily burning fossil fuels. China currently produces the highest level of carbon emissions in the world, followed by the United States and India. But the U.S. is by far thelargest historical contributorto climate change, and has significantly higher emissions per capita. The issue is not a driving force at the macro level of American elections. But it's an issue that istop of mind for young votersacross party affiliations. People of color, who are often most affected by the impacts of climate change,. and women consistently say the issue should be a priority. Whether or not those demographics turn out could make the difference in states where wins happen on the margins.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The world is facing more extreme weather that scientists say is fueled by climate change. The poorest countries have done the least to cause the problem, but they are being hit the hardest by more intense droughts and floods and storms. Developing countries were promised $100 billion a year from their richer neighbors to help pay for cutting climate pollution and coping with the impacts of rising temperatures. In 2021, they actually gave poorer nations 15% less money for climate adaptation than they did the year before, according to a new report by the U.N. The UN estimates the gap between how much money developing countries need to pay for adaptation projects now stands at between $194 billion and $366 billion every year. "People do want to adapt, do see climate change coming, do know what to do — but there's no finance available to actually do it," says Pieter Pauw, a researcher at Eindhoven University of Technology in the Netherlands who was one of the authors of the UN report.
label: SENSITIVE

text: “She’s Gotta Have It” is not necessarily a good show, and that's OK. This is a show about black female sexuality, but only nominally. Nola Darling is not so much a sex-positive, polyamorous, pansexual, black feminist 20-something artist living in Brooklyn as she is the idea of one. Each episode is, for better or worse, dominated by Spike Lee's very distinctly old-school point of view. But Nola, played by the effervescent and stunning DeWanda Wise, has a lot of heart and genuine goodness, which makes up for her characterization in a show that sometimes feels as though it's coming from a world that young, independent black women aren’t actually living in. Despite the show's pretense of being all about empowering black women, the narrative ultimately humiliates and shames Shemekka, who decides to go through with the procedure and works out an amazing performance at the burlesque club where she works out in the only hospital she goes to. It's a good time to sit with, consider and process how we praise and how we criticize black art, and we need to believe that Nola's art, while perfectly fine, is as incendiary and groundbreaking as it's presented in the world of the show. The best of her work comes in the form of a #MyNameIsnt street campaign based on Tatyana Fazlalizadeh's 2012 “Stop Telling Women To Smile”
label: UNSAFE

text: Panama's National Assembly has nearly passed a new law revoking a controversial mining contract. The bill passed a second debate late on Wednesday and now faces a final vote Thursday in which no changes can be made. The contract would allow 20-40 more years of open pit copper mining across 13,000 hectares of forested land. Environmentalists argue continued mining would imperil drinking water and destroy more forest, but the mine is “in the middle of a jungle,” according to Minera Panama’s own contractor, Jan De Nu Group. The mine lies in Panama's share of the Mesoamerican biological corridor, an important migratory route which studies estimate contains up to 10% of all known species. It is the largest private investment in Panamanian history and already creates roughly 3% of the country”s gross domestic product, according to the country's economy ministry. The new bill not only repeals that contract but extends a moratorium on all concessions for mining activities.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Crystalline materials are made up of atoms, ions, or molecules arranged in an ordered, three-dimensional structure. They are widely used for the development of semiconductors, pharmaceuticals, photovoltaics, and catalysts. Researchers have proposed a new machine learning "binary classifier" model that can identify the presence of icosahedral quasicrystal (i-QC) phases from multiphase powder X-ray diffraction patterns. The model achieved a prediction accuracy of over 92%. It also successfully identified an unknown i-ZC phase within multiphases Al–Si–Ru alloys when used for screening 440 measured diffracted patterns from unknown materials in six different alloy systems. Notably, the proposed deep learning method has the ability to identify the i- ZC phase even when it is not the most prominent component in the mixture. Moreover, this model can be used to identify new decagonal and dodecagonal QCs and can be extended to various types of othercrystalline material.
label: SAFE

text: Denis Johnson, the author of Jesus' Son and Tree of Smoke, died on Thursday. His death was confirmed by his longtime publisher, Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Johnson was best-known for his 1992 short story collection Jesus’ Son, which was adapted into a 1999 film starring Billy Crudup. He also wrote plays, poetry collections, screenplays, journalistic works, and numerous novels. His last novel, The Laughing Monsters, came out in 2014 and received comparatively unenthusiastic reviews. It was shortlisted for the 2012 Pulitzer Prize, but the fiction prize that year went, controversially, unawarded. His distinctive, arresting style and capacity for human insight can be found in stories like “Car Crash While Hitchhiking,’ “Happy Hour,” and “Emergency.” He was a powerful inspiration to many American writers, and his reputation amongst the literati has never faded. He is survived by his wife, two daughters, a son, and a daughter-in-law. He leaves behind a wife, a daughter, two sons, and two step-daughters, all of whom he left behind when he died at the age of 67. He was also the grandfather of a son and a step-daughter, both of whom are now in their late 20s and early 30s. He will be remembered as a writer who was “at home, peaceful” at the time of his death.

text: Payment Aggregator-Cross Border (PA-CB) guidelines will help harmonise regulations across the entire payments stack. The guidelines for import-export payments, named OPGSP ( Online Payment Gateway Service Providers ), have existed for more than a decade. In 2022, draft suggestions were issued to classify these players as Online Export Import Facilitators (OEIF). Finally, they will be regulated as PA-CBs. “The new rules clarify several aspects around maintaining an escrow account, reporting requirements, permissible transactions,” said Shilpa Mankar Ahluwalia, partner, head-fintech, Shardul Amarchand Mangaldas & Co.

text: Apellis Pharmaceuticals, Inc. announced data from the GALE extension study following 3 years of continuous treatment with SYFOVRE.
