Heier, M.D., presenting author and director, retina service and director of retinal research, Ophthalmic Consultants of Boston. Approximately 92% of patients enrolled in GALE completed the first year of the study, demonstrating robust long- term treatment compliance. The safety profile of SYFO VRE in Year 3 remained consistent with previously reported data. Zero events of retina vasculitis have been observed in the SYFOvRE clinical trial program, following more than 24,000 injections to date.

text: U.N. report: Earth is speeding toward 2.5 to 2.9 degrees Celsius of global warming. Carbon emissions from the burning of coal, oil and gas rose 1.2% last year, report says. To have an even money shot at keeping warming to the 1.5-degree limit, countries have to slash emissions by 42% by the end of the decade. The chance of keeping warming at or under 1. 5 degrees is about one-in-seven or about 14%, the report says, "very, very slim indeed”"This is just like a whisper. What will be in the future will be more like a roar," says report lead author Anne Olhoff of Denmark’s climate think tank Concito. "We're simply inflating the lifeboats while we're simply breaking the rules," says another scientist who wasn’t part of the report. "None of the large emitters have changed their pledges," study co-author Niklas Hohne says.

text: Storm Babet has caused havoc across the UK, with strong winds andrough seasalong the east coast. Record breaking rainfall andriver levelsin Scotland, overtopped flood defenses, closed roads and railways and sadly at leasttwo deaths. The risk was clear well before the event. Storm Babet is anunusual weather system. Storms that hit the UK in the autumn and winter normally come from the west across the Atlantic. Babet instead traveled from Portugal, picking up moisture from the Bay of Biscay before being trapped over the UK by a hard-to-budge high pressure system across Scandinavia. This resulted in a prolonged period of wet and windy weather and widespread flooding. This is yet another reminder that the climate is changing and we will see more extreme rainfall, putting more people at risk. The previous highest 24-hour rainfall in the area was 100mm recorded in November 2022, with 60mm-70mm recorded during Storm Frank in 2015. The heaviest rainfall has been over the Angus hills in eastern Scotland, visible in white and black in the map below.

text: "Ecosystem collapse", where trees suddenly fade and die, could happen within 50 years. 42 experts said if we act now we can avert the catastrophe. Large-scale loss of forests hit by "wind, fire, pests and disease" has already happened in continental Europe and North America. "A collapsed forest would be heart-breaking, devoid of its essential life and all the joy and benefits it gives to humanity," said Dr Eleanor Tew of Forestry England and Cambridge University. The UK is one of the least forested countries in Europe. Its remaining woodlands face many challenges including climate change, biodiversity loss, invasive species, damage from deer and grey squirrels. There is also a skills shortage in the forestry sector, jeopardising the ability to deliver government tree planting targets. Solutions include planting forests made-up of a range of different species that are better for wildlife and more resilient to pressures such as flood, drought and disease. text: The Cleveland Indians will stop using their Chief Wahoo logo on game jerseys and caps starting in 2019. The decision has the support of the MLB, which has urged the team to decrease its use of the logo. The long-simmering issue escalated in the fall of 2016 during the American League Championship Series between the Toronto Blue Jays and the Indians. The Change the Mascot campaign welcomed the Indians’ decision as a recognition “that Native Americans do not deserve to be denigrated as cartoon mascots” The group used the news to once again revive calls for the Washington football team to take similar action. “For too long, people of color have been stereotyped with these kinds of hurtful symbols, and no symbol is more hurtful than the football team in the nation’s capital using a dictionary-defined racial slur as its team name,” Oneida Nation Representative Ray Halbritter said in an emailed statement. The NFL team didn’t respond to a request for comment on the Indians' decision. The ban extends only to on-field displays, meaning the logo will still be a fixture on merchandise that’ll still be available throughout northern Ohio. The league awarded the 2019 All-Star Game to the Indians in April 2017, and in related meetings pressured the team “transition away from the Chief W Yahoo logo,’ a spokesman said. The team has indicated the team would be receptive to a future change in the future.

text: Van Gogh spent a year in a mental hospital after cutting his ear in a fight with his friend, Paul Gauguin. Art Therapy wasn't even practiced widely at the time and it wasn't until 1942 that a British artist by the name of Adrian Hill coined the term art therapy. Today, says art therapist and research psychologist, Cathy Malchiodi, PhD, "Art therapy is a pretty close match to many other non-therapy approaches, mainly in the realm of art teaching" It's indispensable, and in a way, being a human being--no matter how wonderful your upbringing--can benefit from such therapy or even the practice of art in all its forms. It's a mental health profession in which clients, facilitated by the art therapist, use art media, the creative process, and the resulting artwork to explore their feelings, reconcile emotional conflicts, foster self awareness, manage behavior and addictions, develop social skills, improve reality orientation, reduce anxiety, and increase self esteem. "Art psychotherapy (however) embraces the idea that art is a means of symbolic communication and expresses personality, emotions and other aspects of human experience," says the Association for Art Therapists, representing over 5, 000 individuals professionals in the field. The discipline continued to grow from there becoming an important tool for assessment, communication, and treatment of children and adults alike.

text: October 2023 was the wettest month on record in County Armagh, breaking the previous record set in 1870. Armagh Observatory, one of dozens of weather stations around Northern Ireland has recorded daily rainfall at its meteorological station since 1838. It recorded a total of 195.4mm rainfall in October, exceeding the 193.8mm observed 153 years ago. Last month also had the warmest October day for 97 years, with a temperature of 21.7C. Its director Prof Michael Burton said the data sent a clear signal. "There's no doubt in the pattern we're all seeing - these are all evidence of the world's changing climate," he said. It comes as communities in counties Down, Armagh and Antrim start to assess the damage after flooding this week. But they are also a signal that time to mitigate the impact of climate change is running out. The Met Office has also said county Down had its wetest October ever. But Professor Burton said no single measurement should have too much read into it, he explained that a warmer atmosphere does hold more water.

text: Antarctica is losing ice at an increasing pace, but the loss of sea ice may lead to more snowfall over the ice sheets. Penn State scientists analyzed the impacts of decreased sea ice in the Amundsen Sea in West Antarctica. The researchers identified a feedback loop between sea ice and atmospheric water vapor. A more ice-free ocean surface intensifies evaporation, contributing to increased atmospheric water Vapor. This enhanced moisture causes a locally amplified greenhouse effect, resulting in heightened downward longwave radiation, which subsequently reduces sea ice the next month, the researchers said. The team's findings emphasize the need for refining current climate models to enhance their predictive accuracy, the scientists said.. Increasedsnowfallin Antarctica might slow the sea level rise, but it's essential to recognize that the ice sheet will continue to contribute to rising sea levels, they said. In 2022, we witnessed a new record low, and this year's levels are even lower, significantly below previous observations. These recent rapid changes in Antarctic sea ice highlight the urgency of understanding their causes and their potential impact on the Antarctic ice sheet.

text: 2023 is now "virtually certain" that it will be the hottest year on record. No major climate science body expected this at the start of the year. However, a group of leading climate scientists recently warned that the climate may change more quickly than expected in the future. They suggest that the world hasn't yet tipped into a new phase of runaway climate change, but that it is likely to get worse in the coming decades. The Club of Rome group says climate models suggest the climate is changing faster than expected and that this could be a major contributor to climate change in the near future. text: Witnesses in the Khakassia region of Russia reported seeing a bright meteor. NASA's Near-Earth Object office manager said the meteor could have been a tiny asteroid. "It wasn’t as light as day, but still quite bright,” witness Olga Sagalakova said. “Frankly, I was scared. I thought that it was a bomb,’ she told RT, an English-language news outlet funded by the Russian government. "Something like this probably happens every day or two," NASA's Paul Chodas said. "Just not necessarily over populated areas," he added. "There were no reports of a shockwave," he said, "which tells me it was not a large meteor like ChelyABinsk’s” The meteor may have been 10 to 15 meters in size, he added, and may have hit the atmosphere over a populated area of the Russian city of Sayanogorsk in the early hours of Tuesday morning. The event was captured on video by a resident of the city, who posted it on social media to Twitter. The meteor was not visible to the naked eye, but it was visible to those with binoculars, which are usually used to see meteors and other celestial objects.

text: Temperatures in many areas are expected to fall below the seasonal average. We will see daytime highs in single digits for most, with night-time frosts. The UK's lowest November temperatures on record came on 14 November 1919, when Braemar in Aberdeenshire saw a daytime high of -11.1°C, and a bone-chilling overnight low of -23.3°C. While it will be cold enough for some places to see some of the white stuff, snow lovers in most parts of the UK are likely to be disappointed. Most forecasts suggest the chilly weather will stick around for a while next week, but with only limited amounts of rain or snow. Some models suggest low pressure systems might try to spread from the west by the start of December, which would mean a return of something milder and wetter. It would only take a shot of cold air at the right time to bring a flake - or more - of snow on Christmas Day.

text: NASA has released a new set of maps showing the locations of subsurface ice on Mars. There is plenty of ice on the surface around the planet’s poles, but most mission concepts are more focused on the equatorial region. The new maps use high-resolution cameras on the orbiting Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter mission to look at regions where meteoroids had struck the planet and created impact craters that revealed the ice beneath. As well as being vital for future crewed missions, the presence of ice is relevant to the search for potential ancient life on the planet too. In the harsh environment of the Martian surface, ice can act as a radiation shield. Biosignatures of past life in many ways are more susceptible to ionizing radiation damage than actual living organisms. So ice could preserve signatures of ancient life. If you can melt ice you have water of course, which is believed to be essential to life. So, in the very big picture, our maps will be of interest to exobiology studies.”

There is definitely a heightened awareness around head injuries in football, and there are mandatory protocols now at every level of the game, says John Sutter. There are no fewer than 29 medical professionals at each game, at least one of whom is assigned to one of the team’s trainers, they can review video and see if signs of head trauma are present. text: The massive blue and yellow mural appeared overnight in Dover, England on Sunday. The site is near a major ferry terminal that connects the U.K. with mainland Europe. The painting comes nearly a year after the United Kingdom voted to leave the EU, in a vote commonly known as “Brexit.” It also appeared the same day that France held its presidential elections. Far-right contender Marine Le Pen, who lost to independent moderate Emmanuel Macron, had promised to seek a similar exit from the EU if elected. It appeared the day that British Prime Minister Theresa May began the process of formally withdrawing the EU from the UK. The number of stars has nothing to do with the number of member countries, though the circle is a symbol of unity,.” the EU’S website states. “The number ofStars has nothing. to do. with thenumber of member states, thoughthe circle is. a symbols of unity.’ A post shared by Banksy (@banksy) on May 7, 2017 at 6:40am PDT on May 6, 2017 of a painting by the elusive British street artist, whose identity is not publicly known. text: Travelers are finding ‘any excuse’ for a getaway with family and friends, according to Expedia Group’s survey. ‘Tour tourism’ will continue to thrive in 2024, with over 40% of survey respondents saying they’d travel for a concert as an excuse to visit a new place. Low or alcohol-free lifestyles are on the rise, helped out with movements like dry January and sober October. The travel industry looks set to cater more to sober-curious visitors by stocking minibars with zero-proof options or offering mocktail-making experiences. The ‘generation of generative AI’ travelers will come of age and fully embrace this tech in 2024. Nearly 40% say they would use this tech to find the perfect stay, 35% would plan activities and things to do, 33% would compare flight options, and 1 in 3 would change their travel plans or cancel their plans. The list of 2024 trends would be complete without a mention of Artificial Intelligence.

text: The U.S. removed the Chinese Ministry of Public Security's Institute of Forensic Science (IFS) from a trade sanctions list. The decision comes as President Joe Biden's administration is negotiating with China to resume bilateral cooperation. "The continued listing of the IFS on the Commerce Entity List was a barrier to achieving cooperation on stopping the trafficking of precursor chemicals," a State Department spokesperson said. Human rights advocates expressed concern that Washington's decision to remove the Chinese institute from the trade sanction list raises questions about the U.N.'s commitment to addressing China's human rights practices. "It's crucial to emphasize that the ongoing genocide against the Uyghurs is a matter of bipartisan concern, as well," Rayhan Asat, a UYghur human rights lawyer, told VOA on Thursday. "We have to make tough decisions in this administration" to secure the cooperation with China on fentanyl trafficking, Miller told Voa, adding that fentanyl is the leading cause of death of Americans aged 18 to 49.

text: Orange juice futures hit an all-time high of $4.17 per pound on Halloween. Cocoa futures set a 45-year high this week as supply falls in Ghana and the Ivory Coast. Crude oil futures fell to their lowest levels since July on worries about fallingdemand. Wheat futures soared last year after Russia invaded Ukraine, stoking supply fears, but prices are still falling. and supply is affecting demand, which is the focus of economic weakness in China and elsewhere, analyst David Morrison says. and traders are anxiously awaiting new inflation data from China, expected on Thursday, he adds. and it’s not just cocoa prices that are sending the confectionary industry reeling; sugar futures have risen by more than 30% this year as sugarcane crops in Southeast Asia also dry up. and the Middle East conflict threatens to further constrain the supply of oil, Morrison says, but that doesn’t necessarily mean that consumer prices are changing at this point. and prices are falling.

text: Tokelau is a small Pacific nation with a population of about 1500 people. A Dutch internet entrepreneur offered to manage their country code. Users could register a free domain name for a year, in exchange for having advertisements hosted on their websites. Scammers began using .tk websites to do everything from harvesting passwords and payment information to displaying pop-up ads or delivering malware. At its peak, .tk domains had some 25 million users — massively eclipsing the nation's own population. It has now become the go-to internet domain safe-harbor for spammers, phishing, and other cyber criminal activities. But thanks to the rise in AI techbro investments, Anguilla is expected to bring in some $30 million in revenue this year from domain names alone. Sure, that's a pittance compared to the overall investment in AI around the globe. But not an insignificant chunk of change for a country that's otherwise dependent on tourism andoff-shore tax havens. It's a fascinating — if ultimately rather depressing — look at internet domains as a form of colonialism.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Jami Cantor, a former wardrobe stylist at the NFL Network, filed a lawsuit on Monday. She accused Marshall Faulk, Donovan McNabb, Eric Davis and Warren Sapp of sexual harassment and abuse. The NFL Network suspended Faulk and fellow analysts Heath Evans and Ike Taylor after the allegations surfaced. The suit alleges another man, former NFL Network executive Eric Weinberger, groped her and pushed his genitals against her. Cantor asserts that she was wrongfully terminated by theNFL Network, where she worked 10 years until her dismissal for allegedly stealing in 2016. She said she complained about the working conditions to no avail and was replaced by a woman 21 years younger than her. She was originally filed her suit in October, but it was amended on Monday in response to the allegations against the ex-football stars, which were detailed in an amended lawsuit filed in Los Angeles on Monday by Jami Cantor. She is seeking unspecified damages and unspecified attorney's fees, according to the amended suit, which was filed in connection with the sexual misconduct allegations. It is unclear whether Cantor will be able to collect any of her damages. The lawsuit was filed by attorney Laura Horton, who also represents former NFL Hall of Fame player Warren Sapp, who was fired from the network in 2015 for allegedly soliciting a prostitute. Sapp was never charged with a crime, and charges against him were later dropped. He is in the Pro Football Hall of Famer's company, The Ringer, which has been suspended by ESPN, the network's current employer.

text: "gerontocracy" is a government ruled by people significantly older than the adult population. With a median age of 65, today's Senate is now the oldest it has ever been. Florida Democratic Congressman Maxwell Frost, became the youngest member of Congress - and its first Gen-Z member - when he was elected this year at the age of 25. Some younger people have found success at a local level. New Hampshire has a small population but the largest state legislative body in the country, and Valerie McDonnell, a Republican, was elected aged 18, making her the country's youngest state legislator. She said she doesn't want her age to be a focus, but she does see it as an asset. A Pew Research study found 79% of Americans want age limits for federal officials and generational change. "We are simply seeing the decades downstream consequence of that, amplified by specific historical events and American political institutions," said Professor Kevin Munger, author of Generation Gap: Why the Baby Boomers Still Dominate American Politics and Culture.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Last month, Islamabad ordered 1.7 million undocumented Afghan refugees and migrants to leave the South Asian country. Over 300,000 Afghans, many with only the clothes on their back, have returned to their homeland since then. Pakistan said its decision was in response to the Taliban's refusal to expel the Tehrik-e Taliban Pakistan (TTP) extremist group. Islamabad has accused the Taliban of sheltering the TTP, which is waging a deadly insurgency against Pakistan. The sides appear to be on a collision course, with little indication that they can smooth over their growing differences. The continued mass expulsions of Afghans by Pakistan are likely to worsen the devastating humanitarian crisis in Afghanistan, the world's largest. The Islamic State-Khorasan (IS-K) extremist groups claimed responsibility for the latest attack on Afghanistan's Shi'ite Hazara minority. The Taliban has pledged to protect Afghanistan's religious minorities, but the Shi'ites accuse the group of failing to prevent deadly attacks on Hazara.
label: UNSAFE

text: The top-seeded Boston Celtics find themselves in a precarious position. It’s down two games to zero against a Chicago team that barely made the NBA Playoffs. The blame has predictably shifted onto its boy-wonder coach, Brad Stevens. But the sentiment is unfair, says columnist John D. Sutter. The Celtics at their core have a flawed roster, and one that has easily been exposed, Sutter says. The only “fair’ criticism should be aimed at the entire roster, he says. and don’t forget that he is sitting on a gold-swap pick with the Nets in June’S draft, plus the Nets’ first-round selection in the 2018 draft, he adds. The opportunity to land a top 10 player in his prime doesn't come along often, and when it does, it's often too late, he writes. and it's not worth the risk of losing a player like Paul George or Dwyane Wade, who are in their 20s and 30s, and could be worth $100 million or more in the long run, he argues. The Boston Celtics are down 2-0 against the Chicago Bulls in the NBA playoffs. The series is tied at 1-1, and the Celtics have a chance to win the series on Wednesday night in Chicago. and Thursday night in Boston, if they win the next two games in Chicago, they’ll advance to the NBA Finals for the first time since 2004.
label: SAFE

text: UC Riverside researchers have created a hydro-economic model. It can illuminate the future impacts of major water use changes. UCR's School of Public Policy has published a working paperdescribing the framework of the model. The model is expected to be publicly available online early next year. It was developed by UCR postdoctoral scholar Daniel Crespo, assistant professor Mehdi Nemati, and distinguished professor Ariel Dinar, in collaboration with Zach Frankel and Nick Halberg of the Utah Rivers Council. The 1922 high flow level has occurred during less than 40% of the years since and in only one year since 2000, the authors say. The authors of the working paper are now seeking input from irrigation and urban water managers, as well as various other stakeholders. It will allow for consideration of "out of the box solutions that right now many stakeholders don't even want to mention," Dinar says. "A model like what we developed will allow us to check different options under different scenarios of climate change, and there may be some very reasonable solutions"
label: SAFE

text: The Tamil Nadu Assembly re-adopted 10 Bills covering different departments, including law, agriculture and higher education. The Opposition parties AIADMK and BJP staged separate walk-outs. The Bills in question refer to two bills each that were adopted by the House in 2020 and 2023 and six others that were passed last year. The government is looking into the legality of transferring unclaimed funds of the Sahara-Sebi Refund Account to the Consolidated Fund of India. Apple is targeting production of nearly ₹1 lakh crore worth of iPhones in India this fiscal ending March 2024. The estranged wife of Gautam Singhania has sought three quarters of the industrialist’s net worth, reported at $1.4 billion, for their two daughters and herself, as part of a family settlement following the couple's separation. The Indian stock market is set to hit fresh 52-week high on Monday, with the BSE Sensex and the Nifty 50 both up over 1%.
label: UNSAFE

text: Yoko Ono was officially credited as a co-writer of the 1971 song “Imagine.” The news was announced Wednesday at a meeting of the National Music Publishers Association. Ono, who uses a wheelchair, welled up with tears upon hearing the announcement. She said her waning health has heightened her appreciation of the song and imbued her with a magnified esteem for being alive. The song was also awarded the Centennial Song award at the meeting. It was originally attributed to Ono's deceased husband, John Lennon, but now Ono has been credited as the co-creator of the hit. The National Music publishers Association is celebrating its 50th anniversary this year with a gala in New York City on June 14. The event is also being held in honor of the 100th anniversary of The Beatles' Farewell To The Beatles album, which was released in 1971. The concert will be held at New York’s Madison Square Garden on June 15. The performance will be followed by a concert at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in NYC on June 16. For more information, go to www.nmpa.org/celebrations/farewell-to-the-lennon-and-thelennons-farewell-fearful-love-of-all-time-favourite-song-further-than-ever-before-in-a-golden-era-tribute-to the-greatest-friend.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Floyd Mayweather defeated Conor McGregor in the 10th round on Saturday. The fight was the most hyped boxing match of the year. The two fighters hugged after Mayweather secured his win. See some of the most brutal moments from the Mayweather-McGregor fight in the photos below. Click through the gallery to see the best photos from the fight. Click here to see more boxing photos from Mayweather-Conor McGregor. The match was held at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas, Nevada. The bout took place in front of a crowd of more than 100,000 people. It was the first time Mayweather and McGregor have faced off against each other in a boxing match. The win kept Mayweather's perfect record in mint condition at 50-0 in the ring. He has never lost to a fighter who is not a professional boxer or a UFC champion in his career. The last time he lost was to George Groves in 2010 in a fight that was televised on Showtime in the U.S. in the middle of the night. He lost to Groves by a technical knockout in the ninth round in a bout that was dubbed “The Thrill of the Knockout.” Click here for more boxing pictures from the Floyd Mayweather vs. Conor McGregor fight. The rematch will take place at the Staples Center in Los Angeles on October 26. The winner will be crowned the new WBC welterweight champion of the world in a rematch with Manny Pacquiao on October 27. The loser will be the WBC middleweight champion.

text: Zappfresh has raised $4.3 million in a funding round led by social impact focused fund Heifer Impact Capital. The round also saw participation from publisher Hindustan Media Ventures, venture firm Ah! Ventures, and Unity SFB. The funds raised will be used to diversify the firm’s offerings, adding segments like premium country meat, as well as to add more distribution prowess. Zappfresh is one of the few profitable companies in the online meat ecosystem, having reported a profit of Rs 3.5 crore in FY23, on a revenue of Rs 70 crore. The Delhi NCR-based firm had raised $2.2 million at a $22.9 million valuation in 2019, as per data from Tracxn. In July, it had acquired Bengaluru-based Dr. Meat at a reported deal value of $3 million. The firm is now looking to expand to two new cities over the next 12 months, says CEO Deepanshu Manchanda.
label: SAFE

The memoir describes both struggles and triumphs, showing that mental health challenges can be managed successfully. The book is being used in some psychology courses to provide patient perspectives. text: Tarot cards have been used for centuries to help individuals process past events and look toward their future. Tarot readers explain imagery and meaning to advise a client on his or her path. A tarot deck is made up of the Minor Arcana and the Major Arcana cards. The meaning and spirituality that underlie the cards allow for a shift in perspective, one that could leave a tarot subject feeling better or more certain about future events than he did before.“A so-called irrational approach to problem-solving, tarot seems to make sense in a world that feels increasingly irrational and surreal,” Catherine Bowman, a poet and professor of creative writing at Indiana University, said in an email to CNN.com. “No one has the ability to see your entire future. A reader can see what may be coming based on your current circumstances, but you can shift gears at any time,’” Mary Evans, of Spirit Speak Tarot, said over an email, “I think many people had a difficult 2016 and the election was a big cherry on the top’s of Spirit Spirit.” “So I have noticed a particularness, unsettledness, and desire to be grounded from an anxiousness, from a particular year,“ Mary Evans said. � “The Tarot Lady” reported that as a Tarot reader, she was typically “swamped from October through March, regardless of whether it was the election or the weather.’
label: SENSITIVE

text: Space Force unveils its first official painting. The painting shows a U.S. spaceplane intercepting an "adversary" satellite. The Space Force has its own plane, Boeing X-37, which spent two and a half years orbiting Earth on a secret mission. The primary goal of the Space Force is to protect the interests of the U.s. in space, which means it manages space launches, tracks objects in orbit, and maintains Global Positioning Satellites and various weather and communications satellites. The military branch has tried its best to communicate its mission to the public, but we’re not entirely sure the military branch fully understands what it does, or has effectively conveyed its mission and responsibilities to thepublic. It’s an almost child-like, sci-fi fantasy depiction of a space force, standing up to evil satellites and protecting the weak, feeble orbits of others. It may not be the best strategy, however, as space is the next frontier for battling national interests between different countries.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Local authorities have opened 33 emergency shelters across the region. The Red Cross has deployed disaster response teams. Residents are urged to follow evacuation routes and seek shelter immediately. Emergency hotlines are available 24/7 for assistance. The National Hurricane Center reports sustained winds of 135 mph as the storm approaches the coastline. The storm is expected to strengthen to a Category 5 storm by Friday. The hurricane is expected not to make landfall until after Friday night, the National Weather Service says. It is currently a Category 4 storm with winds of up to 135 mph. The Hurricane Center is not predicting a direct hit on the US mainland or Puerto Rico, but says the storm is moving towards the east coast of the island and could make landfall in the next few days. The U.S. Coast Guard is on the scene and is monitoring the situation closely for any changes in the weather. The American Red Cross is also on the ground in Puerto Rico and has deployed a disaster response team to help with relief efforts in the event of a direct impact on the coast. The agency has also opened emergency hotlines for assistance in the case of a power outage or storm surge. It has opened emergency shelters in the region and is working with local authorities to open additional shelters if necessary. For confidential support, call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or click here for details. For support in the UK, visit the Samaritan’s website. For help in the U.K., call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Goethe Institut hosted an event Thursday, March 26, "Truth is Concrete" Rev. Bill Talen, Savitri D, Taja Cheek, Noah Fischer, Gregory Sholette, and Raquel de Anda were on the panel. Talen: "We kill the people who hear the Earth, we murder them" Fischer: "Existential debts could prove to be a mechanism for solidarity" for those who are saddled with debt for life, or lose to lose to strike or lose their jobs. The panel discussed the need for "creative resistance" to forces such as extractive industries -- oil and gas, among many others -- and the machine in general, pointing to the successes and shortcomings of the #Occupy and #BlackLivesMatter movements as touchstones for what art-activism can and should do. The event ended with a call to action led by a popular reverend, who made a name for himself and the social justice movement by leading the Stop Shopping Choir to fight a machine whose operating system Talen deconstructed. by Florian Malzacher, whose new book Truth Is Concrete: A Handbook for Artistic Strategies in Real Politics explores various ways of merging the symbiotically connected need for art in activism and activism in art, the event was held at the Goethe Institute. The group discussed the difficulty for artists to collaborate on principle of solidarity in the face of "neoliberal capitalism," and expanded on what he meant by "existential debt"
label: SENSITIVE

text: Former Super Falcons captain, Desire Oparanozie, retired from football recently. She talks about her most memorable moment playing for Nigeria, plans on retirement, her best World Cup outing and more, in this interview with EBENEZER BAJELAY. Your retirement came as a big surprise with many saying you left the game too early. Do you agree?I understand their concern because there is this trend that your have to play football till the body is tired and you are no longer able to play. I want to dedicate my time in life to other things rather than stay on the pitch for a very long time. The 2019 World Cup was the best because firstly I was the captain of the team and secondly the drama we had to go through to qualify for the round of 16. It was so tiring but also the best. I have always been an advocate of women’s football, the right of women in sports generally and I am still going to lend my voice in any capacity that I can and do whatever I need to do.
label: SAFE

text: The 16th National Investor Education Week (NIEW) was held at the Exchange, 40 Harbour Street, Kingston, October 14 - 20, 2023. NIEW is a planned week of activities designed to assist the public by raising awareness about the importance of investor education and protection covered by securities regulations. The week was successful with the JSE reaching over 3,000 participants during the week. The details of each event are as shown below: Church Service. National Youth Forum. 'She Leads' Women's Conference. Open House. Primary/Preparatory School Stock Market Education Programme. The goal of the programme is to promote financial Literacy in schools by educating students on the value of investing in the stock market. The Primary/preparatory schools' market participants gathered at the exchange for the launch of the primary school Stock Market Game. The event was opened by our Managing Director Dr. Marlene Street and gave her full endorsement and support of the full Financial Literacy Programme at an early age.
label: SAFE

text: Mark Cuban has entered into an agreement to sell a majority stake in the NBA franchise to the family that runs the Las Vegas Sands casino company. The deal could be completed in the coming weeks. The agreement would be in the valuation range of $3.5 billion, according to a person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because that detail was not being made public. Cuban would retain control ofbasketballoperations in the deal. The company controlled by Miriam Adelson, widow of casino magnate Sheldon Adelson,. announced earlier Tuesday it was selling $2 billion of her shares to buy an unspecified professional sports team. It revealed Wednesday that the team was the Mavericks. The 65-year-old Cuban, who just announced he was leaving the popular business TV program ‘Shark Tank’ after a 16th season next year, rose to fame quickly after buying the Mavericks in 2000. Cuban said almost a year ago he was interested in partnering with Sands. He has been a proponent of legalizing gambling in Texas, an issue that didn't make it out of the state Legislature in a biennial session that ended earlier this year.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Four colonies of emperor penguins in Antarctica moved from sea ice to floating ice shelves. The penguins had to climb 30 meters (nearly 100 feet) to find safer breeding sites. The behavior was observed via satellite and probably would not have been noticed without that eye in the sky. The researchers say the fact that the penguins moved means they "may be capable of adapting their behavior" to fit a newly warming world."These new findings are an important step forward in helping us understand what the future may hold for these animals," one co-author of the study said. "It is likely that there are other nuances of the emperor penguin environment that will be detected sooner through their behavior than by more conventional means of measuring environmental changes," another co- author said of the penguin behavior. "We have yet to discover whether or not other species may also be adapting to changing environmental conditions," the study's other co-authors said. 'We cannot assume that this behavior is widespread in other penguin populations,' one of the authors of the report added. 'The ability of these four colonies to relocate to a different environment, in order to cope with local circumstances, was totally unexpected,' said the other, Barbara Wienecke of the Australian Antarctic Division of the British Antarctic Survey (BAS). 'The behavior is likely to be more common in the future,' the researchers said of other penguins, "but we cannot assume it is widespread" of other species. 'This is a very difficult maneuver," said lead researcher Peter Fretwell.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Pluto’s heart-shaped region is actually a whole lot of ice sitting at the bottom of a basin almost 2 miles deep. The basin trapped nitrogen, carbon monoxide and methane over the past 50,000 years. Scientists predict that atmospheric pressure is currently at its seasonal peak and will decrease in the next decades. That change could cause the heart-like feature on Pluto to act like a real heart.. The half-heart glacier lying inside is a really massive glacier, which is not impacted by the seasonal changes. It probably formed when the basin formed, and will remain there in the future,” Tanguy Bertrand told Gizmodo. “However, it probably flows and retracts over a few hundreds of kilometers (like a heart beating) with time, eroding and shaping the mountains surrounding it.’’ The Tombaugh Regio, which was named for astronomer Clyde Tombaugh, who discovered Pluto in 1930, is located in the Tombaugh region of the dwarf planet. It is home to the New Horizons spacecraft, which landed on Pluto on July 14, 2015. The mission is scheduled to return to Earth in 2018 and is expected to take three more years to complete its mission to the dwarf world. The New Horizons team is currently preparing to land on the surface of Pluto on August 21, 2018. It will then begin a two-year mission to orbit the planet and return to the surface in 2023 and 2028, respectively.
label: SAFE

text: We've been reporting on individual actions that can make a positive impact. Some require a little planning, while others might mean one less thing on your weekend to do. We've broken them down by indoor, outdoor and on-the-go actions to help you find what's right for you at this moment. Stay cool without an air conditioner. Upgrade your gas furnace to a heat pump. Save money on your utilities. Keep your home safe from smoke. And watch out for single-use items like coffee pods that produce the greenhouse gases to produce the individual-serving packaging that we eat in our homes. and on the go. And don't throw away what you throw away (wilted basil can become pesto; scraps can become composted); and don't eat meat that creates methane (a significant driver of global climate change). As WBUR reported: One study found swapping out beef with almost anything else for anything else can cut a person's dietary carbon footprint by almost 48%.
label: SENSITIVE

text: NHL analyst Mike Milbury referred to one hockey player's domestic abuse conviction as an “unfortunate incident,” as he offered commentary for NBC’s coverage. Slava Voynov was previously an Los Angeles Kings player until he was indefinitely suspended in 2014 following an arrest for domestic violence. After his wife accused him of choking, hitting and pushing her into a television, he pleaded no contest on a misdemeanor charge of corporal injury to a spouse. Milbury later defended his comment, arguing he was merely providing context for Voynov”s suspension. “As I said at the time when he was suspended, the league made the right call, 100 percent,’ Milbury said. Several of Voynov's OAR teammates have argued he “deserves to be” at the Olympics this year, according to local Florida television station WFLA. "I know that he's a good player and obviously he deserves to be here," Mikhail Grigorenko said Tuesday. "He's one of our leaders on defense, so I'm not surprised he's here. The around-hockey stuff, there's people that decide that," he added. "Don’t tell me that NBC doesn't talk about athletes’ personal lives!! pic.twitter.com/IPeUf0OoooOf," Milbury wrote on Twitter. "The NBCSN broadcast of the US hockey game just talked about that Russian player Voinov was recently being charged with domestic violence"
label: UNSAFE

text: The Port Terminal Multipurpose Limited, Lagos, said it will receive the largest container-Roll-On- roll-Off ship ever to visit the sub-region on November 27. In a statement on Sunday, the terminal operator said that the ship named MV Great Lagos is owned by the Grimaldi Group. The ship, according to the statement, can transport 4.7 kilometres of rolling freight, 2,500 car equivalent units, and 2,000 twenty-foot equivalent units. The Managing Director of PTML, Mr Ascanio Russo, said the visit was a landmark event for Nigeria’s maritime sector and PTML. He added that the terminal invested over $20m to receive the ship, saying “By extending its Berth 11, equipping it with deeper berths, expanded storage areas, and acquired state-of-the-art cargo handling equipment.” The ship was launched in April, stretching 250 meters in length with a beam of 38 meters and a weight of over 45,000 tonnes.
label: SAFE

text: Rep. Lacy Clay (D-Mo.) returned the controversial student painting depicting cops as pigs to its original location. Rep. Duncan D. Hunter (R-Calif.) is “pressuring GOP leaders to permanently remove the painting,” The Washington Examiner reports. A GOP congressman removed a student painting, without warning or permission, from the walls of the U.S. Capitol complex on Friday, Jan. 6. The image shows a policeman with the head of a boar aiming a gun at a protestor with theHead of a wolf. In the background, protestors hold signs reading “Stop Kill—,’ “History” and “Racism Kills” On the right, a black man in a graduation cap appears crucified and holding the scales of justice. The controversial artwork, made by recent high school graduate David Pulphus, was selected by a committee of artists as part of the annual Congressional Art Competition in May. The piece responded to the civil unrest brewing in Ferguson, where the competition was held, following the fatal shooting of Michael Brown by a white police officer. It is currently hanging in what Marcos described as “a highly trafficked tunnel connecting the Capitol and two House office buildings.” Clay rehung the work on Tuesday, surrounded by members of the Congressional Black Caucus, explaining to press, “This is really not about a student art competition anymore. This is about protecting the Constitution. The Capitol Police are behind me”
label: UNSAFE

text: City leaders agreed Monday night to purchase the property for $2 million. On June 12, 2016, Omar Mateen opened fire in the gay nightclub, killing 49. At the time, it was the worst mass shooting in modern U.S. history. A SWAT team killed Mateen, who had pledged allegiance to the Islamic State group, following a standoff.. The nonprofit onePulse Foundation announced earlier this year that it was scaling back plans for a $100 million memorial following fundraising challenges. The building still stands, surrounded by a temporary display that honors the victims. and more than 850 were injured among a crowd of 22,000 at a country music festival in Las Vegas the following year. The city of Orlando is moving forward with plans to create a memorial on the property of thePulse nightclub, where 49 people were massacred seven years ago. The memorial is expected to be open to the public by the end of the year. It will be located on the same site as the Pulse nightclub.
label: UNSAFE

text: Suryakumar Yadav 's first press conference as captain saw just two journalists in attendance. text: Vivek Ramaswamy, a tech entrepreneur and political novice, impromptu performed Eminem's famous 2002 song "Lose Yourself" during a campaign stop during the Iowa State Fair. Eminem sent a cease-and-desist letter to Ramas wamy's lawyer on August 23, 2023. When RamasWamy learned about the letter, he appeared to mock the Grammy winner, 50, on his X page (formerly known as Twitter). Many politicians have received similar cease- and-desists orders for their campaign song choices in previous election cycles. The entrepreneur also vocalized the lyrics in 2006, while attending his senior year at Harvard University, this time as the alter ego "Da Vek" The initial public offering (IPO) market is red hot, with five issues worth ₹7,400 crore opening for subscription this week.

text: Bob Comis: I cannot think of one sound ethical argument in favor of slaughtering animals for their meat. Comis says he lives an unethical life shrouded in the justificatory trappings of social acceptance. "What I do is wrong, in spite of its acceptance by nearly 95 percent of the American population," he says. "I know it in my bones -- even if I cannot yet act on it. Someday, certainly not any time soon, perhaps centuries from now, we will know this and accept this as well and as much as we know and accept the evil of slavery," says Comis, who lives on a pig farm in New Hampshire. "Until that day, I am and will remain a paragon of animal welfare," Comis adds, "but again, what I am doing, what we are doing, is wrong -- even terribly so" "I truly believe I suffer their death more than they," he writes, "and we need to become the sort of beings who don't weave dark, damning shrouds to sustain, with acceptance and celebration, the grossly unethical" "It might take incalculable generations of being hooked by and grappling with the ethics of slaughter to get there," he adds, 'but we really do need to get to the bottom of what we're doing" "We have an obligation to eat otherwise," he concludes, "even if we can't see it at the moment. Do so, please. See through the false legitimacy of the bucolic alternative to factory farming"
label: SENSITIVE

text: Owen Pallenberg, 14, wrote a poem about the wage gap in America. Women are paid on average 79 cents on the dollar for doing the same job as a man. Women with doctoral degrees are paid less than men with master’s degrees. The racial wage gap has not changed in thirty five years. Minimum wage in California is $10.50 for a man, More like $8.92 for a woman. The gap just gets worse for married women, women of color, and even mothers, Ridiculous, I know. Shouldn’t we all get paid the same as one another? Once men and women are equal, we will finally reach our ultimate goal. Just take a look at the US Women’S National Soccer Team, They earn about 25% of what the men make, which is really quite extreme, Even though the women generate more revenue and won the World Cup, They get paid much less to lace them up.” “I decided to write about the issue of the gender and race Wage Gap in our country because it is a very serious problem that has been recently overlooked due to the issues with President Trump, Syria, Health Care, and in honor of Mother’ s Day and the first annual 50/50 day.’ “79 Cents” by Owen Pallenberg: A woman makes on average79 cents to the man’�s buck, So the woman makes less because of her chromosomes’ luck.

text: Carolyn Kramer worked as a modeling agent in New York City in the 1980s, ’90s and early 2000s. She said she knew about rampant sexual misconduct in her industry, but didn't protect her models. Now, amid the domino-like fall of so many high-profile alleged sexual offenders, the 58-year-old can’t stop thinking about how she and other agents sent girls, some as young as 13, to modeling gigs with photographers who were rumored to be sexual predators. “I think the agencies have massive culpability because they don't necessarily care about anything other than who gets the booking,” the former agent said. It’s true that sexual assault allegations made against fashion photographer Terry Richardson date back to 2001, and that he was only officially dropped by top magazines and brands in October 2017, Kramer said. But insiders claim there is a long list of predators who still thrive in a largely unregulated profession that combines big egos, drugs and young male egos. Weber has denied these claims, and while at least 18 current and former models recently accused photographer Bruce Weber of sexual harassment, he has denied any non-consensual behavior. The #MeToo revolution continues to spark a national dialogue on sexual misconduct, and Kramer wants to expose exactly how the very modeling agencies she worked for enabled predators, a disturbing reality that she believes still exists today. She has a self-described “big personality” and speaks bluntly with a slight New York accent.
label: UNSAFE

Twenty-five percent off if you got fired that day.” For all non-White House employees, tickets for D.D. shows are available here. The musical is set to open on Broadway in the spring of 2015. It will be directed by Tony Award-nominee Nell Benjamin and written by Jeff Richmond and Jeff Richmond, with Fey's husband Jeff Richmond serving as the musical director. The cast is described as a bunch of “Baby Timberlakes,” which seems like an appropriately dated metaphor given the subject matter of the show, but it's still a first-rate group of actors. It's scheduled to open in Washington on October 31 and run until December 3, with tickets going on sale in the U.S. on October 30 and October 31 in the UK on October 29. text: Sarah Chen is facing serious sexual assault allegations from 12 women. Law enforcement has opened a criminal investigation, and the league has placed her on administrative leave. The accusations span several years and describe a pattern of predatory behavior. Victims' advocates praise the women for coming forward. The case has reignited discussions about athlete misconduct and accountability. The league has put her on leave pending the outcome of the investigation. It is not known if she has been charged with any crime. It's not known whether the women have been identified or when they will be brought to justice. The investigation is still ongoing, and Chen has not commented on the allegations or been placed on paid administrative leave until the outcome is known, the league said. The allegations are being investigated by the U.S. Attorney's Office in New York and the New Jersey Attorney General's office in New Jersey. The women have not been identified, but the case is under investigation by the New York City Police Department and New Jersey State Department of Human Rights and Human Rights Enforcement and the Department of Health and Human Services. The U.N. Soccer Player's Association of America has issued a statement in support of Sarah Chen and the women who have accused her of sexual assault. text: Margaret Reid played a “Pick 5’ bet on Derby day, successfully choosing the winners of races 8 through 12 at Churchill Downs. She made the wager more than 1,000 miles away at the Retama Park racetrack near San Antonio in Selma, Texas. Reid has been playing Pick 5 bets for years, and says she does her homework, studying the horses. Justify (at 3-1 odds) was Reid’s last pick for the 12th race, and she won an astounding $1.23 million when Justify crossed the finish line at the Kentucky Derby on Saturday. It is the biggest win ever at the Texas track, according to a spokeswoman for the track. The owners of Justify took home $ 1.24 million in prize money. The winner is planning a big vacation — then investments, then a big win. The whole bar went nuts,” Retama park owner Bill Belcher told the San Antonio-Express News. “She was very excited.” “It was an amazing feeling, yes, that you won a really big ticket — like, a mini-lotto if you will,’ Reid, of Austin, told local CBS affiliate KENS-5 TV. "It doesn’t always work out, but sometimes it does," she smiled. "To bet that little amount of money and win $1,2 million is unheard of," a spokeswoman said of Reid's win.

text: Five years after one of the worst wildfires in American history, the town of Paradise, Calif., is slowly being rebuilt. One million trees have been removed from the Paradise area and many lots are now for sale or being built on. It took nine months just to remove all the hazardous toxins and debris piles before the first homes could be rebuilt. "I don't know that there will ever be 26,000 people in Paradise again," says Ryan Miller, a geography and hazards expert at the University of California, Davis. The slow and expensive recovery that continues in Paradisecould be a lesson for survivors in Lahaina, not to mention scores of other recent wildland fire disasters on the mainland. "My heart goes out to people in Hawaii right now because we can totally relate to that," says Cindy Foudray, a Paradise resident who is still trying to get a new home within the next year. "It's a slow process either way because when you're starting from scratch, you can only do what you can do at that moment and work forward"

text: Migwan, a North American black bear at the Detroit Zoo, is able to connect photographs of objects with the objects themselves. It’s believed to be the first time that Ursus americanus or any other bear species has been shown to have this ability. Migwan was born in the wild but was brought to the zoo as a cub in 2002 after being found with her face full of porcupine quills. Dr. Marc Bekoff, a retired professor of ecology and biology at the University of Colorado and a well-known expert on animal cognition, called the new research “very important.’“We must keep the door open and not write off other animals as being ‘not all that smart,'” he said, adding that we should all expect more surprises when it comes to animal intelligence. “Our personal experiences working with other bears suggests they might all be motivated and quick learners,” said Zoe Johnson-Ulrich, who co-authored a paper about the research which was published online June 24 in the journal Animal Cognition. It's not clear if Migwan is ‘representing’ the photographs as real objects because we don’t know if she thinks the photograph IS the object, or understands the representational nature, in that photos are like objects but not exactly the same,’ she said. For example, “You can�t eat a photograph of an apple” No, but you can use a photograph to show what you like to eat.
label: SENSITIVE

Everybody knows it," Limbaugh said of the national anthem debate. "I do believe that the left wants to cause great damage to the NFL,” he added. "What does the NFL stand for? Masculinity, strength, toughness," he said. "It’s patriotic, you’ve got the flag, you've got the anthem, you're got uniformed military personnel" "They think it�'s about police brutality, they think it's about righting social wrongs, and so forth," he added of the protests. "This is an attack. on the NFL as an institution for shaking it down and lowering its profile and impact on American culture," Limbaugh told Hannity. "Everybody knows it. It's actually happening. There are studies and courses in college that do this," the radio host said of classes on how to take masculinity out of men. "They don’t like displays of patriotism, strength,. rugged individualism, and that's why the players are being used here.” "We're not in a liberal society. We're in a conservative society," Limbaugh added.

text: A Jim Henson exhibition is headed to the Museum of Moving Image in New York. The Museum launched a Kickstarter campaign on Tuesday, calling on all Henson buffs to help raise $40,000. In just two days, the museum met its initial mark. Now they’re hoping to reach their “stretch goal” of $100,000, in order to welcome even more bug-eyed creatures with squeezable noses and unruly mops of hair into their new Queens home. The permanent MOMI exhibition was first announced in 2013, with help from $2.75 million in backing from New York City, a place many muppets would have called home if they could talk. The money helped fund a 2,200-square-foot gallery on the museum’s second floor and ensure that it is puppet-proof. The delicate creatures are to be spruced up by designers and builders at Henson's legendary Creature Shop, where they'll be preserved for future generations to ogle, as well. A traveling version of the exhibition is also slated to go on tour, starting off at Seattle's Museum of Pop Culture on May 20. The Center for Puppetry Arts, based in Atlanta, also has a permanent exhibit devoted to Henson on view. The two exhibitions are not related, as they're not related to each other, but they're both Henson-related and will go on display in the same place in the future.
label: SAFE

text: The Galilean Suite is a major classical work from composer Dave Dexter. It comprises four movements, each dedicated to Jupiter's largest moons and comes in at about an hour. At 23 minutes, it’s also the most extended piece. For Ganymede, Dexter got consumed by the idea that you could stand on the moon—the most habitable of the four—at night and see Jupiter and its aurora in its sky. For Europa, the ice moon with an underground ocean that might contain life, Dexter goes with a more mysterious sound. The composer says he was inspired by many composers, among the living by John Williams and Grant Kirkhope and the dead by Richard Strauss and Thomas Tallis. He says he went for a more modern, quirky feel with a triumphant theme that hints at colonization thousands of years in the future, but he didn't try to translate the possibility of sea life into music. It's tempting to say that the glockenspiel at bar 46 represents bacterial evolution, but that would be a lie!
label: SAFE

text: A team of international scientists from the U.S., France, Germany, and Ethiopia recently published cutting-edge climate research on how thunderstorms can "clump" together. This led to the discovery that this clumping, or aggregation, of clouds can affect the Earth's climate in multiple ways that were not previously understood. This will help provide better observational constraints for models. The research can help provide new ways for climate modelers to test that their models are working correctly and the evidence is that's due to the burning of fossil fuels and is very well understood for a century at this point. This research will help constrain those future studies for the future and New Mexico's Joseph Galewsky says it is a new way of trying to get at the most important uncertainty in climate projections for the next century. The study focused on the global tropics from 2015 to 2020 and focused on thunderstorms in the tropical cyclones of the eastern Pacific Ocean and the western Pacific Ocean. It also potentially helps us to better understand past climates because the isotopes in water vapor are often recorded in cave formations or ice cores.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Tetragonula hockingsi lives in the tropics and subtropics of Queensland and the Northern Territory. Scientists tested the bees' response to common insecticides and heat stress. Even bees exposed to minuscule amounts of insecticide, certainly not enough to kill them, were more susceptible to the effects of heat. Climate projections suggestglobal warmingof less than 1°C will cause tropical regions to experience extreme conditions sooner than other regions of the globe. The combination ofheat stressand insecticide exposure may put this stingless bee at increased risk of decline. The study was published today in the journalRoyal Society Open Science, by Holly Farnan, a Ph.D. candidate at James Cook University in Queensland. She said bees are critical components of natural and agricultural ecosystems and concern is growing about declines in their populations. It could be reduced if bees avoided foraging on flowers contaminated with insecticides. However, our work revealed no consistent avoidance of the insecticides by the bees. We also found the bees had diminished tolerance of heat stress after non-lethal exposure to the insect pesticides.
label: SENSITIVE

Find some good cheer with some healthy food choices this holiday season, and don’t forget the fresh flowers’ don't forget the fruits and veg too, as they are a great source of vitamin C and vitamin B, and can help boost your immune system.

text: The Idiot is the story of Selin Karadağ, a Turkish-American student at Harvard. text: Redmond Gerard claims the United States' first gold medal of the Pyeongchang Winter Games. Gerard scored a run of 87.16 to hold off Canadians Max Parrot and Mark McMorris, who finished second and third respectively. The 17-year-old Gerard, the youngest in the competition, landed a perfect backside triple cork 1440 on his final run. The Sochi Games silver medallist Staale Sandbech was fourth, with teenage sensation Marcus Kleveland a disappointing sixth. In a later news conference, Gerard said he was already looking forward to the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, where he will compete in the men's halfpipe and the slalom events. text: Dan McNeil, 27, from Dumfries, set off on his charity trek from Sandyhills in March 2021. He has raised more than £30,000 for the armed forces charity SSAFA. He said his life went "downhill from there" and he posted a cry for help on social media. "They got in touch and they sent a case worker the next day and basically gave me that bit of inspiration to turn my life around," he says. He described it as the "journey of a lifetime" and which he now hopes to share with others. 'I've got my heart set on a book, to write down everything that I've learned,' he said, "I want to get it on paper - and it's going to potentially help other people as well"

text: This year is "virtually certain" to be the warmest in 125,000 years, European Union scientists say. The heat is a result of continued greenhouse gas emissions from human activity, combined with the emergence this year of the El Nino weather pattern, which warms the surface waters in the eastern Pacific Ocean. "We must not let the devastating floods, wildfires, storms, and heatwaves seen this year become the new normal," said Piers Forster , climate scientist at University of Leeds. text: A new report from the American Psychological Association outlines the processes that make people susceptible to misinformation. People are more likely to believe misinformation if it comes from groups they belong to or if they judge the source as credible. The report also describes features of social media that help misinformation spread very quickly. It recommends eight steps for policymakers, scientists, media and the public to help curb the spread of misinformation and the risks it poses to health, well-being and civic life. The recommendations focus on health misinformation, but can also be used for broader topics such as politics and climate change, the report says. The panel members who wrote the report spent more than a year reviewing thescientific literatureto develop their recommendations. The findings offer direct input to one of the main issues highlighted inAPA's Health Advisory on Social Mediaby addressing tactics that can be used to combat misinformation. It acknowledges that there is much more to learn, and recommends moreresearch fundingand industry cooperation to understand behaviors related to misinformation and create tools to correct it.

text: American artist Jeff Koons (York, Pennsylvania, 1955) can be considered one of the most influential artists of his generation. He burst into the public arena back in the 1980s in New York, with his own interpretation of Duchamp's ready-mades in the style of Andy Warhol. He then evolved towards an art which blends the objective and more cerebral with the subjective and more sentimental. The work of Koons, full of sensuality and seduction, accurately depicts our post-modern capitalist era, which has made him successfully appealing to the masses. Koons tells us that we cannot comprehend his art if we do not previously let ourselves feel what his work awakens in us: the means to achieve, within the plane of ideas, the rational sense of his art. An optimistic message about overcoming and transcending that which is beyond the sensitive, inviting the spectator to converse with, and hence complete, his work, Elena Cué writes in her interview with Koons in Chelsea, New York. She asks Koons: Does your art express a nostalgia of childhood, as a kind of paradise without limits or repression? I think I ended up working with objects as metaphor for people. And it's not about finding relevance or perfection or imperfection in objects, but it's that you can accept yourself, and then go out and accept others. That's really the highest objective state. And everything is metaphor for that state. Not shutting down, accepting things and enjoying everything is an openness and an openness to the world.

text: Unknown vandals splattered yellow paint on Anish Kapoor's Dirty Corner (2011) Kapoor called the incident a "tragedy" and "extremely sad" Politicians from the ruling Socialist Party quickly condemned the incident as an attack on free speech. This comparison is absurd, ridiculous, and malicious," Kapoor told Le Figaro. The artist, however, tried to look on the bright side, declaring that “blind vandalism proves that the power of art can intrigue minds and move limits […]. The positive thing about this attack is that it highlights the creative force of an inanimate object," said Kapoor in an interview with the French newspaper LeFigaro. "It was lightly sprayed with paint. The work is being cleaned," the management of Versailles said in a statement, as reported by the Guardian. "I never used the words from which the controversy stemmed. I referred to ‘Her' or ‘She,' to describe a form that could be feminine, lying on the grass like an Egyptian Queen or a Sphinx," said the artist in a separate interview with Le Figaros. The artwork's sexual connotations unleashed a significant backlash from some conservative French commentators.

text: The northern lights, also called the aurora borealis, could be visible in northern U.S. states after a spike in magnetic activity on the sun on Thursday, November 9. It comes after a correctly predicted stunning display last Sunday when a strong geomagnetic storm produced aurora in the night skies. The culprit is another coronal mass ejection, a cloud of magnetic fields and charged particles from the sun that streams into space at up to 1,900 miles (3,000 kilometers) per second. The sun is currently nearing the peak of its present solar cycle, which is proving to be much stronger than the last one. If you can, get away from light pollution and have a manual camera on a tripod that can take long exposure images (try f2.8-4, ISO 1600, 20 seconds). Wishing you clear skies and wide eyes. As the particles collide with Earth’s magnetic field, they accelerate down its magnetic field lines.

text: Larry Young was perhaps the last great innovator on the Hammond B3 organ. Tragically he passed away at the age of thirty-eight while being treated for pneumonia, but it leads one to speculate on the endless possibilities his continued development would have brought to the music has he lived. This beautifully packaged two-disc set, Larry Young in Paris the ORTF Recordings, captures young in Paris sometime between 1964 and 1965 and features a series of ten songs played with different line ups and broadcast over French public radio. It marks the period just preceding Young's Blue Note Years and you can hear the sound that Young was developing, one that would later be honed with such precision on the groundbreaking album Unity. The music is electric like on Davis' "Trane of Thought," which shows how well Young's left foot bass line could just drive the rhythmic heartbeat of the band. The group is expanded into the Jazz aux Champs-Elysees All Stars with the addition of French players. Tenor saxophonist Jean-Claude Forhrenbach, trumpeter Sonny Grey, and pianist and leader Jack Diếval, along with Italian drummer Franco Manzecchi and conga player Jackie Bamboo. text: LZ Granderson: Claims that science will soon prevent aging and dramatically prolong life strike me as irresponsible hype and false hope. Grandson Tyler is participating in stem cell and genetics research and believes that it is feasible and desirable to double the human lifespan. Tyler: Extending the lifespan will mean more crowding, more mouths to feed, more environmental degradation, and more resource depletion. LZ: The distribution of benefits that will accrue from aging research is a political, economic, and ethical question, not a scientific one. The benefits will almost certainly be enjoyed in a markedly unequal and unfair fashion- greatly favoring the rich and powerful, with only a very slow trickle down to the population at large. This inequity has accompanied every previous technological advance in the long march of human progress and is not specifically disqualifying to progress in slowing aging and death. To quote Mark Watney in the movie 'The Martian': I'm left with only one option, I'm gonna have the science of this out of this shit of this world. And instead of vigilance in how they be, they should be; instead of how to be in a hell in a handbasket- we must remember the risks of advancing, but the potential benefits may be all that stand between us and disaster. Science is disruption, but it may offer our only road to salvation, LZ says, and it's time to get used to the inevitability of death and its inevitable ebb, flow, and recurrences.

The pair say they hope their photos will inspire others to take up the sport of free diving and hold their breath for extended periods of time, as well as taking underwater photos. They also hope that the photos will help raise awareness of the dangers of free divers and the importance of body language when diving with sharks. They say it is important to be able to recognize such body language and know when it is time to respect their space and retreat from their area. "When a shark feels non-threatened it will display slow and natural swimming patterns," they say. "If a shark feeling threatened, it may exhibit certain body positions which includes a hunched back and lowering of the pectoral fins," they write. "It is important for us to know when to respect the shark and retreat," they add.

text: A six-person team from a D.C.-based nonprofit launched an elaborate website that was nearly identical to the team's page. The Washington franchise responded to the campaign on its Twitter account: ‘I just want to give my sincere thanks to the people running the social media and social media account for acknowledging our hard work over the last few months,’ he said. In the past, Snyder has pushed back against claims that the name is racist, arguing that it “represents honor, represents respect, represents pride, hopefully winning” He did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the fake campaign.. ‘We’re not going to boo the Redskins, we’ve going to cheer the Redhawk.’ “That is the cherry on the top, that they actually had to respond to that,“ Medina- tayac said, “that is the top.” “Our goal was to come up with a proactive message ― something that was positive”

text: Fire has scorched 24947 acres in Central Texas. Residents who evacuated are being updated regularly on when it will be safe to return home. Community support centers are providing meals and supplies to displaced families. Air quality monitors show improvement in areas downwind of the fire. The cause of the wildfire is under investigation and no injuries have been reported. The fire has been burning since June 1. The blaze is burning in an area of Central Texas near the town of Laredo and the Texas Rangers are on the scene to help with containment. The wildfire is only 10 percent contained at this time, according to the Texas Department of Public Health and Human Services. It is currently burning in the Rio Grande Valley, a rural area near the city of Austin and the city's East Side. It has burned more than 2,000 acres so far and is expected to burn for at least a few more days. It's burning in a remote area of the Texas Panhandle, which is about 50 miles from Laredos and the Dallas-Fort Worth area. There are no immediate evacuations or evacuations warnings in the area, but the fire is not expected to be fully contained until the end of the week. The Texas Rangers say they are working with local authorities to monitor hot spots and make sure the fire doesn't spread to other parts of the state. The U.S. Army National Guard is on the ground to assist in containing the fire, which has charred more than 1,500 acres in the past few days.

text: A materials research team consisting of NIMS and Nagoya University has designed a novel two-step thermal aging schedule. It is capable of fabricating nickel-aluminum (Ni-Al) alloys that are stronger at high temperatures than Ni-Al alloys fabricated using conventional thermal aging processes. This was achieved by usingartificial intelligence(AI) techniques to identify several dozen different thermal aging schedules potentially effective in increasing alloys' high-temperature strength. The mechanisms behind these schedules were then elucidated through detailed analysis. These results suggest that AI can be used to generate new insights intomaterials research. This researchwas published inScientific Reportson August 4, 2023. The research team hopes to increase the high-Temperaturestrength of more complex nickel-based superalloys already in practical use ingas turbinesusing this AI-based technique, thereby improving their efficiency. The results of this research were published in the journal Scientific Report. The study was funded by Japan's Ministry of Science and Technology.

text: Puente Romano Beach Resort Marbella is one of those destinations whose very name evokes a certain sort of jet-set glamour. text: A report says USA Swimming ignored or covered up hundreds of sexual abuse cases over the course of decades. The report is reminiscent of the recent USA Gymnastics scandal involving former team doctor and convicted pedophile Larry Nassar. The investigation made five principal claims: Top USA Swimmers executives, officials and coaches knew of multiple sexual predators in coaching positions for years and did nothing to stop it. Some officials were not banned from the sport even after they had been convicted of felonies. Between 2006 and 2016, USA swimming spent $7,450,000 on legal fees. It's not clear how much of that money was spent to settle sexual abuse Cases before they can hit the public radar, but SCNG notes that USA Swimmer “arranged settlement agreements in at least three states with victims of alleged sexual abuse by swim coaches’ before the cases were even filed with a court.” “I was able to leave a horrible monster and build a life, but I’ve realized that stories like my own are too important to go unwritten,’ former Olympic swimmer Ariana Kukors said.

text: Americans consume $1 billion worth of electricity per year on keeping home networking devices fired up but could potentially save a whopping $330 million in costs if they switch over to energy-efficient models. Standard modems, wireless routers, and similar devices consume just as much energy as a 32-inch flat-screen TV — that’s 30 times more than a phone charger. There are approximately 145 million of them in use nationwide. This all adds up to 8.3 billion kWH khours of electricity consumed each year, the equivalent of the output of three large, coal-burning power plants (500 MW) The result, according to the NRDC, “is an estimated 5 million metric tons of carbon dioxide emissions each year.” These small, innocuous black boxes that never sleep consume enough electricity each year to power all 1.2 million homes in the Silicon Valley area, the hi-tech capital of the world. It's time for that innovation to be a standard feature in the new modems and routers we buy at the store or receive from our Internet providers,” says NRDC senior scientist Noah Horowitz in a press release. In addition, the state of California is considering setting minimum energy efficiency standards to make sure every model sold there is an efficient one. All rather sobering stuff but good to hear progress is being made. The government's ENERGY STAR program is expected to soon issue a specification that will result in a label to help customers buy efficient models.
label: SAFE

text: Unprecedented resource required almost a year's worth of supercomputing time to create. The dataset, known as CONUS404, is the result of a collaboration between the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) and the U.S. Geological Survey. Scientists are already using the data to dig into new techniques for improving long-range forecasting, planning for water resource allocation, and to better understand the causes and impacts of extreme and rareweatherevents. The weather in the United States is relatively well observed by local weather stations, stream gauges, snowpack sensors, radars, weather balloons, and more. But on their own, these observations cannot always give a clear picture of how weather patterns may be changing over time. 40 years (1980–2021) at 4-kilometer grid spacing—hence the name, CONUS 404. A weather simulation that covers such a large area over such a long time at such a high resolution has never before been possible.
