text: I have always hated involuntary psychiatric treatment. It is demeaning to human dignity, subject to abuse, and extremely unpleasant both to experience and to recommend. But there are rare times when pressuring someone into treatment becomes the lesser evil, preferable to the risks of suicide, violence, jail or homelessness. Involuntary commitment to inpatient psychiatric hospitals has become very uncommon in the US because almost all psychiatric hospitals have been closed. Forty-six states have adopted Assisted Outpatient Treatment (AOT) statutes in an attempt both to improve the lives of the severely ill and also to reduce risk among those who are at highest risk if their severe mental illness goes untreated. Studies show that AOT improves symptoms and functioning and reduces hospitalizations, arrests, and violence. Most people in AOT convert successfully to voluntary treatment within a year. Many who were unhappy when originally ordered into outpatient care, later feel grateful once they have been helped by it. The Barnes/Badre argument about the lack of literature supporting long term antipsychotic treatment doesn't apply to most people who are in Aot on a short term basis. Because it is impossible to extend placebo controlled studies for indefinite periods, we will probably never have conclusive evidence on long term benefits vs. risks. For people with a history of persistent, dangerous, relapses, the real risks of antipsychotics are often outweighed by the substantial benefit. Protecting individual privacy is the most important thing we can do for people with severe, persistent, relapsed mental illness.
label: UNSAFE

text: Last Things premiered in the New Frontiers section at this year’s Sundance Film Festival. The film will open theatrically in New York at Anthology Film Archives on January 12 on a 35mm print. text: Borecore is the vast pool of non-viral, remarkably uninteresting Vines and social media videos uploaded or streamed by young people. It's just ... them, goofing off, cuddling, driving aimlessly or lip-syncing to '80s music alone. People don't seem to be ironically binging on Vines of teenagers removing their nail polish or practicing inexpert karate chops. There are always more people, especially young people with time and energy on their hands, creating content than there are people creating things the rest of us deem worth looking at. Until the day tastemakers create and seek out the intensely boring as a status symbol or artistic aesthetic in itself, there's no need to imagine trends around the long-standing tradition of boring people creating uninteresting content. Stand down, teenagers; your half-hearted Vining doesn’t deserve a name. The New York Times Magazine’s Jenna Wortham diagnoses it not as narcissism but “the never-to-be-v viral output that comes from mixing powerful devices and a lifetime of social-­media training with regular, old teenage boredom.” Sure. As long as there have been low-barrier methods of public self-expression, teens have been on them, enacting their mundane performances of self for an audience of next to no one. The world needed to know my seduction style. No one sought out my dull and self-absorbed LiveJournal, instead flocking to innovative LJs like Oh No They Didn't, a gossipy celebrity blog.
label: SAFE

text: The Pulitzer Prize for Drama was given to the writer of a fast and funny and poignant new American play that I had the good fortune to see. The Pulitzer is awarded to a playwright, but I'd argue there should be a citation in there somewhere for the director of the first production. Theater is a team sport; surely the actors, and the designers too, get credit for their efforts in the development of a new play. A lot can happen in the unseen world of new play development that fundamentally alters the course of a play. So let's hear it for the playwright Stephen Adly Guirgis, whose imagination, comic timing, sense of pace and diction have given us many fine plays, including his latest, the Pulitzer Prize winning Between Riverside and Crazy. But let's also tip the hat to the director who helped him get there, Austin Pendleton, who was in the delivery room of the new play and helped him deliver it to the world.. The playwright knows when we get lucky as well. Some might argue that the Pulitzer is supposed to be an award purely for the script, unlike the Obies or the Tonys or the Outer Critics Circle Awards, where the prize for Best Play cannot help but be influenced by the production. But even in the case of Anna in the Tropics, the script comes with a history of false starts, dropped subplots, and often a whole variety of possible endings that came and went during the process of hearing the play read or in a staged reading.
label: SAFE

text: Parts of Queensland Australia have been battling a rat and mouse plague for months. A surge in the native rodent population has forced the rats to move coastwards in their search for more food. text: Doug Pederson out-coached New England Patriots legend Bill Belichick in a Super Bowl. Pederson went for it on fourth-and-goal at the 1-yard line and called a trick play with a tight end passing to his quarterback. “You really want to know what we call it?’” Pederson said when asked about the trick play. ‘Philly Special’ was actually borrowed from elsewhere. It seems to have its roots at Clemson, who ran it for a two-point conversion from DeAndre Hopkins to Tajh Boyd in 2012. The Eagles led the NFL in fourth-down conversions this season and won the NFC championship game and Super Bowl with a 41-33 win over the Patriots.. And the Eagles sent the running back in motion with a defender on the other side of the field, and Ertz was one-on-one with the Patriots cornerback on the sideline. That’s not as splashy as “ Philly Special,” but it’�s another example of how Pederson and his staff out- coached the Patriots out of his high school coaching days. The Patriots kept us off balance, Belichick said, but it was the other man on the sidelines who stayed on balance, cornerback Malcolm Butler said on theOther man on other sideline, Malcolm Butler.

text: Embryonic neurons transplanted into the damaged brain of mice formed proper connections. By the fourth week, the transplanted young cells became the type of cells normally seen in that area of the brain. The finding is an important step forward for someday repairing brain injury by using replacement neurons, other researchers said. Still, there are many challenges left, including how to supply the new cells and account for glial cells in the brain, which form scar tissue when an injury happens and can be replaced with new cells.. People with Parkinson’s disease suffer from a death of dopamine-producing cells deep in the. brain, and it’S possible to transplant into their brains new neurons that secrete dopamine and help with certain symptoms. They don’t even need to be cells. Other groups have turned induced pluripotent stem cells from human adults into a type of neurons that can be reprogrammed to grow into a desired type of neuron. The first transplant of this kind was done using brain cells from pigs. It was done in a study published Wednesday in the journal Nature. But translating this to human stroke patients, safety will be a concern, neuroscientist Zhiping Pang, of Rutgers Robert Wood Johnson Medical School, said. “A lot more work needs to be done, like the current study, before we can realize this exciting cell-replacement strategy in restoring proper brain functions of a stroke patient,” he said. The study is promising, but acknowledged that things are a lot messier outside the lab.

text: Richard Adams, who died on Tuesday at the age of 96, wrote Watership Down in 1972. The book is about two rabbits, Hazel and Fiver, who live in a bucolic warren of rabbits. Because of its subject matter (talking rabbits), some fans might classify it as a children’s book. Adams shrugs off the label entirely: “I don’t believe there should be such a thing as a kids’ book,” he explained in a Reddit AMA. The kind of fantasy readers under 13 or 14 should be exposed to is exactly the kind of twisted, twisted, alien plot that sits in our heads for decades, becoming more poignant and poignant as you age, Adams said in a 2015 interview. He also said in the same interview that “Readers like to be upset and bowled over by things that were upsetting to me, but fortunately I was able to forget that.’’ Adams’ death was announced by his publisher, Rex Collings, in a statement on Tuesday. He is survived by his wife, Susan, and their two daughters, who were encouraged by their father to write the book when he was a civil servant in the U.K. and had never written fiction in his life. The novel was rejected seven times before it was finally accepted by RexCollings, the tiny and summarily lucky publishing house that would go on to see the book sell in the millions. It is the most violent “talking rabbit book” in history.

text: Mohammed Siraj is the world’s top one-day international (ODI) bowler. The 29-year-old will take the ball in his hand when India take on New Zealand in 2023. The son of an auto rickshaw driver, Siraj first picked up the game as a teenager. He would play in slippers because his daily pocket money of 70 rupees (less than $1) was not enough to buy sports shoes. The tall and athletic pacer from Hyderabad in southern India has come a long way from bowling in slipper on dusty grounds to becoming a household name in the cricket-obsessed country. He took fiveSri Lankan wickets in 16 balls – the joint fastest five-wicket haul in ODI history – and ended with figures of 6-21 as India romped to a 10- wicket win in the Asia Cup final. He has also stood up for his team once more in the World Cup and its biggest group-stage match betweenIndia and Pakistan.

text: The world is heading for considerably less warming than projected a decade ago, experts say. But that good news is overwhelmed by much more pain from current climate change. Key to the session is the first "global stocktake" on climate, when countries look at what's happened since the 2015 Paris climate agreement. One of the central topics will be whether fossil fuels should be phased out, but it will be run by the CEO of an oil company."We are seeing the world's weather start to unravel and there's no evidence that that will stop," a climate scientist says. "We cannot trust these politicians and we cannot trust the processes of the COPs," an environmental activist says, referring to the United Nations' climate talks in Dubai. 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit) of warming over pre-industrial levels is the global goal, while 2.7 (4.9 degrees Fahrenheit), according to UNEP's Emissions Gap, is 2.5 to 2.9.

The OnePlus Open sports a sizable 6.31-inch cover screen with a 2K resolution and a dynamic refresh rate of 10-120Hz. The cover screen on the front equips a 32MP sensor, and the foldable display features a 20MP sensor. Both front and rear cameras are capable of recording 4K at 30fps. It is powered by Snapdragon 8 Gen 2 coupled with 16GB of RAM, which supports RAM expansion up to an additional 12GB. The handset retails at $1699.99 in the U.S. and $2299 in Canada, but the company is offering an additional $200 off if consumers trade in their existing phones under any condition. The first sale of the device will start on October 26, with pre-orders starting with the launch offers.

text: “No Borders” is a one-day pop-up show featuring over 100 works by donated artists. All proceeds from the day’s sales will go toward the ACLU and the International Refugee Assistance Project (IRAP) Tina Fey, Alec Baldwin, Tom Hanks, Tracy Morgan, Maggie Gyllenhaal, Michael Moore, Padma Lakshmi and a whole host of other stars are teaming up for Stand for Rights: A Benefit for the ACLU. Donate now and join us at 7 p.m. ET on Friday, March 31, on Facebook Live. #standforrights2017. The show takes place Sunday, April 2, from 1 p.M. to 6 p. m. at Brooklyn’S Ground Floor Gallery. It features works by Claes Oldenburg, Robert Longo and Victoria Burge, all of which are priced at $200 or less. The exhibition provides a space for the creative community to come together, supporting one another as well as those most targeted by the current administration. It also provides an easier way to show some love to the organizations fighting to protect the rights of immigrants and refugees in this uncertain time. Also, paying $200 for a ClaesOldenburg lithograph is just bananas, so you might want to get there early. It takes place on April 2 at 1pm to 6pm at Brooklyn's Ground floor Gallery. In a single day, the show raised over $5,000 for the Civil Liberties Defense Center and the Standing Rock Medic + Healer Council.
label: SENSITIVE

text: "I have a secret fantasy of being an environmental terrorist," Ethan Hawke said. "I’d love to slip just a little dynamite in somewhere," he said. Hawke's interest in environmental issues has shown itself in a variety of ways over the years. "The Purge" is going to elicit questions of consequence-free crime — but remember, it's just silly banter, Hawke says. "Yeah, 'Ethan Hawke Wages War on Oil.' Next thing you know, I’ll mysteriously die in a car accident," Hawke added after Grantland quipped that the title of their interview would be 'E EthanHawke, Eco-Terrorist' A trailer for "ThePurge" was released on Friday, September 14. The movie is about a father who tries to protect his family from a group of "purgers" in the year 2022. It's also about a man who becomes a vegetarian after his children are grown up and he wants them to be one, too. "She has a joke that she always says at dinner conversations, which is, ‘Are you vegetarian yet?’, because she believes that by the time my children are growing up, basically everybody will be one," he told The Independent in 2007. "OK, good," he replied. "Next thing youknow, I'm going to mysteriously die," he added, referring to his own death. "That would be where my inner demon lurks."
label: UNSAFE

text: Climate extremes will keep hunger in Somalia at record highs, warns U.N. World Food Programme. Floods have driven close to half a million people from their homes and crippled families' attempts to rebuild their drought-ravaged livelihoods. WFP activated a flood anticipatory action programme - its first in Africa - in coordination with the Government of Somalia. The floods have exacerbated Somalia's hunger crisis, at a time when significant funding shortfalls mean that WFP is only able to provide food assistance to less than half of the people most in need. With a quarter of Somalia's population - 4.3 million people - forecast to face crisis-level hunger or worse (IPC3+) by the end of the year, the support of the humanitarian community remains a lifeline. Without additional funding, WFP will struggle to scale anticipatoryaction programmes or make longer-term investments to build resilience, enable Somalia to adapt to these increasingly severe climate shocks and break the cycle of crisis-driven dependence on humanitarian aid.
label: SENSITIVE

text: One in eight women in the U.S. will now face the diagnosis of breast cancer. Cancer is the leading disease-related killer of dogs, with mammary tumors the most common type. Growing interest in canine cancer has led to new comparative oncology research. Researchers hope to identify treatments that will benefit both dogs and humans."Dogs drink our same water, they are exposed to the same toxins," says Luke Robinson, co-founder of 2 Million Dogs. "We're really living in a soup of chemicals," says Sharima Rasanayagam, director of science for the nonprofit Breast Cancer Fund for Dogs, which is raising awareness for cancer in dogs and people. "Under a microscope, a mammary tumor from a dog and from a person look the same," Robinson says. "Not only do you have carcinogens that can directly cause cancer, but you can also do you directly cause it in a dog," Rasanagam says. in dogs, humans can absorb chemicals under the tongue, such as Bisphenol A and phthalates, in many plastics and vinyls, according to a separate study. While humans may develop cancer at age 60, the average age of diagnosis for a dog is age 6. "By combining -- on any environmental exposure issue -- humans and dogs in the same location, you can make a bigger case for the potential impact or abatement of a particular thing," says Dr. Rodney Page, of Flint Animal Cancer Center.
label: SENSITIVE

text: More than 46 firefighters are battling the flames, supported by air tankers dropping fire retardant. Weather forecasters predict shifting winds that could help containment efforts in the coming days. The Red Cross has opened cooling centers for evacuees, and local veterinary clinics are providing temporary shelter for pets. The fire is threatening residential areas in the town of Redding, in the northern part of the state. It has burned more than 1,000 acres so far, and is only 10% contained. The U.S. National Guard is on the scene to help with firefighting efforts, officials say. It is the state's largest-ever wildfire, and the largest in the state since it was started in 1991. The blaze has destroyed more than 2,000 homes and damaged more than 3,000 more, authorities say. text: Small and Medium Enterprises Development Agency of Nigeria has signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Anambra State Government to bolster the growth of Small and Medium-sized Enterprises in the state. The agreement signed on Friday, will support SMEs with N1billion in a matching fund arrangement. This was disclosed in a statement signed by media aide to the SMEDAN DG, Peter Adeshina, and obtained by our correspondent on Saturday. The new agreement underscores the agency’s commitment to ensure SMEs have access to vital funding across Nigeria. The SMEDan boss promised to ensure that the funds, once accessible to SMEs, will be disbursed in a timely, transparent, and equitable manner, eliminating any obstacles preventing deserving SMEs from accessing these vital funds. “This level of meaningful support is what we expect from state governments nationwide, given the established importance of SMEs in driving economic development and prosperity. Small businesses are the backbone of employment and contribute nearly half of our GDP. If we intend to jumpstart the economy, we must invest in them and provide substantial support for their growth”

text: After 10 wins in a row, India's unstoppable run came to a crashing halt in yet another trophy clash. Since winning the Champions Trophy in 2013, India have lost five ICC finals and three semifinals. Sports psychologist Gayatri Vartak believes it was not a case of buckling under pressure and Australia were just tactically superior on the day. Diya Jain, a sports psychologist at Fortis Hospital, said the big match pressure can take a toll on elite athletes but India's performance should be celebrated. 'Cricket is life here, it is the DNA of sport and has no other competitors,' said Matthew Hayden, a member of the Australian team who lost to India in the World Test Championship final in June. 'For athletes, the Indian fan acts as a big fuel, they come from an emotional space,' said Gayatri. 'I don't think it is fair to compare this Indian team with the current composition of those over the last 10 years,' added Gayatri, who works with elite Indian athletes.
label: SENSITIVE

"Regardless of the makeup of our 2024 results, it is important to remember that the long-term outlook for Genesis remains completely unchanged," Sims said. text: Oskar Eustis' Julius Caesar is a gripping tale of power-lust, murder and anarchy in the Capitol. Corey Stoll makes a noble and conflicted Brutus; John Douglas Thompson commands Cassius. Gregg Henry makes a strong impression as the buffoonish president. Most arresting of the group is Elizabeth Marvel as Marc Antony (here played and referred to as a woman) But when Cassius asks, “How many ages hence shall this our lofty scene be acted over in states unborn and accents yet unknown?” we can only answer that we know one such age all too well. The Public Theater production of William Shakespeare’s Julius Caesar opened May 23, 2017 and continues through June 18 at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park in New York City. The cast lists twenty-six players, but an informal count suggests that there are enough extras around to swell the number close to fifty. The current Trumpian version is attention getting, certainly, and enhances the drama. The real-to-life links go astray, methinks, once the title character meets his fate on the Ides of March and cedes the spotlight for most of the rest of the evening. But we do seem to have heard something of the sort elsewhere from Christopherlowe? Maybe it’'s from Christopher lowe? We don’t know, but we’re glad to hear it from the Public Theater, which has been a great home for the play.
label: UNSAFE

text: The 28th edition of the Conference of the Parties (COP), the world’s foremost climate summit, begins in the United Arab Emirates on November 30. Although Africa is responsible for less than 5 percent of global emissions, it is disproportionately affected by negative climate change impacts. The African Group of Negotiators (AGN), which is currently chaired by Zambia, will speak for the continent at the COP28 talks in Dubai. Some of the biggest issues that the AGN will focus on, according to chief negotiator Ephraim Shitima, are a just energy transition and climate change finance, including funding for adaptation. African countries are negotiating for opportunities to accelerate theirfossil fuel productionto enable them to industrialise, before reinvesting those gains in green energy sources. Some say all fossil production should be abandoned as there is no evidence that oil and gas-rich nations like Nigeria have reinvested oil wealth in renewables or even in development. The issue of climate financing is set to come up once again.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Colson Whitehead’s The Underground Railroad was awarded the Pulitzer Prize in Fiction. The journalism Pulitzers honored several local news teams, including the staff of the East Bay Times in Oakland, California, and Eric Eyre of the Charleston Gazette-Mail in West Virginia. text: ESPN recently released its annual “Body Issue” which includes interviews and nude photographs of sixteen athletes and sports teams. Many people are no longer surprised when they see ESPN’s Body Issue since nude or sexualized images in magazines are so common. Our culture views nude images as a source of empowerment when in actuality they are more often a conduit for sexual objectification. The ESPN Body Issue is asking us to “pay no attention to the man behind the curtain,” to the reality of objectification, and instead to buy into the impressive myth of nudity-based empowerment. text: Violence broke out at Hawks Arena during the Warriors game. At least 15 people were treated for injuries, and 6 individuals were taken into custody. Stadium officials are reviewing security protocols. The confrontation began in the stands when fans from rival teams got into an argument that escalated into physical fighting. Security personnel intervened but struggled to control the crowd. The incident occurred during the second quarter of the Warriors' game against the New York Knicks. The game ended in a loss for the Knicks, and the Warriors went on to win the game, 102-91. text: The U.S. Department of Agriculture is allowing organic livestock farmers in California to temporarily abandon the feeding standards that allow them to label their product as organic. Due to a lack of grass -- which livestock typically must graze on four months out of the year to be considered organic -- farmers whose grazing season includes February and March do not have to grass-feed their livestock during those months. The USDA issued the variance after receiving requests from the California Certified Organic Farmers (CCOF) and Marin Organic Certified Agriculture. According to the CCOF, organic producers are only allowed to substitute their livestock’s grass diet with organic feed, but other advocates for pesticide-free farming warn that this is still an unfortunate reinterpretation of what it means to farm organically. “We lost at least a month to a month-and-a-half of pasture,” Albert Straus of the Straus Family Creamery in Petaluma said, noting that the grass dried up back in December. ‘We’ll support this variance if that's the only alternative,’ Ronnie Cummuns, national director of the Organic Consumers Association, told The Huffington Post. Resorting to organic or non-organic feed robs consumers of the nutritional benefits of grass-fed meat and dairy, he said. ”Grass-fed dairy or beef has higher levels of Omega-3 and Omega-6, which is extremely important in human health,“ Cummins said.
label: SAFE

text: Researchers asked people what they believe a driverless car ought to do in the following scenario. People generally agreed that the cars should be programmed to sacrifice their passengers if doing so would save many other people. But people in the survey also said they wouldn't want to ride in these cars themselves. "Figuring out how to build ethical autonomous machines is one of the thorniest challenges in artificial intelligence today," the researchers said in a study."Around 90 percent of those accidents are due to human error," Azim Shariff, an assistant professor of psychology and social behavior at the University of California, Irvine, said at a press conference. "Autonomous vehicles promise to change all that for the better, but there are barriers to their wide adoption," the study's co-author said. "To maximize safety, people want to live in a world in which everybody owns driverless cars that minimize casualties, but they want their own car to protect them at all costs," Iyad Rahwan, a researcher at MIT and co- author of the study, said in the study. "If everybody thinks this way, then we will end up in which every car will look after its own passenger's safety and society as a whole is worse," Rahwan said in an interview with CNN. "It's the tragedy of the commons: It's the way that we make a lot of money, but it's not the way we should live," he said of the potential for autonomous cars to save lives.
label: SENSITIVE

text: "Shybot" was part of a weirdly mesmerizing art project in early March. It was designed by the Italian artist Norma Jeane and engineers for the Desert X Biennial. The rover’s camera streamed its experiences back to The Lab art gallery in San Francisco. It traveled wherever it rolled, though assiduously avoided humans, and was forced to maneuver around obstacles too large for it to climb.. Drones tracked its progress from the air — which Shybot at times appeared not to appreciate. “The machine is let loose in the landscape, free of the human determinism that thus far framed its existence,” Jeane said. ‘And we, in turn, are free to imagine a world liberated from the indeterminacy of us.’ Got it? The artist called it a “fantasy of the desert sublime.” The project is one of several ongoing through the end of April in the Coachella Valley and the Sonoran Desert in southern California and its desert landscape. It’ll be on display at The Lab for the rest of the month, and the artist says it will be open to the public until April 30. The Lab is a collaboration with the city’‘s Italian Cultural Institute, which presented the work in collaboration with a group of artists from around the world. It will be on view through April 30 at the The Lab, which is located in the heart of San Francisco, California.
label: SAFE

text: 73.7 percent of voting Columbia College students have backed a call for the university to divest from fossil fuel companies. The ballot initiative was included as part of an election for student body representatives that took place this week. It was authored by Barnard Columbia Divest, a student group advocating divestment. "We need student support, and now that we have it, it's empowering us to step forward," said Iliana Salazar-Dodge, a co-founder of the group. "It just confirmed to us that we really are representing other students' voices, and not just ourselves," said Daniela Lapidous, a fellow co- founder. The group intends to take the ballot initiative to other groups representing students, such as the Columbia Engineering Student Council, in the hope of securing further votes of support. It is part of the nation-wide divestment campaign launched by 350.org. The campaign is aimed at ending the use of fossil fuel energy in the U.S. by the end of the year, according to the group's website. text: A Chinese space station re-entered the Earth’s atmosphere on Sunday, more than a year after the country lost contact with the school bus-sized structure. Some pieces of the station likely crashed into the Pacific Ocean shortly after 5:15 p.m. Pacific time. The Tiangong-1 station, which translates to “heavenly palace” in English, has been a topic of discussion among space-watchers for weeks after its fall towards Earth began to accelerate. Analysts said it was likely the 9.4-ton structure would tumble back home sometime between March 30 and April 2. The U.S. Strategic Command confirmed the re-entry in a statement on Sunday evening. The JFSCC does not track what happens to space debris after itRe-enters the atmosphere. Most of the debris fell north of the Spacecraft Cemetery, where Russia's Mir station arrived in 2001. An astrophysicist told Reuters that about 10 percent of the. station may have fallen into the ocean northwest of Tahiti. The country plans to complete another station by 2022, the state-run Xinhua News reported. Two crews of astronauts visited the station after it was launched in 2011. However, since March 2016, China has been unable to communicate with the station and plans to send another crew to visit it in the future. It is not known if there were any immediate reports of injuries or damage from the space station's re-enter on Sunday night.
label: SAFE

text: U.N. report says overall climate change will harm human health. But it says positive effects will include "modest improvements in cold-related mortality" British report says climate warming will likely not decrease winter mortality. It suggests more volatile winters might even raise death rates. "Heatwave deaths will increase a lot but there will still be more winter deaths," author says.. report by Philip Staddon of the University of Exeter says findings likely to apply to other developed countries. Excess winter deaths (EWDs) roughly halved to 31,000 in England and Wales in 2012-12 from 60,000 typical in the 1950s. In 2003, the worst European heatwave in centuries killed up to 70,000 people, including about 3,000 from Britain. The correlation between the number of cold winter days per year and EWDs, which was strong until the mid-1970s, no longer exists. "Winter cold severity no longer predicts the numbers affected," the authors wrote. "The correlation between a cold winter day and EWDs ... no longer exist" "We will continue to take account of the latest scientific evidence," a Defra spokesman said. The Defra statement said an updated climate assessment was due in 2017. The study is at odds with a 2012 Climate Change Risk Assessment by the British Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) that said global warming would bring "some potential benefits, for example, a projected reduction in winter mortality" The study was published in the journal Nature Climate Change.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston have taken a big first step toward growing human hearts. The scientists stripped donor hearts of any cells that might cause recipients to reject them. They then used stem cells to rebuild the tissue. Scientists still have a ways to go until they can bioengineer whole functional hearts for patients, a doctor says.. There are 4,153 people across the U.S. who need a heart transplant -- and last year, about 402 people died while on the waiting list for one, according to the United Network for Organ Sharing. The study involved 73 human hearts that had been donated through the New England Organ Bank, but could be used for research purposes, the researchers said.. It also validates the feasibility of using human pluripotent stem cells in the future, said Dr. Young-sup Yoon, director of stem cell biology at the Emory University School of Medicine, who was not involved in the study. "This study certainly provides a direction which may lead to such a future," Yoon said in an email to The Huffington Post. "As a first step, I do believe that parts of human hearts will become available sooner than whole heart grafts, and we are actively pursuing this option," Dr. Jacques Guyette said in a statement. "Regenerating a whole heart is most certainly a long-term goal that is several years away," Guyette added in a separate statement. 'We are currently working on engineering a functional myocardial patch that could replace cardiac tissue damaged due [to] a heart attack or heart failure," he said.
label: SENSITIVE

Leonard, a Marine veteran and political newcomer, is hoping to reclaim the seat for the GOP in the heavily Democratic state. He describes himself as a 13th-generation Rhode Islander whose ancestors fled England to escape religious persecution. text: NASA's James Webb Telescope captured astonishing images of Jupiter that revealed an unusual weather phenomena in the planet's atmosphere. The astronomers spotted a high-speed jet stream in Jupiter's atmosphere just over the equator about 25 miles above the cloud layer. Incredibly, the jet stream is more than 3,000 miles wide and travels around 320 miles per hour, "twice the sustained winds of a Category 5 hurricane here on Earth," according toNASA. "This is something that totally surprised us," said University of the Basque Country physicist Ricardo Hueso who co-authored the study reporting these results in the scientific journalNature Astronomy. "We knew the different wavelengths of Webb and Hubble would reveal the three-dimensional structure of storm clouds, but we were also able to use the timing of the data to see how rapidly storms develop," said study coauthor Michael Wong, planetary scientist at the University of California, Berkeley, who led the associated Hubble observations, in a statement. The two telescopes provided a broader look at Jupiter's complex atmosphere and the processes taking place within the layers.

text: The U.S. Department of Energy is distributing $36 million to 11 scientific projects that aim to help quantify exactly how much carbon potential ocean projects would be locking away. The basic idea behind ocean-based carbon removal has been around for decades: With a bit of human manipulation, the oceans could suck up billions of tons of carbon dioxide and take care of some of the world’sclimatewoes. Right now, such approaches are only able to remove a negligible amount of carbon from the atmosphere. They would need to be scaled up hundreds of thousands or even millions of times more to make a difference in the decades ahead. If they work, such engineering-heavy carbon removal methods—or simpler efforts like planting millions of trees—would need to come in alongside rapid worldwide emissions cuts in order for humanity to meet its climate goals. It's a subset of the nascent, venture capital fueled carbon removal industry, which also includes better known approaches likeClimeWorks’scarbon-sucking fans in Iceland.

text: Colin Kaepernick has filed a grievance against the National Football League, accusing owners of colluding to keep him from playing. Kaepernick received national attention last year when he knelt at a football game during the national anthem. At the end of last season, the quarterback opted out of his contract with the 49ers and entered free agency, allowing him to play with other teams. But Kaepernick has yet to sign with a new team. His grievance accuses team owners of violating the league’s collective bargaining agreement. Kaepernick was most recently snubbed by the Tennessee Titans, who denied him the chance to work after the team's current quarterback was injured. The quarterback threw 16 touchdowns with four interceptions in a matter of 12 games with the San Francisco 49ers last season. It is highly unusual for quarterbacks to spend so long in freeagency, especially one with a record as good as Kaepernick's. The NFL is currently in the middle of a season-long bye week, which is expected to be followed by the start of the new NFL season on September 14, according to reports from 6 ABC and Bleacher Report. The league is also in the midst of a preseason game against the New England Patriots, which will take place on Sunday, September 17. The game will be the first of the season for the Philadelphia Eagles, who are looking for a new quarterback after signing Carson Wentz last week. The Eagles are expected to pick up a player in the draft on September 21, and the pick will be announced on September 22.

text: John Hammack of Madras, Oregon, killed while battling a central Oregon wildfire. Hammack died and another firefighter was injured when the top of a tree broke off and crashed down. Thousands of firefighters fought to snuff out or at least contain blazes that had burned more than 40,000 acres (16,200 hectares) of timber and range land across Oregon. In neighboring Washington state, more than 2,100 firefighters were making steady progress against a pair of blazes, a spokeswoman said. The current fire season has been particularly deadly in the U.S. West, with 19 Arizona firefighters killed in June. and two people perished after being caught in a blaze in Colorado. Friday morning lightning strikes sparked dozens of new fires, an official said, adding that emergency crews were helped by cooler temperatures and higher humidity, a streak likely to end next week with hotter weather and possibly more lightning-bearing storms. The Colockum Tarps fire burning south of Wenatchee was 30 percent contained as of Friday morning. About 45 structures remained at high risk from the so-called Mile Marker 28 fire burning close to the Oregon border, a Forest Service official and a spokeswoman for firefighting efforts said. That fire has scorched more than 80,000. acres (32,375 hectares) in less than a week, has claimed three houses and five other buildings, including three outhouses.

text: Drunk Feminist Films is a group of women who like to watch films they love without letting them off the hook. The group pokes fun at the shortcomings and tropes of mainstream Hollywood films. The first film to be drunkenly mocked was everyone’s favorite vampire love story, “Twilight.” Today, DFF has 13 rotating cast members who, when they’re not smashing the patriarchy, work as comedians, writers, social workers, public servants and designers. The in-person happenings, which regularly sell out, invite angry viewers to yell at the screen, throw things, and release all the pent-up tension that comes from secretly loving “Save the Last Dance” despite knowing that Julia Stiles has absolutely no rhythm, like none, in the movie “ save the last dance.“I think it's a way to sort of alleviate some of the guilt,” cast member Resh Brown said in a phone interview with The Huffington Post. “A lot of these movies, as Resh said, have this element of nostalgia. I think there is something about commiserating with people that helps you make peace with your own problematic past,’” co-founder Gillian Goerz said. ‘We aim jokes at the oppressor and the system (and sometimes the fashion), not those experiencing oppression.’ The first element of a DFF screening is choosing a film with a lovable movie with a truthful, empathetic storytelling.

text: Alderman Michael Mainelli will become the 695th Lord Mayor of London on Saturday. He will be taken to Westminster in a gold carriage to swear loyalty to the crown. A Ukraine-themed float, artist Jim Moir - known as comedian Vic Reeves - and 2,000 troops are set to take part. The show is one of the oldest processions in the world, dating back to the 13th century. It will start at Mansion House, before travelling to the Royal Courts via St Paul's Cathedral and returning via the Embankment and Victoria Street. Saturday's event, which is being broadcast on BBC One, will "bring together 7,000 people, including charities, school children, community groups, the armed forces, 250 horses, and over 150 floats in a three-mile-long parade", said Alderman Mainelli. The event is expected to last up to three hours and will be followed by a reception at the Mayor's residence at St James' Palace, London.

text: At least 29 people have been killed and more than 113,000 displaced following heavy rains and flash flooding in Kenya and Somalia. Kenyan weather forecasters have been warning the country since September to expect heavy precipitation between October and December. El Nino, a naturally occurring weather phenomenon, causes surface waters of the central and eastern Pacific to warm, affecting weather patterns around the world. The heavy rains come one year after the horn of Africa suffered its worst drought in around 40 years, which along with rising prices in food due to war in Ukraine, caused 43,000 people to die, according to the U.N. The severe weather also affected the Somali region of Ethiopia, where crops failed to grow and thousands were displaced from their homes.. text: In 2011, I made a film called Zero Silence. It was a documentary film about young people in the Middle East who have grown angry over the authoritarian regimes they live in. Among other topics, the production will explore the impact of the Internet and non-traditional media such as Facebook, YouTube, and Twitter and whistle-blowing sites on the Arab world and beyond and to what extent these digital media tools can spur society change. During that time, I met Elissa. A Jazz singer from Lebanon who talked about the risk of being an artist there. This is her story. She told me about her experience of living in Lebanon and how she was able to make a difference in the country. She said: 'I am a survivor. I am not a victim. I'm a survivor of the Arab Spring. I have been through a lot and I am going to continue to go through the same thing. I will continue to fight injustice and injustice in my own way. I want to be a part of the solution to the problems that I am facing in the Arab World. I don't want to just sit back and wait for things to happen to me. I need to do my part in the fight against injustice in the region and in the world." She said. "I want to do what I can to help change the world. That is what I am trying to do."

The soap contains certain molecules that stimulate the immune system, so when someone uses it, it can revive immune cells in the skin so they're able to fight the melanoma. "There's definitely still a lot more for me to learn, and I'm really excited to see where all that takes me," he said of his future plans. text: U.S. climate envoy John Kerry says talks this week with his Chinese counterpart resulted in "some agreement" on climate issues. Kerry said, "I am hopeful about that," adding that details of the agreements would be released soon. The U.N. Climate Change Conference, known as COP28, is scheduled for the end of this month in Dubai. The climate conference seeks to meet and expand on climate goals established during the Paris agreement of 2015, in which some 200 nations agreed to limit the rise of global temperatures to 1.5 degrees Celsius, or about pre-industrial age levels."It is irresponsible to be funding or building a coal-fired power plant anywhere in the world," Kerry said at the Bloomberg New Economy Forum in Singapore on Friday. "Who is allowed to get away with doing that, when it is not the only option for what we could be doing?" he said.. The use of fossil fuels in particular is likely to be a central part of the discussion at the conference.

text: The salty expanse of Lake Urmia in Iran has been drying up and shrinking for decades. As the lake dries out, its salinity increases. The warm water’s high salt concentration makes it a prime breeding ground for algae. A family of bacteria called Halobacteriaceae use a red pigment to absorb sunlight and convert it into energy.“If land use and water consumption remain as it is now, then the lake would disappear pretty soon,” says a biologist at the University of Tehran. “There's no doubt about that,’ says Hossein Akhani, a scientist at the university. ‘If you want to see it, you have to go to it.’” The lake was once one of the world's largest brine shrimp habitats, but water loss and higher salinity are cutting into their growth and reproduction, says Akhani. The lake has lost about 70 percent of its surface area in the past 14 years, according to satellite observations. It is now a stained red pool, with sharp, white salt crystals left behind by evaporation now surround the shrinking pool, driving away tourists and migratory birds. It has happened before, but as drought and agricultural use persist in the region, red waters may become a more common sight, says a scientist in Tehran, Iran. The color-changing process may also be due to the production of protective carotenoids in the cells of the micro-algae.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Subglacial discharge from the Antarctic Ice Sheet (AIS) likely played a crucial role in the loss of ice sheet and the subsequent rise in sea level during the last deglaciation. The uranium isotopic composition of seawater is a potential tracer for subglacial. discharge and thus ice-sheet stability in the past. Researchers carried out a high-resolution deep-sea coral234U/238U records from the Drake Passage in the Southern Ocean. The findings provide an important reference for predicting possible future changes in the Antarctic ice sheet. The study was published inNature Communicationson Nov. 13, 2014, by Assoc. Prof. Li Tao from the Nanjing Institute of Geology and Paleontology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (NIGPAS) and a team of researchers from the University of Bristol, University of St Andrews, and Nanjing University. The researchers found distinctively higher seawater.234U and238U values from 15,400 to 14,000 years ago, corresponding to the period of the highest iceberg-rafted debris flux.
label: SAFE

text: Cannabix Technologies Inc. is a developer of breath testing devices for law enforcement and the workplace. The Company is nearing completion of its first commercial version of its CAB device. The CAB automatically checks the sobriety of employees when they come to work. The device takes a picture while a breath sample is being delivered to confirm and record identity and allows for quick input of an employee identification code for system logging. Cannabix is consulting with an established distributor and vendor of alcohol devices in Australia and will be opening up distribution relationships with alcohol device vendors in the United States. More recently the Company has been examining the use of the CAB as a new solution for the24/7 Sobriety Programexisting in several states in the U.S. This program seeks to reduce the re-arrests of individuals previously convicted of driving while under the influence (DUI) of alcohol or drugs through daily breath testing. The company has developed an innovative pre-calibrated modular cartridge technology.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Fire Draw Near is a monthly podcast dedicated to the history of Irish folk songs. In each episode, Ian Lynch breaks down a song's narrative, discusses its various interpretations, and how these different iterations came about. You can give Fire Draw Near a listen on Spotify or SoundCloud (links below). You can hear Lankum's drone-folk interpretations of a few classics here. The complexity of marrying oral tradition with the printed word is a rich topic, and the songs that come about from this union are beautiful and storied. The band has a thorough history and appreciation for the music they are adapting, though it's apparent in the work on its own. Lankum tends to follow in the funeral dirge tradition. Compare their version of Wild Rover to the Dubliner's own. One tells the tale of a pub regular, recounting the hijinks that drinking hath bestowed upon him to his compatriots. The other is a mourner's lament of the curse of lady alcohol. Roughly the same lyrics, not at all the same song.
label: SENSITIVE

text: James Park, a prominent soccer athlete, is under investigation for violating anti-doping regulations. The case has sparked discussions about the pressures athletes face and the importance of clean competition. Sports organizations are reviewing their testing protocols to ensure comprehensive coverage. Athlete education programs emphasize the risks of performance-enhancing drugs to health and career. It is expected that the case is expected to be resolved within the next few months. The investigation into James Park is being handled by the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency (USADA) The case is currently under investigation by the USADA and will be resolved by the end of the year. The USADA is investigating James Park for violating the anti- doping regulations of the World Anti- Doping Agency. It's expected that this will be a short-term investigation and that Park will not be charged with any crime. The probe is being conducted by the United States Department of Justice (US DOJ) and is being overseen by the American Center for Disease Control and Prevention (ACDCP) The investigation is ongoing and the case has not yet been resolved. The U.N. has not commented on the case. The American Center is investigating the case and will provide a statement when it is completed. The issue is being looked into by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and the International Football Association (IFAC) for any further action to be taken against James Park. It has been reported that Park has not been charged with a crime.
label: SENSITIVE

text: In some states, like Arizona and Idaho, the number of large fires burning each year has tripled or even quadrupled. Over the same span, average spring and summer temperatures across 11 Western states have increased by more than 1.5°F, contributing to the higher fire risks. In 2012, thin spring snowpack and above-average spring temperatures contributed to the biggest wildfire year in a decade in Arizona. Researchers predict that the area burned in the West will quadruple for every additional 1.8°F of temperature rise. In the past decade, more wildfires have burned in Utah in most of those years than any year in the 1970s. Every year since 2004 since 2004, every year in Arizona has seen more fires in Arizona than in any year since 1970. Spring snowpack has been decreasing dramatically in Nevada since the early 1980s. And in 2012, the lowest springSnowpack in more than 30 years, combined with above- average spring temperatures, helped fuel the biggest fire year in Colorado for more than a decade. The interactive map also includes a preliminary analysis of mountain snowpack data collected at hundreds of monitoring stations across the West. The data was analyzed according to the methodology described in the Heat Is On, but for the Western states, data was based on larger, 1,000-acre fires that burned on U.S. Forest Service land in the summer of 2012. The heat is on, but the year-to-year variations in wildfires depend on several factors, including temperatures, snowpack, and how large the previous year’s wildfires were.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Committee of MPs had raised concerns over a lack of health services. But the government said on Friday that extra emergency funding was not needed. Lincolnshire grower Henry Moreton currently has 155 acres (0.6 sq km) of land under water. He estimates he has lost between £55,000 and £65,000 worth of oil seed rape, winter wheat and barley to flooding after Storm Babet hit last week. Mr Moreton said he felt the government "did not really care about farmers" but acknowledged more needed to reach out for help, saying: "Farmers are our own worst enemy. We never want to admit we are weak and we are very good at saying we are absolutely fine when we're not." If you have been affected by any issues raised in this article, help and support can be found at the BBC Action Line on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or see www.samaritans.org. text: Scientists have uncovered that violent star collisions, known as kilonovae, have the potential to pose a catastrophic threat to our planet due to the lethal release of radiation. The collision of neutron stars, each containing a mass equivalent to approximately one billion tons within a mere teaspoon, results in a particle explosion capable of annihilating our planet's ozone layer. If a neutron star merger were to occur within around 36 light-years of Earth, the resulting radiation could cause an extinction-level event. The specific distance of safety and component that is most dangerous is uncertain as many of the effects depend on properties like viewing angle to the event, the energy of the blast, the mass of material ejected, and more,” Haille Perkins, a researcher at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, said. But Perkins also assured panic is not necessary — kilonova are “rare.”“There are several other more common events like solar flares, asteroid impacts, and supernova explosions that have a better chance of being harmful,’ Perkins said.
label: SENSITIVE

text: This is a poem I wrote circa 2005. It first appeared on Youtube. Of why he fought and wherefore he fell ought not to be Of what we dwell As we lay to rest our martyr's holiest of devotions. We too beseech our soldier-friend to forgive us when War and woes have made us foes of dead men being Our lost souls. --Yet, no evil ever be as great as thee As when menfolk are turned to warring hordes; And no one asks for what their tasks The sabres and the swords. Therefore, let no man ever say the query of why we fight today Be treasonous atrocity! Saving at hollowed place we let known our grace As we entomb our Son of bloom with sincerest generosity. And so curse not our folly as we sully Your goodly name for our most fallible convictions, Even though we desecrate and by default repudiate The sanctity of your most horrible of afflictions. --Still, no matter what we speak and say, even less of our Deeds today, Shall be yet seen as vanity's rage and roar. For Death enlightens the orbs awake to no more ache As it brings sight to all our fleeting might But being sand-castles forged on breaking shores. And we also implore the Mystery above to greet him With infinite love As he chariots to golden fields foretold of ancient scrolls. We hope that he will wade in eternal everlasting. For we are here not to cheer and even less to jeer.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Jaden Smith has been leaving works of art outside art galleries in Los Angeles. Smith recently attached himself to Shia LaBeouf’s ongoing, anti-Trump livestream “He Will Not Divide Us,” which was relocated to Albuquerque, New Mexico, following a chaotic run in New York. He has been very vocal about his passion for the arts as of late. He recently tweeted that he left a piece of art at Living Spaces in Van Nuys. If that owner is you ― pics or it didn’t happen. If you see a mediocre Basquiat knockoff lying around outside an art gallery, you may just be staring at an original Jaden Smith. Keep making art, keeping leaving art, keep being art. The Twitter sage and planetary citizen has been tweeting about his love of the arts for the past few months. He also recently posted a photo of a painting he left outside a art gallery in San Fernando, California, saying, “I Just Left My Art Piece Here, Come Get It.” He has also posted a picture of a piece he left at a museum in Santa Monica, California.

text: Stephen Hawking said President Donald Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris accord could cause irreversible harm to the planet. In an interview with the BBC in honor of Hawking’s 75th birthday, the Cambridge professor said Trump will cause “avoidable environmental damage” The president announced the decision last month, arguing that the agreement was a “bad deal” for the U.S. As multiple experts, scientists and world leaders pointed out, the deal was nonbinding and had largely been negotiated to meet U.N. expectations. “We are close to the tipping point where global warming becomes irreversible,” he said. ‘We could push the Earth over the brink, to become like Venus, with a temperature of two hundred and fifty degrees, and raining sulphuric acid,’ Hawking said in an interview in March with Piers Morgan on ITV”s “Good Morning Britain” Hawking said the president should get rid of Scott Pruitt, a climate change denier, as the leader of the Environmental Protection Agency. � “It affects America badly, so tackling it should win votes for his second term — God forbid” “Climate change is one of the great dangers we face, and it's one we can prevent," he said in a March interview with ITV's “ good morning Britain.’ ‘Tackling it should be a campaign issue for the next president, so that he can make a difference.”
label: SENSITIVE

text: Dear Data is a data visualization art collaboration between Giorgia Lupi and Stefanie Posavec. Since Sept. 1, 2014, the designers have been sending each other weekly, hand-illustrated postcards visualizing data about their own lives tracked over the past week. The project highlights the possibilities offered by creative design. The designers will complete the collaboration with 52 postcards apiece, “a mosaic of one year of our lives, in data and drawings,” as they put it."Beauty and functionality together achieve extraordinary outcomes!" said Lupi. 'We are trying to show how data is not scary, is not necessarily ‘big,’ but is ever present in everyone’s lives,' said PosaveC. 'There is a huge potential to explore a more human way to measure personal experiences without reducing it to a simple quantification,' Lupi said. 'The goal, of course, is a balanced marriage between the two. "Beauty, functionality and design together achieveextraordinary outcomes," Lupi added. 'Dear Data' is a collaboration between Accurat, a New York-based design studio, and Stefani Posaveh, a London-based information designer and data visualization expert. For more information on Dear Data, visit Accurat's website. The end of the project is scheduled for September 1, 2015, and the two will complete it with a series of postcards the following week, each depicting a different aspect of their lives.
label: SAFE

text: Two recent productions by small theatre companies in Berkeley focused on fictional American families. Both playwrights provoked nervous (and sometimes explosive) laughter from the audience. Each and every one of the survivors was a case study in emotionally damaged goods. In each play, the decedent's daughters was a victim of chronic episodes of domestic violence. In the final scene, Curtis has landed in the hospital after being assaulted by a spoiled brat who refuses to eat a bratty sandwich he's served to his brother-in-law. The audience quickly grasps that this is a marriage whose partners have never really listened to each other or shown much concern for one another's needs. The Lyons is directed by Will Marchetti and stars Ellen Ratner, Jessica Bates, Nicholas Pelczar and Joe Estlack. The play is at Berkeley Repertory Theater until April 14. For more information, visit www.berkeleyrepertory.org. For tickets to The Lyons, call the box office at BerkeleyRepertory Theatre at (510) 615-8255 or go to http://www.berlinrepertoire.org/. For more about The Lyons and other plays at Berkeleyrepertorial.org, go to www.BerlinRepertorium.org/TheLyons. For information about The Tragedy of Macbeth, visit http://bit.ly/tragedy-of-macbeth-the-play.

text: A myth about the Taj Mahal goes that when it was completed as an Agra, India palace for Shah Jahan's wife, the mogul had the hands of the 20,000 workmen cut off so they could never construct a building that might equal or surpass it in beauty. Rajiv Joseph has constructed Guards at the Taj, a darkly mesmerizing play around the 17th-century occurrence, now at the Atlantic. When Joseph requires Humayun and Babur to wade in the red-red water, they become emotional, Metwally and Moayed are thoroughly prepared for that. There's no possibility of declaring the Taj easy on the eyes and ears, but there's no likelihood of following through on the temptation to look away, while the temptation is strong to look through the eyes of the Guards atThe Taj. The playwright is examining the wages of guilt. It's a theme that always has cogency and is certainly pressing as presented in this unexpected perspective. Ultimately, none of the three actors recoiled from the script's lengthy demands -- until the characters can't resist turning to look at the finished TajMahal, which is just a few feet away from them. The story is so colorful in its macabre way that it continues to be told, but the play is too morbid for non-stop yuks. It has some comic elements, but, considering all that's preceded the HumayUn-Babur activities, Joseph's Guards at The Taj isToo morbid forNon-stop Yuks!
label: UNSAFE

text: recruitment for the IT sector has remained muted, while the demand for functional skills such as Development, ERP, Automotive Design, Testing, and Administration, among others, has surged in the second quarter (Q2) of FY24, a new report revealed on Tuesday. According to the business solutions provider Quess Corp, about 65 per cent of the aggregate demand emerged from Development and ERP skills. "For the first time in recent history, large IT services companies have shown a decline in headcount and reduced guidance values, signalling a collective exercise of caution in navigating the future," said Vijay Sivaram, CEO of Quess IT Staffing. The IT sector in India is experiencing a notable transformation as it expands beyond its initial technology hub, Bengaluru. Emerging tech hubs like Pune, Hyderabad, Mumbai, Chennai, and Delhi NCR are gaining prominence. This shift is driven by their flourishing tech industries and the presence of both domestic and international companies, propelling them to become established, mature technology hubs in India.
label: SAFE

text: Electric aviation is a small segment of the industry that is steadily expanding its capabilities. The energy requirements of even the smallest of aircraft are in an entirely different league compared to cars. Existing battery technology simply hasn’t yet reached the energy density levels required to power anything more than the smallest categories of aircraft on a short flight. The Elektra Trainer used in the E-Flight Challenge, for example, can carry a maximum of two people. Adding larger battery packs doesn't work in an aircraft – it would just add a massive weight penalty that could seriously impair the performance. In 2021, Europe is trying to ditch trains for electric planes, since the idea of a large passenger aircraft seems currently unattainable. Only then will we be able to decide exactly what will be the right solution for which part of the market, says Robin Riedel, partner at consultancy firm McKinsey Riedels & Co. In 2022, a Swedish startup that has racked up orders and investment from United Airlines and other prominent industry players – announced that it was dropping pure electric propulsion for the aircraft they’re developing.
label: SAFE

text: Rephrase.ai provides a text-to-video generation platform that helps users create professional looking videos. Adobe will look to integrate Rephrase’s tech stack and generative AI video capabilities with its in-house video-editing platform, Creative Cloud. The transaction is expected to help Adobe accelerate its ability to provide AI-powered video content tools to its customers. This also marks the first-ever deal for Adobe in the generative. AI and video-tooling space. It also makes Rephrases the first Indian startup to be acquired by Adobe, which has largely struck such deals in its home market, the US, and in Europe. The firm, founded by IIT Bombay graduates, Malhotra, Nisheeth Lahoti and IIT Roorkee alumni Shivam Mangla, has raised $13.9 million till date. In September, last year, the company raised $10.6 million in a round led by US media company Red Ventures.
label: SAFE

text: Hulu's "The Handmaid's Tale" includes a splash of blood in the third episode. Showrunner Bruce Miller said the show needed to be unflinching if it was going to be successful. Miller said filming close-in on Offred, to create a claustrophobic effect that would emulate her oppression, would be stylistically key. To create a woman character who thinks and feels on her own terms is a feminist act, and certainly to read the book is afeminist experience, Atwood said in a recent New York Times op-ed. The author has taken issue with certain aspects of early feminism, which took a stand against feminine modes of self-expression, and has said that the story is about power dynamics more broadly, and could’ve been told from a man’s point of view. The show's star, Elisabeth Moss, has since wheeled back on the comments, saying, "It's just a story about a woman,” actress Madeline Brewer said, when asked whether she got involved with the story because of its feminist themes. “You feel every emotion go across her face, even when she wants to hide from the rest of the world, and that was so frustrating,’ Miller said of filming close in on Moss' character, Offred. "We’re so used to being able to hop on the internet or watch TV or ask somebody a question, and all of that was lost all of the time," Miller said.
label: UNSAFE

text: Michael Levi is a senior fellow for energy and environment with the Council on Foreign Relations. The video is part of a series of interviews with speakers, attendees and panelists at The Aspen Ideas Festival, produced by The Huffington Post in conjunction with the Aspen Institute. text: California ends its "miracle" water year with enough rain and snow to fill reservoirs. State officials measured 33.56 inches (85.2 centimeters) of precipitation through the end of September. Statewide, reservoirs held 27.4 million acre feet of stored water as September ended. One acre foot of water is enough to supply two families of four for a year. The potential for more strong storms this year, particularly along the coast, “keeps me awake a little bit at night,” said Gary Lippner, deputy director for flood management and dam safety with the California Department of Water Resources. The state's rainy season could be complicated by El Nino — the natural, temporary and occasional warming of part of the Pacific Ocean. It's just the fourth time since 1950 the state's snowpack exceeded 200% of average, according to Michael Anderson, a state's climatologist. The storms also dumped tons of snow on the mountains, filling rushing rivers and reservoirs.
label: SAFE

text: Olive oil prices, driven in part by two years of drought inSpain, has meant opportunity for criminals. Warehouse break-ins, dilution of premium oil with inferior product, and falsification of shipping data are on the rise. Gangs using chainsaws to steal heavily laden branches and even entire trees from unguarded groves. The crimes mean fewer olives for growers already contending with high production costs and climate change. in Greece, a 1-liter bottle of extra virgin oil jumped from $8 to $9 last year to as much as $15 this year. in Spain, a company has developed tracking devices that look like olives to try and catch thieves. in Italy’s southern Puglia region, growers are pleading with police to form an agriculture division. in February, six people were arrested in southern Greece for the theft of 8 tons of olive oil in a series of warehouse break-in over several weeks. The global olive oil market has been disrupted by a nearly two-year drought in Spain. It's expected to shrink global production to 2.5 million metric tons this crop year.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Saturday's Yankee-Red Sox game was a 16-inning, nearly six-hour uber-marathon. Bob Greene: Baseball is a pastoral sport in a digital age, but even Springsteen stops the show after three hours. Greene: Night baseball games should start no later than 7. He says relief pitchers should be prohibited from throwing warm-up pitches on the field, and commercials: cut one thirty-second spot between innings and, viola, you have just cut at least eight minutes per game. The average length of a 2017 postseason game was nearly three and a half hours, Greene says. The seventh game of last year’s World Series started on a Wednesday night, a few minutes after 8, and ended at 12:30, he says. It's not just the length of the games destroying the sport, it's the start and end times, he writes. The next move would be to designate fans as fair ball or foul fielders, Greene writes. “The extra-inning death march can no longer be tolerated,” Captain Picard said once, “once the line must be drawn here’t it?” he says, ”Once the line is drawn here, the ball must be thrown here.’‘No more playing Kate Smith” during the 7th inning stretch at Yankee Stadium, not unless they are going to follow it with Woody Guthrie’S “This Land Is Your Land” But no, that would add more time to the game.
label: SAFE

text: Sarah Ali aced the Common University Entrance Test Undergraduate (CUET UG) in 2022 by scoring 800/ 800 in the exam. She is doing a BA Psychology (Honours) and a minor in Sociology at Delhi University’s Lady Shri Ram College. Eighteen-year-old Ali scored 96 per cent overall marks in Class 10 and Class 12. She selected English, history, political science and psychology to appear for in CUET2022. Ali shares how she prepared for the CUET and why she chose LSR College over others. She says: "I think having a supportive environment where it is just other women and you do not have to be judged is really a haven. The college also offers a lot of other opportunities in the form of societies where almost everybody finds their niche and some opportunity that interests them and helps them grow" She is now involved in an animal welfare project. She also got to work with the college magazine and a couple of editorial boards.
label: SAFE

text: If we stay the course, the first humans will set foot on the Red Planet by the year 2033. The key to this architecture is to separate much of the supplies and equipment and send them in advance of the crew. The largest payload elements, such as the surface habitat and the ascent vehicle to return the crew to Mars orbit, weigh 30 to 40 metric tons. Improved entry, descent, and landing (EDL) approaches will safely and precisely land larger payloads on the surface of Mars. With a sustained program of activities over the next 10 to 15 years, we will eliminate the knowledge gaps that remain and we will build up an infrastructure that is capable of sustaining human missions, says Joe Cassady, Executive Director, Aerojet Rocketdyne. This piece is part of a special op-ed series, Explore Mars, curated with diverse contributors in public interest, in which we incorporate a combination of technology, public interest and political will to incorporate Mars into the overall structure of our future space program. We need to take the first step that proves the possibility that we may be living at the perfect time – a time when Mars beckons us and may be the perfect place for us to walk on Mars. We are going to Mars, twenty years and counting! NASA is already working on improved decelerators and other techniques such as supersonic retro propulsion. Such technologies need to be perfected within the next ten years, because the most massive payload elements will need about four years to be prepositioned.
label: SAFE

text: As drought conditions worsen in Central Texas, local leaders are promoting innovative water conservation strategies. Greywater recycling systems are being installed in public buildings as demonstration projects. Schools are incorporating water conservation education into science curricula. Community gardens are shifting to drought-tolerant crops. Emergency water supplies have been secured, and officials are confident the region can weather the drought with continued conservation efforts. The drought is expected to last through the end of the year, according to the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. The National Weather Service has issued a severe drought alert for the area until April 15. The agency is urging residents to conserve water and to use alternate sources of water if possible. For more information, go to www.weather.gov/texas. text: Inflation is coming down, but it doesn't mean everything will get cheaper. President Joe Biden's administration recently released theFifth National Climate Assessment. The report analyzes the risks the climate crisis poses, and how those risks could threaten Americans and the economy. The impacts of the crisis will keep getting worse without significant action, and it'll increasingly strain Americans' budget as they struggle to afford basic household needs. It'll especially harm low-income and minority communities who live in areas with inefficient cooling systems and poor insulation. But the Federal Reserve has expressed confidence the country is moving in the direction it needs to reach the central bank's 2% inflation target. The Consumer Price Index, which measures inflation,increased 3.2% year-over-year in October, marking a decrease from the 3.7% reading a month prior. The Fed still does not forecast a recession right now, but the government's climate assessment casted a shadow on the economy's recovery. It added that "household consumers face higher costs for goods and services, like groceries and health insurance premiums, as prices change"
label: SENSITIVE

text: Becca Longo is the first woman to receive a football scholarship at an NCAA Division II school or higher. She signed a letter of intent to play for Adams State University in Colorado. Longo made 30 of 33 extra-point attempts and hit a 30-yard field goal last season for Basha High School in Chandler, Arizona. About a dozen women have played football for NCAA schools but none was on a scholarship, according to CNN. The Arizona Republic reports that coach Timm Rosenbach says Longo has "a strong leg, and she can be very accurate” and "can be competitive" and "very accurate" in the kicking game. She also plans to play basketball for the school in Alamosa, Colorado, the Arizona Republic says. "I’m just so unbelievably grateful that somebody game me a chance," Longo tells ABC 15 of the scholarship offer. "She has a strong leg," says coach Rosenbach, a former NFL quarterback. "There is no doubt she canBe competitive,” Adams State coach says of Longo, who can connect from 48 yards out and 30 yards out. “I was completely shocked. I was so excited,’’ Longo says of being a pioneer in collegiate athletics. 'I was just so excited,' she says of the offer, which she says she was "completely shocked" to receive. 'She can be competitive,' says the coach, who says she has a "strong leg' and can be " very accurate"

text: Negotiators for the EU's member states and lawmakers reach a deal on new rules to curb methane emissions. The provisional deal, which still needs to be formally approved to become law, was struck just two weeks before the start of COP28, the UN climate summit in Dubai. It requires the fossil fuel energy sector to have new measures to track and monitor methane gas emissions, and to prevent leaks. It bans routine venting and flaring and limits non-routing flared and venting to only when it is unavoidable. It also calls for methane monitoring measures on imports of oil, gas and coal into the European Union, to be introduced in three phases. The European Commission hailed Wednesday's agreement as "crucial" to the EU’s fight against climate change and says that, over a century, methane has an effect 28 times greater than that of carbon dioxide on global warming, and over a 20-year timescale it is 84 times more potent than carbon dioxide, it says.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Pittsburgh is praised for welcoming driverless cars, cultivating a young new food scene and being one of the most livable places in the country. Yet we can't seem to shake the stigma that our style isn’t keeping up (just ask GQ). As a street style photographer in Pittsburgh, I have the freedom to capture the style I admire, and let me tell you, there’s plenty. We have to prove that as a city, we are more than just Antonio Brown jerseys and mismatched outfits, and that we really do take pride in our personal aesthetics. That's why I feel a responsibility to showcase that style in a public way. Of course we take pride. in the things that have always defined our city, but it�'s important for the new generation to know we have more to offer, so they too can take Pride in PGH. I’ve learned, firsthand, that’re simply not the case. I want to show the world that Pittsburgh is not just a city of sports fans and Yinzers, but that we have a lot more going for us than that. I hope you'll join me in sharing some of our favorite Pittsburgh moments with your friends and family over the next few weeks. I'll be in touch via Twitter and Instagram @KeepPittsburghDope and @pittsburghdope. For more information on Keep Pittsburgh Dope, go to keeppgh.com/keep-pgh or go to www.pgh-style.com.

text: Over 265 young girls and women have accused former USA Gymnastics and Michigan State University team doctor Larry Nassar of sexual abuse. Judge Janice Cunningham announced the updated number on Wednesday in a Charlotte, Michigan, courtroom during Nassar’s second sentencing hearing. The three counts Nassar is being sentenced for include two girls between the ages of 13 and 15 years old, and one who is under 13. Nassar pleaded guilty to all three counts in November and is expected to receive a minimum of 25 to 40 years in prison. A large number of the 265 identified survivors are the 156 women who read their impact statements in court during the weeklong sentencing hearing that began on Jan. 16. Another 65 survivors are expected to read impact statements during this hearing, expected to go into next week. Many of the women said they were inspired to come forward with their stories after listening to the 150-plus women give their impact statement last week. “No high schooler should have to know the inside of a court as well as I do,” victim and former gymnast Jessica Thomashow said in the first statement. "It takes a monster backed by ego, experience and power, fueled by multiple institutions, to sexually assault a child in front of their own mother," said Tiffany Dutton, who says her mother was in the room when Nassar molested her. "For the rest of my life, I’m going to have to heal from what you did," one victim said.
label: UNSAFE
