text: Grey whales migrate through the Bering Strait and some go as far north as Point Barrow, Alaska. A few will make it all the way east from there to the Beaufort Sea, perhaps as far east as Canada. Others will cross the Chukchi Sea going northwest into the Siberian Sea. In Barrow I heard how the grey whales had helped forge alliances between Yupik Eskimos in Russia and Inupiat EskimOS in the US. Both communities depend on hunting marine mammals, including whales, for survival. These cultural bonds are stronger than differences in nationality and location. We're backtracking a little on the migration route, the ferries are infrequent and this was the only way we could fit it in. Last stop. Kodiak here we come. We've somehow managed to miss them at every single stop since. Some places they just didn't show up that day, and one time the sea was too rough for us to go out on the water looking for them. I'm desperate to show my son that the mother and baby whale pairs have travelled allThe way up here too, and to see them for myself. I've been travelling by train, bus, boat and taking a few plane rides when we had no other option. We came up through Los Angeles, Monterey Bay, Depot Bay in Oregon, the San Juan Islands, past Vancouver Island and through the Inside Passage to Alaska. It's inspiring to hear how the whales have bridged international relationships and thrilling that they are now here in their Alaskan feeding grounds.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Storm Babet and Storm Ciarán have left ground waterlogged. Some organisers said they would try to rearrange their events, but most said cancellation was the only option. Bosses at the centre, based in East Kirkby, said rainfall over the last two weeks had taken the car parks and grass landing strip to a condition which would not be safe to use. Anyone with tickets would receive a refund, they added. Meanwhile, the Caistor and District Lions Club has cancelled its display and the event in Bourne will also not now go ahead. Both were due to be held on Saturday. Spilsby Rotary club also cancelled its fireworks event which was due to take place on Sunday. It said the decision was "not taken lightly" and said it was a decision it had made to protect the public's safety and the safety of its members. The company maintained its full-year forecast for the console of 15 million units, which would be a 16.5% decline from the year earlier. This year has been a stand-out one for the release of new games across the industry, after the pandemic caused widespread disruption to development. text: NASA's Lucy spacecraft will make its first asteroid flyby on November 1. The flyby will be used to test out the spacecraft’s system for locating an asteroid and locking its instruments onto its location as it flies past. With the tracking system in place, the spacecraft should be able to point its cameras more precisely and collect more accurate data. Lucy is on its way to the orbit of Jupiter tostudy the Trojan asteroidsthere. It won’t arrive there until 2027, but the spacecraft will have the opportunity to do some extra science before then, as it will soon be making a flyby of another asteroid called Dinkinesh. At less than half a mile wide, this small asteroid sits in the main asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter, and it will be Lucy”s first asteroidFlyby. It will take nearly 30 minutes for the first signal to make it to Earth. The spacecraft is so far away it takes about 30 minutes to travel between the spacecraft and Earth.
label: SAFE

text: British-born scientists David Thouless, Duncan Haldane and Michael Kosterlitz won the 2016 Nobel Prize for Physics. Their studies of unusual states of matter may open up new applications in electronics. Physics is the second of this year’s crop of Nobels and comes after the prize for medicine on Monday. The prizes were first awarded in 1901 to honour achievements in science, literature and peace in accordance with the will of Swedish dynamite inventor and business tycoon Alfred Nobel, who left much of his wealth to establish the award. Click here to follow the Nobel Prize news LIVE. to see how the prize was awarded and to follow back-up for your copy of the latest Nobel Prize in Physics on CNN.com. Back to the page you came from.  http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/world-news/2016/01/26/nobel-prize-for-physics-takes-tongue-in-cheek-by-David-Thouless-and-Duncan-Haldane-who-discovered-unusual-states-of-matter.html#storylink=cpy. The trio's discoveries, using advanced mathematics, had boosted research in condensed matter physics and raised hopes for uses in new generations of electronics and superconductors. The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences awarded the 8 million Swedish crown ($937,000) prize to the trio. They join the ranks of some of the greatest names in science including Albert Einstein, Niels Bohr and Marie Curie.
label: SAFE

text: The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) holds a unique position at the intersection of technology, governance, and social welfare. In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, many countries realized the need for comprehensive digital transformation strategies. The UNDP’s approach is that bridging the digital divide and digitizing systems do not need to happen sequentially - progress can be made on both fronts simultaneously. The rapid pace of technological advancement often outstrips policy development, necessitating agile governance capable of adapting to these changes. The potential of AI to exacerbate existing inequalities, poses a significant concern, according to the UNDP's Chief Digital Officer, Robert Opp. However, retention of local tech talent remains a challenge, as skilled individuals often leave for opportunities abroad, he says. The Web Summit 2023 is taking place in Lisbon, Portugal, from November 14-15. For more information, visit the Web Summit website. The event is open to the public and free to accredited attendees.

text: “All You Had To Do Was Stay” is one of the saddest songs in Taylor Swift’s discography. The song falls into what Swifties call the “Track Five” factor. The fifth track of each one is the saddmost and most cathartic of the project and typically best captures its mood and message. With the release of1989, the time has come to reassess the long underappreciated track. “People like me are gone forever when you say you say goodbye,” Swift said in an interview with TIME in 2014. The 17-year-old song plays a critical role in the brilliance of Fall 20s, but also of Swift's mastery of the lyrically complex story she's trying to tell. It carries us into the chorus, with a line that lands with a sinister calm before an explosive “stay!” “I’m so glad you’re here,’ she said.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Eric Minh Swenson's EMS Nude Survey 1, aka EMSNS1, opens at Brooks' Costa Mesa Gallery, Jamie Brooks Fine Arts. Swenson -- who has spent the last four years documenting the Southern California art scene through photography and videos -- is the son of acclaimed photographer Lou Swenson. Eric's father will have a nude photograph in the show as a reminder of where the younger Swesons came from, and as the core influence of his photographic pursuits. Some of the images are not "pure" nudes; there are works in which models are partially clad, but the overall impact of bodies -- male and female -- in all their forms, is revealing of the human condition, of our desires and urges for ourselves and others. The official social media campaign leading up to the show features his photographs of the artists and models involved in the exhibition. (Full disclosure: I modeled for one of the social media images) The result is a lush, and sumptuous array of nude humanity depicted in photographs, paintings and sculpture. A majority of this inaugural show will be monotone, though some of the painters were given liberty to use color, mainly because they seldom if ever work solely in black and white. Of note: Eric is not afraid to show strong, unabashed nudes by women artists. Standouts are photos by Angela Izzo and Renée Jacobs which contrast nature with the cosmopolitan, while April Flores pushes erotic self-engagement to the limits.

text: A supermoon is a full moon that appears at the perigee, the closest point in the moon’s orbit to Earth. Supermoons appear to be about 14 percent larger and 30 percent brighter than full moons that appear at the apogee. The January supermoons are the end of a trilogy of big moon treats that began Dec. 3 with a full cold moon. If skies are clear, the total eclipse will be visible from eastern Asia across the Pacific Ocean to western North America. The super blue blood moon will also occur during a total lunar eclipse, when the Earth moves between the sun and the moon, blocking the sun's light from reflecting off the moon. It will be the second full moon of the month, which is usually called a “blue moon” because a double full-moon month occurs essentially once in a blue moon — about every 2½ years. But that won’t be the only rarity that night. The night of the lunar eclipse the night of January 31 will also be a superblue blood moon, with the moon appearing blood red because of the way the blocked sunlight bends. To get the full effect of the Lunar eclipse, watch at moonset, NASA advises. “Sometimes, the celestial rhythms sync up just right to wow us,” notes the space agency. The Jan. 1 supermoon will be. the biggest of the year. The moon will be oversized for a few nights after that, though will no longer be a fullmoon.
label: SAFE

text: Tennis great Martina Navratilova said her salary for Wimbledon commentary was no match for John McEnroe's. She said in a BBC Panorama documentary to air Monday that Mc enroe earned at least 10 times more than she did for BBC coverage of the Grand Slam tournament. “It makes me angry for the other women that I think go through this,” she said. BBC Sport told the Guardian that Mcenroe’s participation was of “a different scale, scope and time commitment.’ “He is widely considered to be the best expert/commentator in the sport, highly valued by our audiences, and his contract means he cannot work for another UK broadcaster without our permission,’’ a BBC spokeswoman said. The BBC published a list of its highest-paid personalities, putting his pay between £150,000 and £199,999 ($210,560 to $280,740), HuffPost UK reported. The tennis championships last about two weeks, with about 10 appearances compared with 30 for Mc Enroe during Wimbledon, according to the Telegraph, which estimated the disparity at £15,000 to £200,000. The disparity didn’t add up when told that the BBC may use McEnroe”s greater hours as a defense, Navratillova said. ‘It was a shock because John Mc enroe makes at least 150,000 pounds. I get about 15,000 British pounds for. Wimbledon. And unless John Mcenroes is doing a whole bunch of stuff outside of Wimbledon,. he’m getting at least ten times as much money than I am for very comparable work,' she added.

text: Helgi Tomasson's Romeo and Juliet made a comeback at San Francisco's War Memorial Opera House. The theme of the tragic fallout from senseless political feuding was given short shrift in favor of teen romance and botched parenting. Long stretches of unmemorable choreography, at times deaf to the emotional swells of Prokofiev, were punctuated by brilliant outbursts from the exceptional supporting cast. Ballet to the People missed the class struggle of Lavrovsky's original 1940 Socialist Realist production, the bold crowd scenes of John Cranko's 1962 interpretation, and the oppressive grandeur of Kenneth MacMillan's in 1965. The crack-of-dawn bedroom pas de deux that opens Act III is a towering achievement of TomASSon's production, says Erik Tomass on the San Francisco Ballet Orchestra's performance. The Acrobats Norika Matsuyama, Francisco Mungamba and Wei Wang brought the house down with their elegant, fearless tumbling and spinning, says Tomassons on the Ballet orchestra's performance of the score, which is based on the work of Sergei Rachmaninoff and Dmitri Shostakovich. The ballet is set to a score by the composer, who also wrote the score for the film version of the play, "Romeo and Juliet," which was released in 1973. It's on PBS stations in the U.S. and on PBS in the UK, with an online version on PBS.org.

text: Manchester United face FC Copenhagen on Thursday, November 9 at Parken Stadium. The game will kick off at 20:00 GMT or 3 p.m. ET. But they got their first points in the home game with Copenhagen two weeks ago with Harry Maguire's header and Andre Onana's injury-time penalty save. Luke Shaw, Tyrell Malacia, Lisandro Martinez and Amad Diallo will miss the match against FC Copenhagen as they are already on the long-term injury list. Omari Forson has traveled with the team and is most likely to play against Copenhagen. Experts expect a Copenhagen 1-2 Manchester United result. Though United’s recent form has been bad, they thrashed Copenhagen recently. So, it is still hard to look past them against the team bottom of Group A.

text: Song sparrows that live year-round on Alaska's Aleutian Islands can be up to three times larger than their cousins near San Francisco Bay. The study offers support for what is known as Bergmann's Rule, which states that among organisms that regulate their own heat, larger bodies are more efficient at retaining heat. The findings suggest a resilient future for these birds, said Peter Arcese, a co-author and professor in UBC's department of forest and conservation sciences. But there is a limit to how fast climate change can keep pace with the speed of adaptation, Carbeck said, "the key question is whether local adaptation can keep up with the overall speed of climate change" The study is published in Nature Communications. text: U.N. report: Some nations have taken marginal steps toward slashing emissions. But scientists warn that the world needs to spew around 45% less by then. Report looked into the climate plans of 195 countries and found that emissions will go up 9% by 2030. "It is time for a climate ambition supernova in every country, city, and sector," says U.N.'s Simon Stiell. "There is simply no time left for delays," says Abu Dhabi National Oil Company's Sultan al-Jaber, president of the COP28 climate talks in Dubai. "Governments must not only agree what stronger climate actions will be taken but also start showing exactly how to deliver them," he says in a press statement. "We cannot continue this way," says Disha Ravi, an Indian activist with the youth climate group Fridays for Future, of current extreme weather. "Leaders have continued prioritizing profits over the health and safety of our planet and its inhabitants," she says.

text: Wildlife biologists are launching an intensive conservation program to protect the declining Gray whale population. Local schools are participating by learning about the species and its ecosystem role. Scientists are optimistic that with dedicated effort, population numbers can recover. The Gray whale is an endangered species with a population of less than 1,000 in the wild. For more information on the Gray whale, visit www.graywhale.org or call 1-800-273-8255. Cheeses in India now usually make similar products with microbial rennet — or made with imported rennet. The booming cheese industry shows how religious rules, scientific research and commercial ingenuity can combine to produce positive outcomes. text: Australia has assured India of steady supplies of coking coal, two Indian government sources said. Domestic mills grapple with shortages of the key steelmaking raw material and a surge in prices. Nagendra Nath Sinha , the most senior official at India's federal Ministry of Steel, met Philip Green , Australia's high commissioner to India in New Delhi. Both sides discussed coking Coal supplies and other issues, including decarbonisation efforts of Indian steel companies. Australia accounts for over half of India's cokingcoal imports of around 70 million metric tons a year. Last month, prices for Australian cokingCoal jumped 50% to over $350 a metric ton due to factors such as maintenance outages, lower than usual supplies from Queensland, and a slower train network. Other than Australia and Russia, India also imports coking Coals from the U.S. and other countries such as Russia. text: Roger Federer breaks down in tears after winning his sixth Australian Open title. The 36-year-old Swiss defeated sixth seed Marin Cilic 6-2 6-7(5) 6-3 3-6 6-1. Federer joins Novak Djokovic and Roy Emerson as the only men to win six Australian Open trophies. The win was Federer's 30th grand slam title and his fourth grand slam after his 30th birthday. He said: "My thoughts were all over the place. All day I was thinking ‘What if I lost? What if I won?’ Every minute of the day’“Thank God I slept to 11” said Federer of the scorching hot day in Melbourne on Sunday. The match was played under a closed roof at Rod Laver Arena in front of hundreds of fans. The final took place under the roof at Melbourne Park’s Garden Square on Sunday night. The tournament will be held from January 28 to February 4 in Melbourne, with the final to be played on February 6.. The Australian Open is the second grand slam of the year after the U.S. Open, which runs from January 26 to March 4 in New York. It is the first grand slam to be held in Melbourne since the Australian Open in 2002, when Andy Murray won the men's title in his first final in Melbourne. It was the first of 20 grand slam titles for Federer, who has 20 career titles.

text: Jonathan Safran Foer and his family were given free tickets to see The Lion King. But the tickets weren't there when they got there. The theater was sold out. Foer: "We strolled through Times Square lit up like the day. We carried my mother-in-law's umbrellas and it never rained once" "New York City is, above all, deeply human," Foer says. "I'm proud of you," he says to his son. "You're more together than I am" "I don't want to go into the show late," Mary said. "We hugged grandma goodbye. We were driving at least halfway to North Carolina after the show" "We threw a hundred dollars at a spectacular dinner and ate half of it on the subway. We had free tickets. Only we didn't. I finally got the man who had given us our tickets on the phone at 7:15. "WHAT!? This has never happened! I'll make a call and call you back." He apologized and said he'd try to make it right. He'd just wanted to treat us to a show. He had walked to the box office and made sure. He apologized for the mixup the night before and gave us a bag of Lion King goodies. "What's a Simba? You're about to find out," he said. 'I gave Rowan the soft baby Simba. I gave him a t-shirt and a fistful of plastic money"

text: At least 21 people have died in the Dominican Republic after heavy rain. Nine people died when a highway tunnel wall collapsed in the capital. More than 13,000 people were evacuated to secure areas after heavy downpours. President Luis Abinader called it the "largest rainfall event ever" in the country's history. Four of those killed were US nationals, and three were from neighbouring Haiti, AFP news agency reported. The rainfall, which resulted from a tropical depression, is expected to continue across parts of the country into Monday, the U.S. embassy said. The Caribbean nation has been battered by torrential rainfall with footage on social media showing torrents of water flowing through streets and washing away vehicles. A majority of the nation's 32 provinces remain under red and yellow weather alerts, it added. Classes have been suspended until Wednesday "in order to evaluate the schools that may have been affected" and "guarantee the safety of our young people" The storm is believed to have been caused by the tropical depression.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Charlie Munger, the 'Oracle of Pasadena', passed away on November 28, 2023, at the age of 99. Munger was best known as the vice chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, a conglomerate led by his longtime friend Warren Buffett. He was also a generous philanthropist, donating millions to education, science, and journalism. His demise marks the end of an era in the corporate world and investment landscape. He valued integrity, honesty, and humility, considering his family and friends of utmost importance. His legacy includes his wisdom, wealth, and lessons on how to think and live better. He is survived by his wife, seven children, and a son-in-law, who is now a successful investor of his own. He leaves behind a legacy of wisdom and wealth, as well as a family of seven children and a wife of more than 50 years. He will be remembered for his multidisciplinary approach to investing and problem-solving. He advocated the use of mental models to gain a deeper understanding of the world and make informed decisions.
label: SENSITIVE

text: "Self Reflected" is an 8-by-12-foot gold panel depicting a sagittal slice of the human brain. The work was created by Greg Dunn, a neuroscientist-turned-artist, and Brian Edwards, a physicist. To reflect the neural activity within the brain, Dunn and Edwards have developed a technique called micro-etching. The artists hope their work will inspire people, even professional neuroscientists, "to take a moment and remember that our brains are absolutely insanely beautiful and they are buzzing with activity every instant of our lives," Dunn said. "We can't explain consciousness through an art piece, but we can give a sense of the fact that it is more complicated than just a few neurons," he added. "Everybody takes it for granted, butWe have, at the very core of our being, the most complex machine in the entire universe," Dunn added.. "Self Ref reflected" goes on display Saturday at The Franklin Institute in Philadelphia, with a public unveiling and a lecture by the artists at 3 p.m. in front of a crowd of about 1,000 people, including President Barack Obama and former Vice President Joe Biden. "The human brain is insanely complicated," Dunn says. "Rather than being told that your brain has 80 billion neurons, you can see with your own eyes what the activity of 500,000 of them looks like," he adds. "That has a much greater capacity to make an emotional impact than does a factoid in a book someplace"
label: SAFE

TikTok has said artificial intelligence and more than 6,000 moderators have removed millions of posts since the Hamas attack, and that it has a large team specially dedicated to removing violent content linked to children. text: A 10-year-old boy has won Alaska's annual giant cabbage contest. Keevan Dinkel of Wasilla, Alaska, submitted a 92.3-pound (41.9 kg) specimen named "Bob" Growing big cabbages is a tradition in this part of the state, just north of Anchorage. This year was the first time in the contest's 18 years that a child has won the weigh-off."Bob" fell short of the world-record 138.3 pound (62.7 kg) cabbage, called the "Palmer Pachyderm" The contest was watched by hundreds of onlookers, attended by green-clad women dressed as "cabbage fairies" and monitored by a representative of state Division of Weights and Measures. $2,000 prize-winner Keevan, whose family operates a local farm, took home $1,000 for his prize-winning entry, which was carried in by several Boy Scouts, in the Alaska State Fair's Giant Cabbage Weigh-Off on Friday night. "Cabbages are a cold crop. They like their roots warm and their heads cool," said Mardie Robb, Scott Robb's wife of Palmer greenhouse owner Scott Robb. "They like their head cool," she said of the traditional green cabbage, which is grown in the state's main farm belt. The fair offers a junior competition for growers 12 and younger, but Keevan's entry was put into the adult open category because of its size.
label: SAFE

text: Kunwar Danish Ali is an Indian Muslim member of parliament with the Bahujan Samaj Party. On September 21, he was subjected toIslamophobic comments and communal slurs. A legislator from India’s governing Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) called Ali a “pimp”, a ‘terrorist’ and used the pejorative “circumcised” among other derogatory remarks inside the Indian parliament. Al Jazeera spoke to Ali about the incident, how requests to Prime Minister Narendra Modi to condemn Bidhuri's behaviour have gone unanswered and what he believes the incident says about the future of Indian democracy. Ali:I am being targeted because I am a vocal, responsible Muslim parliamentarian. The people of this country and the majority of this community still believe in this country. Their secularism and secularism are doing the same thing everywhere, he says. The “terrorists are in the parliament’ I can only say that they are in a fool’

text: Russian officials say Ukraine targeted Moscow and other Russian cities with a fleet of at least 24 drones. Ukraine, meanwhile, reported being targeted by at least nine Russian drones overnight on November 26. It was the biggest such attack since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion in February 2022. Ukraine has upped attacks on Russia since launching its counteroffensive, aiming to hit regions close to fighting zones as well as further inland into Russia, including Moscow. The Russian Army also said it had downed two Ukrainian missiles over the Azov Sea that it said were headed for Russia, but Ukrainian officials made no immediate comment on the reported attacks.. Nearly 400 localities are without electricity in Ukraine due to "extremely difficult" weather conditions, President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said. The Ukrainian president warned that the weather is worsening with heavy snowfalls expected in the Kyiv, Chernihiv, Cherkasy, and Odesa regions. The situation remains difficult in the south and east of the country, says the head of the military administration in Kherson.

text: Conor McGregor faces Floyd Mayweather Jr. in Las Vegas on Saturday. McGregor has never fought in a professional boxing match. Mayweather has a record of 49-0 as a pro boxer, while McGregor is 29-3 in mixed martial arts and has never competed in a boxing match in his professional career. He is also a southpaw, which makes it a little more difficult for a conventional fighter to take him down, the group says, and he's 12 years younger than Mayweather. The fight will be held at the T-Mobile Arena in Las Las Vegas, Nevada, with the fight going under the lights at 10 p.m. ET on Saturday night on Showtime. The bout will be contested by Mayweather, 40, and McGregor, 29, in a megafight that is expected to be the richest in boxing history, with a purse of more than $100 million. text: Hancock County has built a comprehensive system focused on both treatment and recovery. From 1999 through 2020, 131 deaths in the county were attributed to opioids. Since its implementation began a decade ago, Hancock County has brought in more than $19 million. The county’s approach, which echoes experts’ recommendations for use of the settlement money, is that people with the right support can recover from addiction. It's not just about how to get people off of opioids, but how do we keep them in remission and increase their stable recovery, Harvard expert John F. Kelly says. The settlement funds from drugmakers, wholesalers and pharmacies will not be enough for every harm reduction, treatment, recovery and prevention program that might be needed. But it could be enough to jumpstart major changes to the efforts, he says. the county has three confirmed overdose deaths and five suspected ones so far in 2023. After 28 overdose deaths from all drugs last year, the county had three confirmed overdoses in 2018.

text: N Nvidia has told customers in China it is delaying the launch of a new artificial intelligence chip until the first quarter of next year. Nvidia is betting on the chips to help it preserve its market share in China after it was barred from shipping products including its advanced A800 and H800 AI chips by Washington's tightened export rules. The H20, L20 and L2 include most of Nvidia's newest features for AI work, but have had some of their computing power measures cut back to compliant with new U.s. rules. text: Price cap affects 29 million households in England, Wales and Scotland. Analysts have predicted that prices will fall back in March. Ofgem sets the maximum amount that suppliers can charge for each unit of gas and electricity but not the total bill, so if you use more, you will pay more. The regulator is consulting on whether to raise the charges by £20 a year for direct debit customers, to cancel the gap in bills compared with prepayment meter customers. Last winter, overall energy prices were high and rises would have been bigger had it not been for the government's Energy Price Guarantee limiting the typical bill to £2,500. A typical household energy bill fell by £240 a year in October to £1,834 a year but, of that, £89 was not an actual drop in the price you pay, but actually the result of a new estimate of the typical amount of gas, electricity and gas used by households. Had the calculation not been made, the fall was £151 a year.

text: Cuyama Valley north of Santa Barbara is one of California's groundwater basins. Growers Grimmway Farms and Bolthouse Farms are the valley's biggest water users. It's all about the money," said Chris Wegis, who runs a family farm with her husband. "It's totally disheartening that somebody wants to come in and basically destroy you for their own personal gain," she said. "Our blood, sweat and tears are in this land," said Weg is, "and for someone to try to rob us of our livelihood and take it from us, it's unrighteous. I mean, it'm just criminal" The companies say they are committed to reducing water use and taking part in the Valley's groundwater management plan, which the state recently approved. But residents and small farmers said they remain at odds with the carrot growers.

text: Magnetic iron nanoparticles found in traffic fumes may be able to enter the brain, according to a new study. The tiny grains may contribute to brain diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease, the researchers said. The nanoparticles are a form of iron oxide called magnetite. In the study, published Sep. 5 in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, researchers found millions of magnetite particles in a gram of brain tissue. The particles are small enough that they can travel up the nose and reach the brain through the olfactory bulb, study author Barbara Maher said. But wearing a mask is unlikely to be useful to avoid getting a magnetic load from air pollution, she said, because the amount of pollution drops rapidly from the sky. The highest brain magnetite content was found in a 32-year-old Mexico City resident, the study said, and younger people who were exposed to high levels of air pollution in Mexico City also showed high concentrations of the particles in their brains. It's not fully known how iron is involved in the disease, but previous studies have found higher levels of iron in various brain areas of people with Alzheimer's. The researchers plan next to look directly at the toxicity of these particles by growing them in the lab by growing their own magnetite in a lab. This will be difficult to show, however, because people living in suburban areas will be more likely to be exposed to lower levels of particles, Maher said, even if those people are exposed to open fires and other pollution sources.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Scientists Rainer Weiss, Barry Barish and Kip Thorne win the 2017 Nobel Prize for Physics. Ripples in the fabric of space-time first predicted a century ago by Albert Einstein. gravitational waves sparked a revolution in astrophysics when their first detection was announced early last year. Physics is the second of this year’s crop of Nobel Prizes and comes after Americans Jeffrey Hall, Michael Rosbash and Michael Young were awarded the Nobel prize for Physiology or Medicine on Monday. The prizes for achievements in science, literature and peace were first awarded in 1901 in accordance with the will of Swedish business tycoon Alfred Nobel, who bequeathed much of the fortune he generated from his discovery of dynamite to the Swedish Royal Academy of Sciences. The prize is worth 9 million Swedish crowns ($1.1 million) and is split between Weiss and Barish, with Thorne sharing the other half, the Nobel Prize-giving body said on Tuesday. The teams involved in the discovery of gravitational waves quickly emerged as favorites for Tuesday's prize, the Royal Swedish Academy of sciences said in a statement. “This is something completely new and different, opening up unseen worlds,” the Academy said in the statement announcing the winners of the prize. The waves were detected using laser beams at the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) “The signal was extremely weak when it reached Earth, but is already promising a revolution In astrophysics,’ it said.

text: Hydrogen has been regarded as a potential energy carrier instead of fossil fuels. Proton exchange membrane water electrolysis (PEMWE) is considered an ideal and sustainable approach to produce green hydrogen. However, the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in PEMWE involves a slow four-electron/proton transfer process, resulting in slow reaction kinetics. In addition, the localized strong oxidative and acidic environment will corrode the catalyst, leading to poor durability. There is an urgent need to develop efficient and stable OER catalysts to boost the OER toward high-efficiency and economic hydrogen production via water splitting. The optimal electrocatalyst (350-Ta@IrOx) exhibits 147.7 times higher mass activity (1207.4 A gIr–1) than that of commercial IrO2at 1.55 V vs. RHE. It demonstrates no noticeable performance degradation during the 500 h durability test, obviously outperforming the undoped sample and commercial Iro2and claiming its potential for industrial applications.

text: Flooding in Downpatrick, Newry, Kilkeel, Portadown and Templepatrick this week. 45,000 properties in Northern Ireland are at risk of flooding from rivers, sea or surface water. Armagh Observatory: October 2023 was the wettest month ever - breaking a record that had stood since 1870. Data from weather stations all over Ireland has been analysed by researchers at the Icarus Climate Research Centre in Maynooth University. It found clear signals of climate change - an increase in both rainfall and rainfall intensity, and an average temperature rise in Ireland of 0.88C for every degree of warming on a global scale. It's hard to say for definite but warmer air holds more moisture so a warmer atmosphere will produce more rain - to quote observatory director Prof Michael Burton: "That's physics." The atmosphere is warming, causing more rain, but human changes may also affect how likely flooding is. Perhaps property has been built on a floodplain. A river's course may have been altered, affecting where and how quickly the water flows.

text: The NFL on Wednesday approved a new policy to intercept national anthem protests before they happen. The measure mandates that players who are on the field must stand for the national anthem. Teams could be fined by the league if their players sit or kneel, as many have done in protest of racial injustice and police brutality in recent seasons. The NFL Players Association criticized the league for failing to consult with the union on the matter. The league also debated the issue in previous meetings since former 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick sparked national controversy in the 2016 season by taking a knee during the anthem. The movement, which grew to include other players and teams, continued in 2017, prompting repeated outrage from President Donald Trump. The union will review the new “policy’ and challenge any aspect of it that is inconsistent with the collective bargaining agreement,” the union said. “As always, conversations at league meetings are candid, thoughtful and thorough,’’ an NFL spokesman told HuffPost in an email. ‘We will continue the conversation this morning,' the NFL spokesman said in an emailed response to a CNN request for comment on the new policy, which was not immediately available for comment. The new policy was approved at a meeting of the league's owners on Wednesday, the league said. It will take effect this season, and teams can opt out of the policy if they so choose, the NFL said in a statement. It would be up to the individual teams to decide whether to fine or punish players and other personnel.

text: The Hawaii Space Exploration and Analog and Simulation team has spent a year in a Mars-like habitat on Hawaii's Mauna Loa volcano. The six-man crew will emerge from their dome free of spacesuits for the first time in 365 days on Sunday. The team's main goal is to better understand the risks associated with space travel, including conflict, stress and depression. The crew shared everything from personal hardships and plans for the future to the realization that humans are capable of anything, including a trip to Mars in the 2030s, they told The Huffington Post in an exclusive interview."It doesn’t feel like a year, I think that’s the strangest part. It feels like we’ve been here a few months," crew member Sheyna Gifford said. "The little things people do that you’d never notice in real life can make you think about how you dealt with them on the stairs here," crew architect Tristan Bassingthwaighte told HuffPost. "A person can be totally cool one minute and severely annoying the next,” he said in an email, adding that he often felt “bored to death” Other times he just wanted to be alone, to find a place to get away, to be totally totally alone, he said, adding, “The littleThings that you do in life that you'd never notice on the steps here can makeyou think about them.’”

text: More than 240 hostages were snatched at gunpoint on 7 October from their homes or workplaces next to the Gaza Strip. They included some 30 children, the youngest just nine months old. Over the years, Israel has endured many hostage crises. During the 1980s, the country showed it was ready to pay high prices for its citizens in prisoner swaps with Palestinian and Lebanese armed groups. In 2006, Hamas kidnapped a soldier, 19-year-old Gilad Shalit, in a cross-border raid and his father, Noam, led a painful five-year campaign to bring him home. The future of the hostages will be decided in the coming days, says Gershon Baskin, who led secret backchannel talks with Hamas and is a key figure involved in the Shalit deal. But the main complication this time, he says, is the scale of atrocities, which he says will prevent any comprehensive deal being done. The military wing of Hamas said it wasready to free up to 70 women and children held in Gaza in exchange for a five-day ceasefire.

text: A group of exoplanets seem to be shrinking. Scientists think radiation from the planets' core pushes their atmospheres away. The exact mechanism for the atmosphere loss remains unclear. Scientists looked at data from NASA's retired Kepler Space Telescope to test two theories. They found that most of the planets there retained their atmosphere, making the core-powered mass loss a more likely cause of eventual atmosphere loss, they said. The study was published in The Astronomical Journal, a journal published by the American Astronomical Society. But the mystery isn't over yet, according to the study's author, Jessie Christiansen, who says our understanding of the worlds will develop with time. "There's something going on that impedes planets from reaching and/or staying at this size," Christiansen said in a statement. "This gap is not a fluke. There's something to be solved here," she said, adding that the research isn't done yet, and that more research is needed to solve the mystery.

text: Marta María Pérez’s photo is part of “Radical Women: Latin American Art, 1960-1985.” The exhibition is on view at the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles. The photos are “omens,” Marcela Guerrero writes in a catalogue essay, offering “an unromanticized view of maternity that transgresses Western notions of motherhood’” and “Do not kill animals or watch them be killed’ The title refers to the Afro-Cuban superstition that a pregnant woman who either kills an animal or witnesses a killing will give birth to a child with violent or criminal instincts, the artist explained to HuffPost. The images welcome pain as well as love, truth as well and fantasy, horror and tranquility, she said. and ‘Recognizing ‘fetal abuse’ moves us toward criminalizing pregnancy,’ Johanna Hamann wrote in “Baby Is a Crime,�” a book about the mother-to-be in the U.S. and the world around her. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, which also published “Born to you strangled by the cord” by Asa Lynn Paltrow, author of When Becoming Pregnant Is A Crime, a novel about a woman who becomes a mother.

I'm thankful to EkolU for the opportunity to go on tour. The band started off in high school. We entered the 1995 "Brown Bags" and lost to ballerina dancers. Me, Makapu, and Akoni (who is no longer in the band) kept practicing as a trio band. From there we added keyboards, then drums, and now we have horns. Then we added another guitar player. It's weird to talk about this now because what is like 20 years ago now?!? That's crazy. Professionally we've been together for 16 years. That was when we put out our first album in 1999. That album had "Down in the Valley" and "Stuck On You" and all that stuff. Usually, Akoni writes one and then I handle the rest. The songs are pretty much influenced by my wife. I stay motivated and inspired because of her. She was there for the hard times. She helped me and I lost a lot of weight. I don't know if people know this, but before, I was like 541 lbs. Nowadays I'm much more appreciative and thankful. Like back then, we were young. We didn't know the impact. But now, for me, I feel like all the new artists, I see them working hard for what I have.

text: Antarctica is losing ice at an increasing pace, but the loss of sea ice may lead to more snowfall over the ice sheets. Penn State scientists analyzed the impacts of decreased sea ice in the Amundsen Sea in West Antarctica. The researchers identified a feedback loop between sea ice and atmospheric water vapor. A more ice-free ocean surface intensifies evaporation, contributing to increased atmospheric water Vapor. This enhanced moisture causes a locally amplified greenhouse effect, resulting in heightened downward longwave radiation, which subsequently reduces sea ice the next month, the researchers said. The team's findings emphasize the need for refining current climate models to enhance their predictive accuracy, the scientists said.. Increasedsnowfallin Antarctica might slow the sea level rise, but it's essential to recognize that the ice sheet will continue to contribute to rising sea levels, they said. In 2022, we witnessed a new record low, and this year's levels are even lower, significantly below previous observations. These recent rapid changes in Antarctic sea ice highlight the urgency of understanding their causes and their potential impact on the Antarctic ice sheet.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Shuffleton's Barbershop is arguably Norman Rockwell's masterpiece. It is chiaroscuro at its best – a noirscape of an after-hours moment in a small town barbershop. It was painted as the family crisis escalated and my grandmother Mary’s impending breakdown loomed like an invisible wraith inside the home. Mary had dedicated herself to my grandfather and his work for over 15 years before she began to collapse. She had never individuated – she went from being an overly protected, isolated child to the wife of an already famous and successful American illustrator, 15 years her senior. She tried everything to find a solution – went to doctor after doctor, becoming attached to each one – until she snapped one day at a coffee counter in Arlington, Vermont in the dead of winter in early 1951. She broke down into uncontrollable tears as she sat with the younger family doctor who had been trying to analyze and help her. Perhaps in that moment she realized he couldn’t save her, he didn't have the answers either, and once again, she was left with her overwhelming existential pain. This is the painting that had haunted me from afar. I felt apprehension, a well of emotion coming to the surface, as I sat in anticipation of seeing the painting in person for the first time. Would it live up to my expectations or disappoint me? I knew I was going to encounter my grandfather in a very different, more personal way this time.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Terry Frei was fired after saying he was "very uncomfortable" that Takuma Sato, who came from Japan, won the Indianapolis 500 this year. Frei will look as if he is the victim, because he was open in his opinions, says John Sutter. Sutter: Athletes who are attacked are attacked because they are too good. What is feared is their superiority, not their inferiority, he says. The distinctions that are drawn do not depend on citizenship either, Sutter says, and the hyperbole and the possessive are not subtle.sutter: We must understand how people form and maintain these types of attitudes. Otherwise we will not be able to address them in a constructive manner, he writes. The risk is that, in the vernacular, “the script will be flipped,” Sutter writes. If he had not been fired, I would be calling for discipline, he adds, and he should be taken to task for his actions. The Sato-Frei incident is not isolated, and it is not an isolated incident, says Sutter, and we need to talk about it in a more constructive way, he argues. The “Indy 500” is especially all-American, taking place in the heartland on Memorial Day weekend. It is supposed to announce summer as an ongoing celebration of white working-class heroes, including those whose family names end in vowels, Sato says. It has not been accepted on these shores.
label: SENSITIVE

text: 'Sculpture Victorious: Art in the Age of Invention 1837-1901' at Tate Britain aims at presenting Imperial Britain as elegant in spite of the obvious lack of restraint and excessive theatricality of their sculptures. The representation of elegance in England has not always been that easy. Henry VIII's conversion to protestantism and its consequent iconoclasm prevented indigenous painters and sculptors from enjoying the same level of patronage that they had in the continent. While the Spanish monarchs were used to purchase Titians, Rubens and Velazquez, Elizabeth I had to conform with a lesser kind of royal portraiture. The British could not restrain from showing off their bling bling in whichever opportunity they found. This taste for excessive ornament and historicist folly reached its peak in Victorian times when the English finally got the means to properly do what they like to do: showing off. The outcome is for everybody to see in the Victorian sculptures included in this show. But do not take my word for it, let's read what The Daily Telegraphs' Richard Dorment has to say about this show: 'Its incoherence is frightening. It is as if this exhibition were curated by the Victorians themselves. To be honest, I left this show trying to know more about the Elephant. How did it function? How was it supposed to be displayed? It's as if the curators believed technical prowess was a source of artistic value which, of course, is never the case'
label: SENSITIVE

text: Scientists have run the first proof of concept of their DNA 'time machine' to shed light on a century of environmental change in a freshwater lake. Their approach, which uses AI applied to DNA-basedbiodiversity,climate variablesand pollution, could help regulators to protect the planet's existing biodiversity levels, or even improve them.Researchers from the University of Birmingham, in collaboration with Goethe University in Frankfurt, used sediment from the bottom of alakein Denmark to reconstruct a 100-year-old library of biodiversity, chemical pollution, and climate change levels. They found that pollutants such as insecticides and fungicides, alongside increases in minimum temperature (a 1.2-1.5-degree increase) caused the most damage to biodiversity levels. However, the DNA present in the sediment also showed that over the last 20 years the lake had begun to recover. This is concerning as different species can deliver different ecosystem services, and therefore their inability to return to a particular site can prevent the reinstatement of specific services.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Downing Street never suggested this would be a flurry of the fresh; a wagon load of new ideas. Instead, this felt very Sunakian: iterative, rather than explosive, but with an emphasis on ideas he is personally passionate about. There is some interesting detail in this idea, including the government considering extra taxes on vapes. But let's take a step back and ask a bigger question: does all of this add up to enough to change the political weather? For those familiar political sentences I mentioned include the increasingly widespread expectation here at Westminster that the Conservatives will lose the next election. And given the familiarity of much of what we heard from the King, the concern of Tory MPs will be that these measures - however individually laudable or otherwise - simply won't be enough. And the focus on crime - while potentially popular with a wide cross-section of the electorate - appears framed with a particular eye on Conservative voters recent and long-standing. They are not without at least a splash of internal party controversy.

text: Retailers are kicking off the unofficial start of the holiday shopping season on Friday. But executives are growing concerned with a spending slowdown that could temper sales. text: Actors Equity may end up busting up its own union, says Rick Baumgartner. "Divide and conquer" has been the strategy of anti-labor movements for years, he says. The union defies a two-thirds vote of its local membership to pursue its own leadership's agenda, he adds. The most likely outcome is some negotiated legal agreement, he writes, starting with a 30-year-old settlement that established the 99-seat plan."Hopefully, Equity leadership will not continue to stand in the way of the continued blossoming of the creative blossoming in L.A. theater," Baumgardner says. "This would be a splitting of a union that has been in existence for more than one hundred years," he says, since many abandoned in recent years. "It would be unprecedented, since Equity has made serious missteps before, when it tried to stifle the Off-Broadway movement in 1950s and 1960s," he adds, referring to the OffBroadway and Off-Off-Offway movement. 'It's practically impossible already with 99 seats. And, to make matters worse, under the proposed "showcase" code, actors are prohibited from forming non-profit corporations to raise funds,' Baumgartner says of the union's new rule on membership companies. 'This would not be many years before many unions that abandoned many years ago would be split, since their membership were soon soon themselves,' he writes.

text: Extreme snowfall events may be a feature of some locations at higher latitudes and elevations in the decades to come. The warming effect at low-medium mountain elevations is predicted to instead enhanceextreme precipitation, with a 7% increase in rainfall per 1°C of warming globally. This contrast is likely to have consequences for the communities living in these environments, who rely on the regularity ofsnowfall for livelihoods, such as tourism and the skiing industry. The trend was most evident in the south of the French Alps, where the Mercantour massif is projected to experience a 39% reduction in mean annual snowfall at 1,800 melevation. The research is vitally important to translate across other cold mountainous regions to helplocal communities to plan future changes in environmental and socioeconomic management strategies that enable them to survive, say the researchers at the University of Grenoble Alpes, France. They used a climate model under Representative Concentration Pathway 8.5, which predicts Earth's temperature will increase by 4.3°C by 2100 relative to pre-industrial levels.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Youichiro Adachi is the 18th generation of his family to be a master cormorant fisherman. He is one of about 50 people in Japan carrying on the 1,300-year tradition of using trained birds to dive for fish. The method, known as ukai, was once common in Japan and a version of it has also been practised in China. But today it is largely supported by tourists, who watch the fishermen and their birds bringing in the catch. Now, environmental changes are making the fish ever more scarce and small, endangering the lifeline of the fisherman and their flocks. The fish like to eat algae that grow on large stones, but those rocks have become less common after repeated anti-flooding works carried out by river management authorities. “I go to the river every day so I can feel the changes,” Adachi said, drawing upon nearly four decades of working on the Nagara River in Oze, central Gifu prefecture.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Australian activist Colin Russell was today released from a St. Petersburg detention center. Russell is the last of the Arctic 30 detainees to be freed on bail after the seizure of the Greenpeace International ship Arctic Sunrise more than two months ago. Russia has so far refused to participate in the proceedings at the Tribunal, invoking an exemption Russia added to its 1997 ratification of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) Russia was not formally obliged to participate, but it is under an obligation to comply with any ruling the Tribunal makes. Such rulings are binding to any party to the UN convention on the law of the sea -- including Russia, says Greenpeace's Tim Lister, a lawyer for the ship's owners, the Dutch government. Greenpeace does not disagree and assumes that Russia will comply with the ITLOS ruling and stands ready to welcome home our friends and activists as soon as they are allowed to leave, Lister says. Russia is obligated to also comply with a ruling by releasing the ship and its crew, says Lister. The Netherlands had argued at the Hamburg-based Tribunal that Russia had no right to board and detain the ship, and all on board and that the detention of the crew is a violation of their right to liberty and security. In developments today, theDutch Foreign Ministry said it had finalized the bank guarantee in compliance with the Tribunal's ruling. It eventually ruled in favour of the Netherlands and the release of the ship with its crew of 30 and all those on board at gunpoint.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Clinical ink is expanding its patient engagement suite with the inclusion of the SPUR behavioral diagnostic tool created byObservia. This unique integrated solution combines assessment of patient behavior with lifestyle modification, eCOA, eSource, and Digital Biomarkers. The tool has been validated in numerous patient populations, including diabetes, obesity, and others. It collects a comprehensive dataset of behavioral drivers (social, psychological, usage, and rational) that helps quantify each patient’s decision-making motivation. It also allows for personalized support at the patient level. The collaboration with Observia allows Clinical ink to capture a holistic view of patient behaviour together with clinical outcomes and digital biomarkers. “As the world of clinical trials transforms to become more digital, we are thrilled to bring our SPURTMprofiling tool into the Clinical ink service offering,” saysKevin Dolgin, Head of R&D at Observia. The company is the inventor ofSPURTM, a validated, ground-breaking tool for predicting health behavior.
label: SAFE

text: Artist Iván Sikic buried a 24-karat gold nugget beneath 54 tons of dirt in an abandoned mansion in Peru's capital city, Lima. Sikic asked people to engage in the artwork by, well, digging. The installation was open to hunters for just three days, but when no one was able to uncover the nuggets, Sikic himself took on the role of miner to unearth it. The artwork thrusts the normally passive art-goer into a morally precarious position: he both relishes the dig and must question that enjoyment, he writes in a blog post about the piece. It's worth around $2,000, and Sikic says it's a reminder of gold's long and troubled history in Peru, where European settlers ravaged indigenous populations to extract it, and today’s mining practices are similarly destructive -- both to the Amazon Rainforest and to the lives of over 400,000 illegal miners. The art piece may no longer be open for those seeking riches, but it continues to address the unacknowledged ways income and lifestyle disparities can emerge from those riches. It was acquired through pure luck -- the gallery was located across the street from the derelict mansion, and the property developers were happy to give Sikic free artistic reign. "I realized that the reading of it went well beyond that of my original intention,” Sikic wrote, “and the work seemed to also speak a lot about human greed for anything that we consider to be of significant value”
label: SENSITIVE

text: Researchers have discovered a series of large undersea sediment deposits in a region near Italy that were likely formed by an ancient volcanic supereruption. The deposits, known as megabeds, were found in the western Marsili Basin, an area at the bottom of the Tyrrhenian Sea that surrounds the Marsili Seamount. The study suggests that these megabed originated not from nearby volcanoes, but from a volcanic province to the north. That province, researchers think, was an area once near the Campanian Ignimbrite (CI), the largest one of itsvolcanic eruptions since Campi Flegrei's formation nearly 50,000 years ago. If a volcano in this region were to erupt today, the movement of such vast magma deposits beneath the surface could trigger tsunamis threatening nearbycoastal citiesand cause a variety of other ecological disasters, the researchers say. The discovery of these previously unknown megabedes is pivotal for understanding and measuring the impact of such recurring geohazards over time.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Johnny Somali, 23, was charged with forcefully obstructing a business's operation. The business in question was an Osaka restaurant, where he played extremely loud music and harassed the staff. The suspect is known to have repeatedly made mocking remarks about the atomic-bombed cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. He also engaged in other offensive acts across Japan and broadcast these actions online. The 23-year-old suspect is believed to have been filming his action and streaming the footage online. But police identified him from the online footage as well as images captured by security cameras. He was arrested on Thursday in the city's Dotonbori area. He is a controversial Kick streamer who is known for making offensive remarks toward locals in Japan. He has also threatened to kill Japanese people with nuclear weapons in the past and has posted videos of his threats on YouTube and other social media sites. He and another American man were arrested on suspicion of "forcible obstruction of business" after broadcasting inside of a restaurant in Osaka's Chuo Ward.

The company remains well-positioned to deliver top-tier earnings per share and dividend growth of 6% to 8% a year through at least 2026, it says. In addition, PPL says it is on pace to achieve its projected O&M savings of at least$175 millionby 2026. It plans to invest nearly$2.5 billionthis year and$12 billionthrough 2026 to modernize the grid. The firm also plans to further strengthen grid reliability and resiliency for customers as extreme weather threats increase, and advance a cleaner energy mix without compromising on affordability. For more information about PPL, visit www.ppl.com.

text: Underground sensors detected excessive radiation levels inside a nuclear waste storage site. No workers have been exposed and there was no risk to public health, officials say. Air-monitoring alarm went off at 11:30 p.m. local time Friday. The source of the high radiation readings had yet to be determined, and a plan to send inspection teams below ground to investigate was put on hold as a precaution. The facility is designed as a repository for so-called transuranic waste, which includes discarded machinery, clothing and other materials contaminated with plutonium or other radioisotopes heavier than uranium. the incident posed no danger to human health or the environment, the U.S. Department of Energy says. The site is expected to continue to accept radiological materials until 2030, the Energy Department says. "We're in shutdown mode," spokesman Bill Mackie says.. Inbound waste shipments had already been suspended at the plant since a truck caught fire there earlier this month in an accident that left several workers suffering smoke inhalation. The Chihuahuan Desert normally receives up to 6,000 cubic meters of radioactive waste a year and employs more than 800 workers. Just a few dozen essential personnel, including security officers, remained at the site over the weekend. But officials said they believe they believe this to be the first real alarm since the plant began operations. The alarm automatically switched the underground ventilation system to filtration to keep any releases from reaching the surface, DOE officials said.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The sand where turtles nest is warmer than usual due to theabnormally warm temperaturesthis summer related to climate change. Temperature is what determines these turtles' sex. The turtles laid 52,500 nests this year along the Space Coast, an area of eastern Florida named for its proximity toNASA's Kennedy Space Center. That's three times the amount of nests from the previous record set in 2022. But even amongst all these record numbers, from 2018-2022, scientists found no male sea turtles, Lucy Hawkes, an ecologist from the University of Exeter, told Insider. "If you ran out of all males, it would threaten the population — but we don't think that's going to happen too soon," Hawkes said. The sea turtles have survived over 230 million years, withstandingmultiple mass extinctions, according to the British Natural History Museum. "They are amazing animals. And they have ways to deal with all kinds of things that have been thrown at them," Joel Cohen said.

Mackie says her character is "very open and she’s very real. She doesn’t necessarily think things through before saying them. But she feels that way about things, which is something that I really liked about her.” She says the character is not from the ‘80s and that there might be a parallel to a former “Who” companion, Ace ― is any of this true? I’ve read that “Doctor Who” showrunner Steven Moffat has hinted otherwise. She is very much a present-day woman. Kind of a normal young woman, really. There is a nod there, in her vintage-inspired outfits, but she's definitely not in the '80s. She's quite witty and quite intelligent and very human and driven by her gut and the way she feels about things. And I felt like it was a real person that you’d like to meet. And it was like that it was someone that you'd like to have a real conversation with. I would say that kind of how she is about early 20s, I mean, she's about that age that I would kind of say that she is. But yeah, yeah, I would. But maybe that’�s why I related to her so well.

text: A new study published inApplied and Environmental Microbiologyprovides the first characterization of the coral microbiome under hypoxia. The research is an initial step toward identifying potential beneficial bacteria for corals facing this environmental stressor. When there is not enough oxygen in the water, it throws the community of microorganisms on the coral out of balance, and some of the suspected harmful bacteria, such as Desulfovibrionaceae or Clostridia, become more active. This study is a first step toward understanding the response of coral microbiomes to deoxygenation which, along with warming andocean acidification, represent the "triple threat" of climate change to the ocean's ecosystem. The researchers plan to look more closely at the health of corals and relate that to the response to stressors when challenged by the stress of low oxygen. The bacteria that increased are those that can survive without oxygen and are ready to take advantage of a change in resources. They suggest that changes in the microbiome may influence coral resilience to low oxygen conditions.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Naval and air assets from Australia and South Korea combined to test maritime warfare skills and build on strong partnerships. Exercise Haedoli Wallaby - named after the 'Haedoli' dolphin mascot of the Republic of Korea Navy (ROKN) and the wallaby that symbolises Australia - took place from October 31 to November 3. The biennial bilateral exercise aimed to strengthen combined operational capabilities and interoperability between the two nations. Six ships from the ROKN participated, including destroyer ROKS Gang Gam-chan. Australia contributed RAN frigate HMAS Toowoomba, with its embarked MH-60R Seahawk helicopter, Valkyrie, and a RAAF P-8A Poseidon maritime patrol aircraft. The combined exercise was first conducted in 2012 following an agreement reached between the defence ministers of the two countries in 2011. This year marks the ninth anniversary of the exercise. The exercise is part of Australia's regional presence deployment throughout South-East and North-East Asia.

text: Ruthie Ann Miles is nominated for a Tony for her performance in "The King and I" "She has a real strength about her, but also a real sensitivity and warmth," says Tony-nominated actress. Miles is the mother of an almost two-and-a-half-year-old daughter who she says is giving her and her husband "a run for [their] money" "My daughter is saying she needs my attention more than the phone call," she says of her daughter's reaction to her Tony nomination. "I'm one of those people who has trouble falling back asleep," Miles says of the Tony nomination experience. "She's not the favorite for the big award, but, while all the nominees in that category are giving notable performances, she's my choice," says the Tony- nominated actress of the role of Lady Thiang in the revival of The King and. I. "Her "Something Wonderful" is amazing vocally--I'm sure those who saw her in Here Lies Love are not surprised by that--but what I think is so brilliant about her performance is her ability to pay attention to her surroundings," says actress-producer-director David Hyde-Smith. "Because of the intelligence of the performance throughout, LadyThiang is more empathetic than in other productions I have seen," says Hyde- Smith. "People leave the theater talking about her," says Hale-Smith, "in addition to Kelli O'Hara of course"

text: The U.S. Northeast was two to four times more likely than usual to experience extreme winter weather. Past climate projections predicted that, in a warming world, winters would be the seasons to heat up the fastest. The relationship between spiking Arctic warmth and pockets of cold to the south was “really, really strong,” the study authors said. The researchers could not conclude that a warmer Arctic was directly responsible for harsh winter storms in the U.K., northern Europe and northern Asia. But answers may lie in another atmospheric disturbance linked to a warming Arctic, the authors said, and there is still much to be learned about how climate change could shape patterns around the world, they reported. The findings were published online today in the journal Nature Communications (March 13) in the study’s lead author, Judah Cohen, is a director of seasonal forecasting at Atmospheric and Environmental Research, an organization that assesses risks from weather events and climate change.“I’d argue that our expectations were overly simplistic for climate change,’’ Cohen said. “It was kind of expected that if you warm the Arctic, that is just milder and warmer.’ “ The study authors reported their findings in Nature Communications, a journal that covers climate change and the environment. The study was published on March 13, 2016, in the online edition of the journal, Nature.com/Magazine/Handbook of Climate Change, a peer-reviewed, open-access journal.
label: SENSITIVE

text: NASA will not be sending commands to its fleet of Martian rovers, orbiters, and spacecraft until the Sun moves out of the way. The Mars solar conjunction is from November 11 to 25, a period that occurs every two years during which Earth and the Red Planet are on opposite sides of the Sun in their respective orbital path. During this time, NASA will still check on the overall health of its spacecraft save for two days when Mars will be fully hidden behind the Sun’s disk. Once the two-week period ends, the Martian missions will relay the data back to Earth and resume communication with ground control. The Perseverance and Curiosity rovers will monitor changes in surface conditions, weather, and radiation while remaining parked in the same place on the surface of Mars, according to the space agency. Ingenuity Helicopter, will use its color camera to study the movement of sand on Mars, which can pose an issue for other missions. It will also collect data on interactions between Mars’ atmosphere and the Sun.
label: SAFE

text: Photographer Zak Noyle found the waves of Java, Indonesia, covered in garbage. Strong currents had carried the trash of the world’s most populated island to its once pure waters. Indonesia, a country comprised of more than 17,000 islands, suffers from a terrible trash problem that is polluting its waters. Some of the population centers have little to no trash collection infrastructure, leading locals to dispose of their waste in the street or in river beds, after which it inevitably is washed out to sea. In addition to the sea of plastic, large objects like tree trunks were being tossed around in the waves, as well as noodle packets and other debris. The only other disposal option Indonesians have is burning their trash, which creates equally harmful ( albeit less visible) damage to the environment. The stench of burning plastic is ever present, according to a non-profit that sails the world researching plastic pollution. No matter who is to blame, the effects are felt by those who live in or visit Indonesia. “My boyhood fantasy felt disappointingly ruined," a writer for the surf website The Inertia said. "I couldn’t believe it. Trash in the lineup. And not any lineup. A lineup right out of my imagination – the perfect lineup … spoiled by trash.” The juxtaposition of incredible natural beauty with the blight pollution in Bali was heartbreaking,” Mark Lukach said. ‘We met many people who would like to do the right thing, but simply don't have access to basic waste removal/disposal’
label: SENSITIVE

text: Palm oil producers, buyers, civil society organisations and government recently stepped up collaboration on sustainable supply chains at the SMART SEED event. The ninth edition of this event focused on "Supply Chain Transformation in Support of Sustainable Palm Oil" Palm oil, like many other commodities, faces increasing demands from international customers and regulators to demonstrate progress on a number of sustainability indicators. Globally, Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) regulations haveincreased by 155 per cent in the past decade. The European Union Deforestation Regulation (EUDR), which will prevent commodities linked to deforestation from entering the bloc, will be implemented at the end of 2024, while other guidance on climate disclosures and sustainability reporting will only increase compliance requirements. Through SMARTSEED, GAR is supporting suppliers to address these challenges with a programme of education and capacity-building sessions led by industry experts including the Council of Palm Oil Producing Countries (CPOPC), Verité, World Resources Institute (WRI) Indonesia, Earthworm Foundation (EF), and representatives from GAR.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Aquaculture has been the fastest growing food sector in the world for decades, and people now eat morefarmed fishthanwild fish. Production of wild fish has been flat since about 1990. Fish farming and shellfish productionusually spew far lessgreenhouse gas emissionsthanproduction of beef and other animal protein. But aquaculture can still cause serious environmental problems. As it has grown, the problems with large-scale farming have grown with it. The farms and the waste from them can degrade and pollute nearby ecosystems, diseases can quickly sweep through the tightly packed fish, and gathering the feed for the animals can cause distant problems. Fish farmers are trying new ways to boost production and minimize harm. China is also trying to lessen the environmental impacts of fish farming. One way: Take it offshore, where currents can deliverclean waterand waste can dissipate quickly. In a warehouse near Miami, large indoor tanks are designed to mimic the natural environment of salmon by establishing the right temperature and salinity.
label: SENSITIVE

text: David Perry: How do we know anything, ever, at all? Not unless we decide to trust our nervous systems and the perceptions they engender. We do not, truly, know anything because all we can do is perceive, he says. Perry: Science is not possible without faith in our perceptions, yet science itself tells us how limited those unaided perceptions are. Knowing within our sliver of reality, therefore, comes naturally; all the rest is rather harder. How we know is of practical importance to us every day, for science is being abused. The science of climate change is abused by deniers of the long established and increasingly obvious, he writes. The health benefits of eating vegetables and fruits and legumes are abused every time, until science is used to tell us everything we knew most reliably yesterday, Perry says. We did not suspect that apples fell down, not up from their trees before Newton’s calculations, he adds. We know that a passing fixation on lectins does nothing to alter the established benefits of vegetables, fruits, legumes, nor does a study of routine consumption of them alter the effects of environmental factors on health, nor do we ignore the influence of social factors on the environment. In this post-truth era, we seem to have forgotten, or allow ourselves to be mislead, where science is routinely mislead about what we know, or at least where we have forgotten to be at least at least to be honest about what science is.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Elon Musk says he is unsure why one of SpaceX's Falcon rockets burst into flames. A SpaceX-led accident investigation is underway. A massive fireball enveloped the rocket on Sept. 1 as it was being fueled. SpaceX has backlog of more than 70 launches for commercial and government customers, worth more than $10 billion. The rocket that was destroyed was the second of 29 Falcon 9 rockets to fail. accident. It took SpaceX about three weeks to identify the likely cause of its previous accident, which occurred on June 28, 2015. “We remain fully confident in the results of (that) investigation ... The current investigation has no bearing on this,” SpaceX spokesman Dex Torricke-Barton wrote in an email to Reuters. SpaceX’s next flight had been slated for later this month from a second launch pad at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California. ‘We have confidence that SpaceX will resolve the matter and when they do we will be ready to launch,’ Iridium Communications Inc, told Reuters on Friday. The $200 million communications satellite owned by Israel-based Space Communication was going to be used by Facebook and Eutelsat to expand internet access in Africa. SpaceX said last week it was looking to shift its Florida launches to a nearly completed pad at NASA's Kennedy Space Center, adjacent to its Cape Canaveral site. The company has not yet said how much damage was done to its launch pad, located at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida.

text: The global regenerative agriculture market was valued at USD 920.6 million in 2022. The market is expected to reach USD 3247.34 million in 2030, with a CAGR of 14.80% during the forecast period 2023-2030. North America, specifically, the U.S. and Canada, has emerged as a leader in championing regenerative farming practices. The rapid growth of the Regenerative Agriculture market in the Asia-Pacific (APAC) region is attributed to a confluence of factors including substantial government backing, population expansion, heightened environmental consciousness, and the uptake of advanced agricultural technologies. Innovations like precision farming, data analytics, and remote sensing are enabling more efficient and effective implementation of regenerative practices. These technologies are streamlining farming operations and making regenerative Agriculture more accessible and profitable. However, transitioning from traditional farming to regenerative. practices often requires significant initial investments. This financial barrier can be a deterrent for some farmers considering the switch to Regenerative agriculture.

text: Pakistan's Wakhi shepherdesses have trekked to remote mountain pastures to graze their flocks for centuries. The income they generated has been pivotal in transforming their community, helping to pay for healthcare, education and the first road out of their valley. Today, there are only seven of the shepherdesses left. As their way of life dies out, BBC 100 Women joined them on one of their last trips to the pastures. We walk for eight hours a day through rain, snow and scorching heat. The journey that used to take the women three days takes us five. The threat of landslides is ever present and the thud of the sheep's hooves vibrates through the ground, bringing rocks and dust crashing down. In the past, to ward off wolves and leopards, they slept on rooftops, even in the harshest weather, made traps and burned fires. "We would be shoeless, and walk into the ice like that," says 88-year-old Annar.
label: SENSITIVE

text: People with synesthesia are more likely to make associations between shapes and meaningless words. The most common form of synesthesia causes people to perceive colors in letters and numbers. Synesthesia is thought to be rare, but estimates are highly variable and unclear. It may be possible to learn synesthesia, by consciously trying to associate different sensory modalities, to improve your memory and creativity, some researchers say. The condition has been linked to creativity, with some research backing it up.. One study in Australia found 24 percent of synesthetes to be involved in an artistic profession. Among the general population, this figure falls to just 2 percent, according to a study in the European Journal of Neuroscience. The study was published Sept. 15 in the Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery and Neurophysiology, a journal of the American College of Neurophysiologists and the European Society of Neuroscientists.
