text: Astronomer says laser beams could be used to make Earth stand out to other civilizations. David Kipping: "An alien civilization might choose to try and make their transit signature -- as seen by Earth -- look weird or funky" The idea of deliberately trying to make our presence known is the subject of some debate. Kipping says the idea of whether humans are alone in the universe is perhaps our species' ultimate question. "To say that I hope, certainly it would be intellectually extremely interesting if we discovered something. In that sense, it'd be fantastic," he says. "There's over 2,000 confirmed planets, and we definitely have examples, no matter how you slice and dice it, of planets which resemble Earth in the Kepler data," he adds. "We are already looking for their signature. Somehow, if they follow the same path of detecting planets, they would perhaps assume this very simple method might be one way to broadcast themselves," says Kipping. "Who can predict what possible benefits a confirmed signal would have? It's impossible for us to foresee how that could change our society," said Kipping, who is based at Columbia University in New York. "This has lots of advantages," Kipping said of the laser-created patterns. "It's a very simple way to cloak our planet from the prying eyes of those in deep space who would do us harm," said a graduate student who wrote a paper on the topic. "I think it's a great idea," said Columbia's Alan Teachey.
label: SAFE

text: A mother spider sacrifices herself as prey to her offspring as an essential step to waking up their hunting instincts. The process is called matriphagy, or mother-eating. This cannibalistic process can happen within a few hours of birth, and is common in several arachnid species and a few other closely-related creatures. The mother then presses herself into her babies, stimulating instinct even more -- then the final switch is flipped, and they attack. Now, what has your mother done for you today? text: The Mars InSight landercame to an end last year as its solar panels were covered with dust and its power supply slowly dwindled away. Insight leaves an incredible legacy though, having provided the best-ever look at the interior of Mars and being the first time a seismometer has been used on another planet. To learn about how a single little lander was able to look through an entire planet, we spoke to two leading scientists on the inSight team. We learn about Earth’s interior structure by looking at how seismic waves travel through the planet, and we can do the same thing on Mars. To understand how Mars has evolved — Why did it have a different atmosphere in the past from today? — you have to understand the interior structure,” Catherine Johnson of the University of British Columbia said. “Each mission results in a big leapfrog forward in our understanding” said Mark Panning of NASA” It wasn’t easy to convince people that InSighting would be able to detect useful information all on its own, especially considering that a seismometers had never been placed on anotherPlanet.”
label: SAFE

text: Elasmobranchs (which includes sharks, skates, and rays) have thrived for over 450 million years and survived Earth's most dramatic climate shifts. Yet, in today's world of rapidly warming oceans, they face a new and formidable challenge. Climate change has brought to light the importance of species' ability to adapt to changing conditions, either by redistributing to more suitable thermal habitats or by demonstrating phenotypic plasticity and adaptation. The key to understanding this challenge lies in the context of their ecology and mobility, as the degree to which a species can move and adjust to new environments plays a crucial role. This applies to sharks and their relatives, too, as they range from the elusive tiger shark to the resilient epaulette shark, the versatile blacktip reef shark, and the adaptable Atlantic stingray. With over 1,000 species under the ‘elasmOBranch’ label, each creature brings its unique strategies to the table to combat rising temperatures and shifting environments.
label: SENSITIVE

text: NASA's Mars robots receive their commands from the mission team at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California. This is due to that massive fireball in the sky — aka the sun — coming between Earth and Mars. The celestial event is known as solar conjunction and happens every couple of years. Affected robots include the Perseverance rover, which reached the Martian surface in 2021, and the Curiosity rover,. which landed in 2012. NASA’s three orbiters — Odyssey, Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, and MAVEN — are affected, too. The two weeks of downtime allows the team at JPL to catch up on other work or take a vacation. The robotic explorers will stay busy though, collecting weather data, listening for marsquakes, and more:https://t.co/d8OrX4JD4Wpic.twitter.com/NH01Rd5GUe — NASA Mars (@NASAMars)September 28, 2021. We'll stand down from commanding our Mars missions for the next few weeks while Earth and the Red Planet are on opposite sides of the Sun.
label: SAFE

text: Crocodiles have a rich and varied evolutionary past. Researchers are peeling back the layers to find out how the surviving species came to be. There are about 28 living species of crocodilians found throughout the tropical and sub-tropical regions of the world. A pair of new papers has been delving into this rich evolutionary history, tracking where this group originated and how it spread around the world, as well as exploring the origin of their typical slow growth. Researchers found that the larger, modern group of crocodILians likely first appeared in Europe up to 145 million years ago. The ancestors of crocodiles and alligators then split from each other in North America, with the ability for crocodiles to tolerate saltwater meaning that they were then able to spread much further than alligators. It turns out that the life history of crocodile size turns out to be equally complex. The fossils of these creatures were in fact fast-growing, lethargic, active animals. It is now thought that many of these gigantic animals were growing far quicker than would be assumed for their size.
label: SAFE

text: Nokia introduced eco-friendly product packaging in 2022, for its broadband customer premises equipment. Nokia’s new packaging eliminates non-biodegradable foam, plastic, bleaching, toxic materials and chemical treatments. The buffer material which protects the product from dropping damage, is made from fully recyclable carboard components in compliance with the Forest Stewardship Council. In 2022 Nokiawon 6 Red Dot Awards, including their ‘Best of the Best’ distinction, and 8 iF Awards for the Nokia Networks Sustainable Packaging System that uses organic, biodesgradable material and reduces transport cost as well as waste disposal. Nokia has committed to Science Based Targets through which the company aims to cut greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 50% by 2030. It is in line with limiting global warming to 1.5°C by 2030 and reaching net zero by 2050. The packaging is also more compact, which allows more efficient transport and further reduces CO2 emissions by up to 60%.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Artist Alison Nastasi has compiled photos of famous artists and their cats. The book, Artists and Their Cats, is a "family album" of sorts. From Picasso to Frida Kahlo to Salvador Dali, the felines behind some of the biggest painters and sculptors in the business. The idea for the book came from a Flavorwire article about Tracey Emin and her cat Docket, which had just died. The artist-cat duos featured in the book predate Internet culture's feline obsession, but Nastasia says she thinks it's "fantastic" for the cause of animal welfare and spaying-and-neutering. of sorts, the book includes photos of Agnès Varda, Henri Matisse and his cat Zgougou, Patti Smith and her furry guardian, and many more. The photos were sourced from libraries, photo archives and artist families to create her " family album" Of sorts, featuring tender moments between animal and man, including photos of Picasso, Matisse, VardA and Patti, the author says: "There’s a mutual respect or symbiosis ... Working in the studio can be isolating sometimes. Cats bring life to a space that still provides an artist with the necessary alone time to thrive" She adds: "I think the cat obsession has helped bring attention to various animal rescue organizations and special-needs animals that might have been previously ignored.”
label: SENSITIVE

text: Officials in baseball are defending their decision during a crucial moment in yesterday's World Championships. The call in question determined the outcome of the game, and replay footage shows the ruling was marginal. League officials emphasize that referees make split-second decisions in high-pressure situations. Discussion has turned to whether instant replay review should be expanded. The officiating crew will meet with supervisors to review the call and discuss proper protocol. The officials will also discuss the use of instant replay in the future. The World Championships are being held in New York City and Los Angeles. The games are expected to last until Sunday night, with the final to be played on Monday night at 8:30 p.m. ET. text: A recent scientific study on dark matter has sparked ethical debates within the research community. The experiment involved animal subjects, which some ethicists argue raises concerns about appropriate research boundaries. The research team maintains that proper protocols were followed and the study provides valuable insights. An independent ethics review board is examining the methodology. Scientists emphasize the importance of balancing scientific progress with ethical considerations. text: About 100 genetically modified papaya trees were hacked down with machetes on Thursday night. The act is believed to be an act of eco-terrorism rather than random vandalism. The Big Island is currently considering the future of biotech on the island. One of the bills would require that the island's GMO papaya fields be cut down entirely, and farmers caught growing GMO papayas would face jail and fines. In 2011, about 10 acres of trees were cut down on the same papaya farm, and the year before, some 8,500 papaya Trees were similarly cut down. The police never solved those cases, and they have not been solved this time around, as well as a 2011 papaya incident in which about 8,000 trees were also cut down in the same area of the Big Island. In the 1950s, a ring spot virus wiped out Hawaii's papaya industry. The genetically modified version is credited with saving Hawaii's $11 million papayaindustry, which is now worth about $10 million a year to the state, according to the Hawaii Papaya Industry Association. It's not the first time activists have attacked genetically modified crops. Activists have taken weed-whackers to drought-resistant wheat crops in Australia and genetically modified eggplants in the Philippines. It means somebody has to have passionate reason, an industry official said, "It's hard to imagine anybody putting that much effort into doing something like that," he told the AP. The incident -- the damages of which are valued at about three thousand dollars -- was relatively contained.
label: UNSAFE

text: There has been much comment in the media about the issue of banks either denying accounts to people or closing the accounts of existing customers. What is slightly puzzling to me is that people are getting angry with the banks when the banks are responding rationally to the economic incentives set for them by their regulators. The U.S. Treasury Department has said that bank de-risking could hurt some communities and even “pose a national security risk” by driving transactions out of regulated institutions and into shadowy corners of global finance where they cannot be monitored. Instead, why not take low-risk people out of the loop completely? Go to a bank with your passport and get a Fed Pre Number. Then when you open a bank account, hire an accountant or wire money to an elephant in Thailand, without filing an SAR, you can give your money to the elephant. We could recognise this by allowing people with Fed Pre Numbers to send $100,000 to the Fed, and not need to do that.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Kevin O'Brien's new book offers an intimate look at living with depression while pursuing a creative career. The memoir describes both struggles and triumphs, showing that mental health challenges can be managed successfully. The book is being used in some psychology courses to provide patient perspectives. Readers report finding comfort and validation in Kevin O'sBrien's story. The author credits therapy, medication, and strong support systems for recovery. text: Spanish design students have created a "water bottle" that you can eat. "Ooho" is a gelatinous blob that is actually a membrane that encapsulates water. The gooey membrane is edible, hygienic and biodegradable. The design was a winner of the second annual Lexus Design Award and will also be featured during Milan Design Week."Anyone can make them in their kitchen, modifying and innovating the recipe," said co-designer Rodrigo García González. "It's not DIY but CIY — cook it yourself," said another co-Designer Guillaume Couche of the Ooho design. 'Ooho' is the first such container designed specifically for replacing water bottles, but it could be used for running sports events, for example, and could be infused with electrolytes to give competitors an athletic edge. The bag-like containers are also incredibly cheap — each one costs just 2 cents to make, and they could even be concocted at home, according to García García, who said the design is "not DIY butCIY — cooking it yourself" and can be made in the kitchen or on the go, he said. The Ooho globule is formed through a process called "spherification," a methodology first pioneered in 1946 and still utilized by some chefs in modern cuisine. It is frozen into ice before being encapsulated to ease the process and prevent the water from mixing with the membrane ingredients.
label: SAFE

text: The University of Colorado football team delivered Saturday misery for years. Deion Sanders, or Coach Prime, has radically made over this year’s team. His success could open doors for more Black head coaches at the highest levels of the college game. More than 8 million people watched Colorado beat Colorado State in double overtime after 2:15 a.m. Eastern time in mid-September. The scene “feels like Black Hollywood,” says one sideline spectator. “The atmosphere is electric, man,’ DaBaby tells me before leaving the field. Right now this is the most exciting place to be in football’’ The Buffaloes enjoyed just four winning seasons in the past 20 years and finished 1-11 in 2022, according to a report by the Colorado Athletic Association. The team has already exceeded expectations and stimulated the college-football economy, and compelled more than eight million people to watch Colorado beat the Trojans, the report says. It also says that teams with majority-Black players help generate, in some cases, north of $100 million in annual revenue.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Harvard University is offering a course titled " Taylor Swift and Her World" The course aims to dissect the multifaceted influence of the pop icon on music, lyrics, culture, and beyond. The University of Florida is also joining this academic exploration with Melina Jimenez's course, "Musical Storytelling with Taylor Swift" Other notable figures, such as former One Direction member Harry Styles, Nicki Minaj, and Bad Bunny, have also been the focus of university courses. Other institutions, including Ghent University in Belgium, the University of Texas at Austin, Berklee College of Music , and the University Of California, are similarly acknowledging the profound impact of Taylor Swift on contemporary culture. The curriculum goes beyond a mere examination of Swift's contributions to popular music, delving into how her artistry intersects with the literary canon. The phenomenon is further underscored by the resounding success of her Eras tour . Professor Burt emphasizes that Taylor Swift's presence, whether in her talks or through her musical creations, leaves an enduring imprint on her ever-growing fan base.
label: SAFE

text: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida attacked his onetime mentor, former President Donald Trump, on Wednesday. Trump was weighing in on theongoing conflict between Israel and the militant group Hamasduring a rally in Florida. Pro-Trump accounts on X have since hit back at deSantis for his criticism of Trump. The Trump War Room, an X account linked to the Trump campaign, said DeSantas had mischaracterized Trump's remarks on the war. The presidential hopeful often shies away from attacking Trump directly, a political science professor told Insider in July. The pro-Trump account hit back, saying: "Smart does not equal good. It just proves Biden is stupid, Ron. And now you look stupid,Ron.""It is absurd that anyone ... would choose now to attack our friend and ally, Israel, much less praise Hezbollah terrorists as 'very smart," DeSanta wrote in a Wednesday post on X. "It's a very tough line because so many of the voters [DeSantis] wants — they like Trump," the professor said.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The J.A. & Kathryn Albertson Family Foundation (JKAF) announced today the completion of the Idaho Outdoor Fieldhouse. The 46,000 square-foot facility has been designed to create an inclusive and empowering environment for military veterans and athletes with physical disabilities. The Fieldhouse offers unparalleled amenities, housing, and medical wellness services tailored to meet the specific needs of its members. In Idaho, there are an estimated 200,000 individuals living with disabilities and 125,000 veterans, many of whom are eligible to receive support and benefit from CAF and Mission43 programs. For more information about Mission43, visit mission43.org. About Challenged Athletes Foundation-Idaho, visit Challenged. Athletes. Foundation. To learn more about The Idaho outdoor Fieldhouse, visit:https://www.idahofieldhouse.org/ Media Resources●Images for Media●Idaho Outdoor Field House Video/Broll for Media # # ## About JKAFTheJ.A., Kathryn, and A.A.: The J.KAF is committed to making Idaho an exemplary model for innovative learning, a world-class destination for accessiblerecreation, and the most desirable state for life after the military.

text: Students flooded the stands with teal at Michigan State University’s basketball game Friday night. Teal is the official color of Sexual Assault Awareness Month, which occurs in April. Over 140 women have accused sports doctor Larry Nassar of sexual abuse, including Olympic gymnasts Aly Raisman, Gabby Douglas, McKayla Maroney and Simone Biles. Nassar, 54, was sentenced to 40 to 175 years in prison for child sexual abuse this week. In the wake of Nassar's sentencing, MSU has faced its own firestorm of criticism. The university's president, Lou Anna Simon, and athletic director, Mark Hollis, have succumbed to the pressure and resigned this week, The Detroit News reported. The school beat the University of Wisconsin, 76-61, on Friday night, according to the university's athletic department. The game was played in the Breslin Student Events Center’'s student section, also known as the Izzone, for coach Tom Izzo. The sea-colored supporters covered the B Reslin Student events Center”s student section. The University ofWisconsin won the game, 73-55, and the game will be shown live on ESPN2 on Sunday at 8 p.m. ET. The MSU basketball team is currently ranked No. 1 in the nation. The Michigan State team is No. 2 in the Big Ten, ahead of Ohio State and Penn State. The team is also No. 3 in the National Collegiate Basketball Association.
label: UNSAFE
